column2: Pending in the New Jersey Senate's judiciary committee is an amendment to that state's laws governing rape. The bill Specifies that evidence of an alleged rape victims's sexual conduct "other than with the defendant" cannot be introduced at the suspect's trial unless the victim offers it.

Richard L. Roudebush, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, said today that there was "no question" in his mind that Congress would override President Ford's veto of a bill increasing education benefits for veterans.

Vast new vistas of parklands, scenic beachfronts, entire new islands in Long Island Sound; clean water for bathing, shellfishing and recreational use; new industries attracted by better transportation, shipping and a plentiful supply of pollution-free energy--all these and more are in the panorama of possibilities painted by the long-awaited draft report of the Long Island Sound Regional Study.
Israeli cuisine, naturally, will be among the featured displays at the 1974 North Jersey Israeli Fair, which begins a four-day run today at Temple Sharey Shalom. Hours are 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.
Even if she were not black, young Adrienne America would be an unusual phenomenon in the world of figure skating because she is deaf.

Olivia Newton-John is an Australian vocalist who has spent most of her musical career singing English pop tunes. But five weeks ago, having "crossed over" and joined the stampede to the Nashville sound with a country-style gold record

According to a recent Louis Harris poll, 65 per cent of the people in the United States think the country is now in a recession. Administration officials have acknowledged that we are in a recession, and most economists and newspaper correspondentss now take it for granted.

Whimsey is a most demanding theatrical art, and Katherine Litz has made a long career of it. She has mastered the preoccupied dither, the ex-. pression of perpetual questing and unruffled acceptance of even the bizarre.
For reasons of compassion and common sense, the state polic in Connecticut have been cutting back in stages on the arrests they make, according to Police Commisioner Cleveland B. Fuessenich.
Mr. and Mrs. Murray H. Ocko of Brooklyn and Danbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Sue Ocko, to Ralph Z. Levy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Levy of Nashville.

It was a sociologists version of a church supper: Everyone was bringing something to the "instant museum" at Maspeth Town Hall, where until Tuesday, the cultural history of Maspeth will be depicted through the artifacts and memorabilia of its residents.
The Fiat Motor Company, Italy's largest private employer, reached agreement today with trade unions on production cuts after 17 hours of continuous negotiations, informed sources said.

Joe Washington ran for two touchdowns, one a brilliant 57-yard punt return, as Oklahoma beat upset-minded oklahoma State today, 44-13. Oklahoma, trailing 13-10, unleashed a 34-point second-half to gain the victory.

Looking through some of the recent volumes of photographs that are now pouring from the presses in happy profusion, one is easily persuaded that photographers can be divided into two classes: those who eagerly seek out the history of their time, and those who are consciously and programmatically in flight from it.

The Justice Department having filed its biggest antitrust action ever--against the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the biggest corporation the world has to offer-it should come as no surprise that just about everything on the subject comes out in superlatives.
Edgar Sayers is not having much trouble selling his fire alarms after one of them worked convincingly for him.

Guy Beaufort is one of the few auto dealers wearing a smile these days. With major car prices up and sales drastically down, Mr. Beaufort says that business at his electric car dealership is on the upswing.

Jerusalem has become a more economical place to visit this winter, following the 43 per cent devaluation of the Israeli pound last month. The rate of exchange is now 6 Israeli pounds to the dollar, compared with 4.2 pounds before devaluation.
Emil A. Liloiva accrued a medical bill of more than $10,000 in the last 70 hours of his life, and the administrator of his estate wants doctors to justify every cent.

We are in for a rare treat, ladies and gentlemen. We are standing behind the arras in the famous Oval Office where President Ford, seated behind the famous Oval Desk, is about to be briefed on American foreign policy in the Middle East.

The Garden State Ballet, under the direction of Fred Danieli, will present Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" at Symphony Hall next Sunday. The performance will mark the beginning of the company's third annual tour of the state.

Words that haunt: Diron Talbert, Redskins' defensive tackle, discloses before Washington's key game with the Dallas Cowboys: "If you knock Roger Staubach out, you've got that rookie (Clint Longley) facing you. That's one of our goals. If we do that, it's great." Longley's sensational passing pulled out a 24-23 victory.
If one really loves natural history books there is an intriguing fantasy about coming down on Christmas morning -say in 1838 --and finding a set of the Audubon Double Elephant Folio under the tree.

Bill Cleland is not sure just what the New Jersey Jazz Society is, but he ??s know that it is surprisingly successful. "We know we're not a traditional jazz club," the society's 67-year-old president said in explaining its musical ideology.

Eight days short of the seventh year after he did the first heart transplant, the South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard has performed an experimental operation he suggests may help with two of the fundamental medical factors that limit the success of the transplant procedure.
Silencio, por favor," and a raised hand. That's the way New Jersey's "Outstanding Teacher of the Year" keeps classroom order.
United States Attorney Earl J. Silbert has canceled his order not to prosecute persons with small amounts of marijuana in the District of Columbia.

Frederick Wiseman-lawyer, social critic, master of cinema verite and, in the opinion of many, this country's most interesting filmmaker-is about to subject television audiences to an unsettling hour and a half of prime-time viewing.

There is nothing nations like to do better than to display on stamps their native artistry and cultural heritage--and now it is carpets. Tapestries have, of course, appeared often, but carpets seem to be new. And in the realm of philately, where one leads others are certain to follow, and in time collectors may be making a specialty of collecting carpets on stamps and becoming experts on their exquisite patterns and rich variety.

Margot Nystrom chose unbeaten paths in her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. The Swedish pianist not only included three contemporary works (by Maurice Karkoff, Hilding Rosenberg and Goffredo Petrassi) but also offcred comparatively neglected pieces by Haydn and Sohubert.
Canada is preparing to propose a new international development-aid partnership with the Arab oilproducing states--the Arabs would provide the money and Canada the expertise.
ROCKAWAY -- Despite wide-open space, lakes and hills, the principal characteristics of this sprawling Morris County community of 45.3 square miles,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George R. Lustig Jr. of Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Lustig, to Jeffrey F. Lehman, son of 'Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Lehman of Lancaster, Pa. Miss Lustig is a senior at Messiah College in Grantham, Pa., from which her fiance graduated this year.
Massachusetts businessman who was kidnapped Thursday and taken to Canada by three hitchhikers was found unharmed today by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Pope Paul VI today formally awarded the Pope John XIII Peace Prize to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, but indirectly expressed surprise at recent decisions virtually ousting Israel from membership in the organization.
The following City Council hearings, which are open to the public, will be held this week. Unless otherwise noted, they will be held in the Council's chambers.

Breathes there a mother with soul so dead who never to everyone around has said: "My son knows all the baseball averages." One of the great attractions of baseball is the averages. Never mind that a Manny Mota spends a career outhitting a Johnny Bench; the averages and all the other statistics, for better or for worse, give people something to chew on.

Reggle JacKson, DicK Allen, Tony Perez and Steve Carlton-all baseball untouchables less than a year ago-are good bets to wind up as trade bait this week when the major league moguls gather here for their annual winter meetings.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Harold Charles Gotoff of Melrose, Mass., on Nov. 6 at the Meirose - Wakefield Hospital. Mrs. Gotoff is the former Margot Lee Jacobson of New York. The child has been named Daniel Robert.

Art works and antiques that the police said were worth more than $100,000 were reportd stolen last night by a woman who returned from a holiday trip and found her East Side apartment broken into. The woman was identified as Cathlen Poulos, the tenant of a top-floor apartment in a 35story building at 245 East 63d Street.

A daughter was born Nov. 26 to Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Pearlman of Cliffside Park, N.J., at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The child has been named Mia Beth. Mr. Pearlman is a producer with NBC News.

Rodrigo Valdes retained the World Boxing Council version of the middleweight boxing title tonight by knocking out Gratien Tonna in the 11th round. The finish set off a controversy that almost evolved into a free for all in the ring.
All the New York stars faltered here this afternoon in the fight for the national mixed-pair title during the second day of play in the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals.
Some of the statements contained in the letters from tenant representatives [Nov. 17] were simply irresponsible.

A new "home away from home" for the elderly, the St. Charles Jubliee Center, 277 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights, was dedicated last week by Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

When Ed Logue gets up in the morning and looks out of the windows of his apartment at 1 East End Avenue, he sees what any prosperous east-facing East-Sider (living between Gracie Square and the U.N.) can see, which is a two-mile-long rocky sliver of an island splitting the fierce currents of the East River.
For $650,000 this Christmas you can learn the secrets of oddsmaking and gambling from Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker whose betting lines appear in over 200 American newspapers.

With the country sliding rapidly into what appears to be a serious recession, suggestions are being made to revive the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as part of an overall economic program. The Democratic leadership has proposed this step and has introduced the necessary legislation.

Leslie Amelia Lynch, who is in the industrial relations department of Bethlehem Steel in Burns Harbor, Ind., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert John Westerman, a lawyer who works in labor relations for the United States Steel Corporation in Gary, Ind. The Rev.
The official themes at the United Nations these days are Korea and the Middle East, but when delegates cluster in the corridors they are most likely discussing the case of the disgraced princess.

What are community planning boards and why is everybody saying such harsh things about them? If criticism from all quarters is a sure sign of arrival, New York City's community boards--the neighborhood councils chartered by the city to advise officials on the "public welfare" of their communities--are fast approaching immortality.

Members of the International Association of Machinists and Areospace Workers tonight ratified a proposal for a three-year contract with the Pratt Whit-ney Aircraft Division of the United Aircraft Corporation, largest employer in Connecticut.
New Jersey waters are destined to become the southern end of a new and Important tanker route-the Northwest Passage.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Jon Voight, film and stage luminary, and Susan Bloom, producer and music publisher, have joined forces for the presentation of "The Hashish Club," a play by Lance Larsen at the Bijou Theater on Jan. 5.
The police said today that some Alabama motorists "could be riding around in a time bomb" because they bought fake antifreeze containing methyl alcohol.
When Tony Donadio enrolled in Ohio State University four years ago he was adamant Like against joining a fraternity because he regarded the organizations as "petty."

Two 15-year-old girls who had abortions under Medi-Cal, the California program of medical aid to the poor, have filed a civil rights suit in Federal District Court. here to stop the state from violating their right of privacy by mailing detailed medical statements to their homes.

The 63d annual appeal for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will open next Sunday Since 1912, when The Times published a report of conditions among destitute families in the city, the fund has helped thou sands of unfortunate people in the metropolitan area.
The disputants in the Middle East were maneuvering for superior position last week but whether for renewed peace talks or renewed fighting was not clear. Here is what the parties did:

Mr. and Mrs. James Martin Van Buren of Walton, N. Y., and New. York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katrina Elizabeth Van Buren, to Edward Taws Claghorn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Strawbridge Claghorn of Philadelphia.

Cancer of the colon and rectum is often called "the cancer nobody talks about." It might also be called the cancer that little is done about. Yet it is the most common life-threatening cancer in the United States today, and a means of preventing most fatal cases has been available for nearly 60 years.
She looks and sounds like a sensual Betty Boop, with her cherubic blue eyes, button nose and rosebud lips strange. ly coexisting with a snug.

A car pool matching program here that is aided by Federal, state and local funds is having trouble attracting participants. The program, which uses a computer to match up commuters in pools, was proposed at the height of the fuel crisis a year ago, when gasoline was in short supply. But because of bureaucratic delays, it did not get under way until August: and with the waning of the crisis came a waxing of apathy.

On the evening Muhammad Ali boxed George Foreman in Zaire, a man looked across the dining room in the Penn Plaza Club upstairs in Madison Square Garden and said: "There are three men at that table who could whip Ali the best night he ever had." Following his gaze, the man's companion saw Jack Dempsey,

In a truly fantastic turnabout that will rank among the most retold legends of an already legendary rivalry, the University of California spotted Notre Dame a 24 0 lead in the first 29 minutes of play and then demolished the Irish in a 55-24 victory.

According to the readers of True Story magazine, Mary E. Chase is the fifth most outstanding "Woman of the Year," ranking behind Loretta Lynn, Julie Eisenhower, Pat Nixon and Billie Jean King, but ahead of Mary Tyler Moore, Rose Kennedy, Dale Evans and Susan Hayward.
A measure calling for the establishment of a tax court to accelerate and improve the administration of property-levy appeals in the state was approved by the Assembly last week.

The view of Manhattan is spectacular from the Lumber Terminal Exchange, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn But despite the glittering panorama, the current mood at the exchange is less than cheerful.

Jean Barbara Mackenzie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Mackenzie of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., was married in Huntington at noon yesterday to Norman Edward Novotny, son of Mrs. Edward Arthur Novotny of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and the late Mr. Novotny.

Emma Sheridan is 11, fat, black, and her Afro keeps wilting. Her pesky younger brother Willie seems to be a throw-back to the earlier "feets do yo' stuff" stereotype, tap dancing his way improbably through life. They are the despair of the senior Sheridans, straight-arrows up out of hard times, living now on East End Avenue.
It was been three years since Dan Cooper parachuted from a Northwest Airlines jet that he had hijacked with $200,000 in ransom money. Two more, and he'll be home free--if he's alive.

Anyone who thinks that the explosion of Federal spending in the last five or six years is a major cause of the nation's economic troubles can take little comfort from the elaborate program of expenditure reduction set to Congress by President Ford last week.
Chang Che - chung returned from the United Stated eight months ago with a master's degree in electrical engineering and since then, he says, he is constantly asked, "Why did you come back?"

Angered by the possibility of restrictions on alterations to their homes, several residents of the Steinway section of Astoria, Queens, said last week that they planned to challenge the city Landmarks Preservation Commission's recommendation that the area be given historicdistrict status.
Armand Hill, a. sophomore guard, pumped in 21 points and grabbed seven rebounds tonight as Princeton opened with a 70-47 victory over Fordham at Jadwin Gym.

RICHARD ADAMS'S "Watership Down" (Macmillan, $6.95) is the Odyssey and Iliad of rab bits, for people of all ages - a splendidly written adventure story, a rather broad allegory, a meditation on bravery, a text on ecology, a lecture against totalitarianism and a passionate act of imaginative projection.

Janet Sue Gunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Gunter of New Hyde Park, L. I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday morning to Dennis Edwardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Edwardson of Lantana, Fla.
Starting today, New Jersey boatmen will be able to register their craft and obtain a motorboat operator's license with the same case and convenience as they register their motor vehicles.

It's specials time. Television is stumbling over itself in an effort to offer temporary relief from the tired formats of regular weekly series. Among the special items on prime-time tap this Week: Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward treking through "The Wild Places," a new version of "The Red Badge of Courage,"
Handcrafted pottery does not come cheap these days, unless it comes from the ovens of a place such as The Salem Craftsmen's Gnuild. The prices are surprisingly, and even incredibly, low.

The stock market ended an abbreviated week in dull fashion on Friday with most issues showing only minor price changes . At the conclusion of trading last week, the Dow Jones industrral average stood at 618.66, up 3.36 points for the week. Advances and declines were almost evenly divided. The market was closed on Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving. Volume was light throughout the week.

Governmental bodies moved last week toward decisions on three major projects that have aroused varying degrees of enthusiasm in the once-thriving downtown Brooklyn neighborhoods stretching along Flatbush Avenue from the Fulton Street shopping area to Prospect Park.
With the acquisition of Naum Gabo's "Spheral Theme" sculpture, now installed on an opulent stretch of green, Princeton University has registered a crowning achievement in the world of outdoor art.
The Virginia Squires withstood four 3-point goals by Bill Keller of Indiana in the last 2.28 and broke a seven-game losing streak tonight with a 121-120 A.B.A. victory over the Pacers.

Of the three new photography books, lying on my desk, Leni Riefenstahl's THE LAST OF THE NUBA (Harper Row, $18.95) is unique; and the making of it is a story. Mrs. Riefenstahl, a well-known film maker and actress in Germany before and during the Hitler years (she directed "The Triumph of the Will" and "Olympiad"), was seduced into going to Africa by reading Hemingway's "Green Hills of Africa."

Miss Vicki, who was 17 years old when she married the singer Tiny Tim five years ago before a television audience of 45 million people, has been on welfare in New Jersey since August, according to The Philadelphia Sunday Bulletin.

To the Editor: Your Nov. 25 editorial on the Justice Department's antitrust action against the Bell System correctly states that the case is of enormous importance. Regrettably, however; the editorial contains several misallegations and totally ignores the interests of those who stand to lose the most from this action: the nation's telephone users.

By an intentional coincidence on the part of publishers there's a new book to put you in the mood on each of the 24 nights before Christmas. Making your own presents or decorations? Take your pick--"Christmas Crafts" or "Crafts for Christmas." Thinking about the tree? You can select from among "The Silver Christmas Tree,"
India and Pakistan decided today to end their 10-year-old ban on trade.

Dr. Paul F. Brissenden, economist and labor mediator, who retired in the mid-nineteenfifties as chairman of the industry-labor relations department of the Columbia University faculty of business, died Friday in Lemon Grove, Calif. He was 89 years old and formerly lived in Mountain Lakes, N.J.
The marriage of Nancy Henderson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Faxon Henderson of Palm Beach, Fla., to Richard Scott Hood of Charleston, S.C., took place in Palm Beach last night.
Syosset, the No. 1-ranked high school football team in the state, beat stubborn Berner, 8-6, today and won the Conference I-II championship in the Nassau County playoffs at C. W. Post College.

Charles Schmitt, a RolisRoyce dealer, sold one man seven of the cars this week for more than $1-million. Among the seven purchased Wednesday were the Queen Juliana Rolls-Royce Phantom, worth $280,000, and a 1930 Rolls valued at $200,000.
A Massachusetts businessman who was kidnapped Thursday and taken to Canada by three hitchhikers was found unharmed today by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Last January, F.B.I. agents in Los Angeles broke into a one-story building which, they had excellent reason to believe, was the center of a large-scale "tape-pirating" operation. Sure enough, they found $100,000 worth of tapeduplicating equipment.
While private industry, and the Federal Government are deeply in debt, most state governments have surplus fundsenough to pay off two-thirds of this year's Federal deficit of $6.3-billion.
A state judge has barred Standard Oil of Califorria from drilling new wells in Santa Barbara Channel, pending a decision on whether an environmental impact report should be filed on the project.

Anne Loudon, research editor of Kuhn, Loeb Co., investment bankers, and John James Closner, president of Preload Technology, Inc., in Garden City, L. I., were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L. I. The Rev.

With the State Supreme Court deadline now only a month off, Senate Democrats have scheduled a two-day conference, starting tomorrow, in an effort to come up with a new system for financing public schools in New'Jersey.

SIMPLE FRENCH FOOD, by Richard Olney (Atheneum, $10) has the most marvelous French food to appear in print since Elisabeth David's "French Provincial Cooking."

New York University will increase its scholrship aid to graduate and doctoral-level minority students in the science fields through a rise in the Martin Luther King Fund, which the university established in 1968.

North Carolina State, with David Thomson scoring 33 points, opened its season today with a 98-81 triumph over East Carolina. State's pair of guards, Monte Towe and Moe Rivers, stole the ball the first four times East Carolina brought it down the floor.

Q: The cement floor in our basement has been painted several times with grey paint. White deposits keep showing up through the paint, spoiling the appearance. The house is about 20 years old and the basement seems dry, but the problem worsens each year. Can you help us with this problem?-Mrs. H. J. V., Montreal, Que.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Armand Reid of Rye, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laurelaine Michelle Reid, to Bruce Gavin Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Morrison of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next June.
Canadian politicians, who have traditionally depended on big corporations for most of their campaign funds, are being forced to turn their attention to individual donors.

Greek and Greek-Cypriote leaders opened talks here today to seek a common stand on further handling of the Cyprus problem. Premier Constantine Caramanlis of Greece and Archbishop Makarios, the deposed President of Cyprus, led the two sides, which met for more than two hours.
Pioneer 11, after a coasting journey of almost two years, is rapidly plunging toward its crack-the-whip trip around Jupiter Monday night.

Last year, the second largest bank in the country paid the nation's largest law firm $3.6million in fees. At least 51 law firms billed more than $500,000 each to corporate clients. And a partner who was dismissed last summer by one of New York City's most prestigious firms for misusing a client's fees sat on seven corporate boards.
Fred Greene's formula for keeping youngsters out of trouble is a mixture of motivation, self-respect, responsibility, talented guidance-and a little money.

Mary Stoll Warner of Louisville, Ky., and Theodore L. Cross, a New York lawyer; were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church in Peewee Valley, Ky. The Rev. Robert W. Estill of Alexandria, Va., performed the ceremony.
Wendy Alix Ghislaine Loree, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Loree Jr, of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald Frank Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Wood of Fresno, Calif.

It is no secret that Israel is becoming more and more isolated diplomatically, and it is no secret either that if it came, as it might, to the question of preserving Israel's existence, that nation could and would turn to the United States for an answer.

There is a feeling among many New York Giant players that tomorrow afternoon's game against the Chicago Bears (2 P.M., Eastern standard time, Chan. nel 2) may signal the end of the club's: self-destruction era and the beginning of better times.

A package of bills designed to protect widows is about to come up for consideration by the Legislature. The legislation, described by the sponsors as the first comprehensive revision of New Jersey probate laws in 23 years, is scheduled for an Assembly vote tomorrow.
Handicappers who play percentages might do well to draw a circle around El Pitirre in their early figuring for next year's Kentucky Derby.

A former assistant to J. Edgar Hoover has recommended that the Federal Bureau of Investigation be stripped of all authority over domestic security and foreign intelligence operations to keep the agencys power within bounds.

Red and green signs delaring "Little Italy is love" were neatly posted along Mulberry Street yesterday as the neighborhood opened its first weekend of making its main thoroughfare more attractive for people by keeping out cars.
Chancelor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany appeared before the Labor Party conference here today and urged Britain to remain in the Common Market.

The Eliot Feld Ballet, which officially opens its second New York season this even ing at Joseph Papp's Public Theater on Lafayette Street, has been critically hailed as one of the county's most distinguished young companies.

Mr. and Mrs. James A. Humphreys Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paget King Humphreys, to Hans Stephen Goerl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Goerl of Anif, near Salzburg, Austria, formerly of Pound Ridge. N.Y.

Is there a shortage of nurses in New Jersey? In Trenton, the people. who make studies and long-range forecasts of tile state's health-manpower needs say there is not. Furthermore, they predict that the state will have a surplus of nurses in 10 years, perhaps in five.
HARTSEL, Colo.--One hundred years after they were slaughtered by hunters to the brink of extinction buffalo are making a comeback.

Alexis Zehel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Zehel of Kent, Ohio, and Richard M. Sternhell of Mount Kisco, N. Y., son of Mrs. Charles M. Sternhell, of Lynbrook, L. I., and the late Mr. Sternhell, were married yesterday afternoon by Mayor Gertrude Cummingham of Ravenna, Ohio, at the Zehel home.
Floyd Layne, who came back from shame and scandal, returned triumphantly to City College of New York last night. In a way, so did many of his friends.
The Canadian Government has announced a study to decide whether the 53foot rise and fall of the tide in the Bay of Fundy can be used to generate electricity.

The world's rarest bird, the Hauritius kestrel, may yet be haved from extinction. Only seven of the tiny hawklike birds are known to survive, and they are on the Indian Ocean island-state of Mauritius where the big flightless dodo bird was exterminated by European settlers in 1681.
Totem poles, sculptures, bowls, masks and other ceremonial objects form the nucleus of the exhibition of Northwest Coast Indian art at the Amron Galleries through Dec. 14.
A water main ruptured on the Lower East Side and ripped open a 12-foot-deep hole at the intersection of Rivington and Ludlow Streets.
Ouida Bergere Rathbone, a writer for stage and screen, as well as an actress and theatrical agent, died Friday in Roosevert Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived at 15 West 72d Street.

The piety, whimsy and extraordinary sculptural power of a semiliterate black artist named William Edmondson are boldly displayed in an exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum.
The Norweglan Government is trying to bar foreign fleets from commercial fishing waters off the coast. The aim is to extend control in three stages to waters 200 miles from shore.

Responding to a demand by the American Jewish Congress that he "correct" his statements on the Middle East, Vice President-designate Nelson A Rockefeller said yesterday that he supported President Ford's policy regarding Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Two major bottling concerns have taken space in the Hunts Point Industrial Park, which is being developed by Abraham J. Rodolltz.
Mortimer Finkenberg, a furniture dealer here for many years, died yesterday in Highbridge House in the Bronx. He was 82 years old and lived at 910 West End Avenue.

Merribelle, Coles, daughter of Robert R. Coles, former chairman of the Hayden Planetarium, and of Mrs. Coles of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to John C. Stubenbord, a Buffalo medical student, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Glen Cove.

What was once a Billy Blake discount store on Nesconset Highway here will open tomorrow as 250 small shops.

Jane Cornelia Kuntz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richard Kuntz of Larchmont, N.Y., and Lost Tree Village, Fla., and John Karl Kellersman, son of Gilbert Conrad Kellersman of Naples, Fla., and the late Marjorie Kellersman, were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. George F. Bardes in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul In Larchmont, N.Y.

About the only useful thing that might be claimed for the term, "The American Scene Painters," is that it applies to a large, disparate group of artists who, around the 1930's and 1940's, turned to the American social scene and the American landscape as the source of their inspiration.

More than a century after Congress established land-grant colleges to "promete the literal and practical education of the industrial classes," the historical egalitarian purpose of these public schools is being eroded by steeply rising tuition and inflation.

The difference between the Amerioan and French economies, as the chief of the French Employers Association, Francois Ceyrac, sometimes says, is the difference between a vehicle of four and of two wheels. When the four-wheeled vehicle stops, it remains upright. The two-wheeler stops, and it falls over.

The coffee was perking cheerily in the corner, the curly-haired instructor was riffling through his notes and the blue-jeaned students seemed eager for class to begin. La panade. Few Americans are acquainted with this peasant dish and, in fact, this bread soup, which has been described as "the best, the cheapest and the most digestible of soups," has all but disappeared from contemporary French cookbooks. This is a shame. Not only is it a thrifty dish, using up every last slice of leftover bread, but it can be an excellent one.

A bomb thrown through the window of a bar frequented by officals from the Irish Embassy in central London tonight injured six or seven people, the police said. None of the injured was thought to be seriously hurt.

The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America suspended yesterday an internal dispute on whether to remain a constituent of the Syngogue Council of America along with the Reform and conservative branches of Judaism.

The Hong Kong Government today reversed its policy of permitting refugees from China to remain in Hong Kong. It announced that five persons had been turned over to the Chinese authorities, the first such action in seven years.

India and Pakistan moved to end their 10-year ban on trade relations-dating from the 1965 war over the Kashmir issue with the signing of a protocol stating that the ban would be lifted Dec. 7. Two elderly Chinese men were stabbed to death in apparent robberies Saturday night in tenement entrances four blocks apart on the Lower East Side.

The metropolitan area's Sikhs, a growing community of Indian and American adherents of the 16th-century Guru Nanak Dev Ji, celebrated the 505th anniversary of the founder's birth yesterday with hymns of praise and a feast of brotherhood.

WASHINGTON - When President Ford sported a wolfskin parka in Vladivostok and promised an admiring Leonid Brezhnev to send another wolfskin along as a gift, a New York Times editorial excoriated him for aiding and abetting the extinction of an endangered species.
A window was broken in the office of the Liberty Travel Service here today, apparently as a protest against the concern's dealings with trips to the Soviet Union.
MOVIES AND MAKERS Two programs of interesting films, both including discussional appearances by contributors. start here today.

Greek and Greek Cypriote leaders said that they had agreed to take a "common line" in negotiations with the Turks over the future of Cyprus; but a communique issued in Athens after two days of talks did not explain what that line would be.

Wyn Sargent, one of the better known brides of 1973, came to town the other day. One reason, she said, was to tell her side about her much publicized marriage to the chief of a cannibal tribe in West Irian, formerly Netherlands New Guinea.
Horses from Panama won all three international races held yesterday and today at El Commandante race track here.
Sucheta Kripalani, a leading fighter in the struggle for Indian independence, died here today of a heart attack, She was 67 years old.

.When the 12th Congress convened in 1811, the House of Representatives elected a freshman member, Henry Clay, as Speaker. Clay had resigned from the Senate to serve in the House, then regarded as the more important branch. Both developments would be regarded as inconceivable today.

The first major championship of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals was decided here in the early hours today. The mixed pair title went to Gerald Caravelli of Des Moines, Ill., a financial analyst for an insurance company, and Helen Utegaard of Bethesda, Md.
At 1:53 A.M. on a recent day, the telephone rang in the room whereJames Wichrowski works. The woman on the line was hysterical. "My children have been stabbed," she credit.

The following Is a supple mentary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

New Jerseyans' discontent with the way Gerald Ford has conducted the Presidency, particularly his handling of the economy, has risen sharply since September, according to the latest New Jersey Poll, conductedd by the Eagleton Institute.

Dr. L. Emmett Holt Jr., the internationally acclaimed pediatrician Who expanded the pediatrics department of the New York University School of Medicine into a major research center, died Saturday in Myrtle Beach, S C. He was 79 years old.

With 1,510 Civil Service and provisional city employes scheduled to be dismissed. in an economy move, Mayor Beame said that those with Civil Service status "will get top priority in reassignment to provisional positions that are available and to which they. are eligible."

The Supreme Court ruling last week affirming the unrestricted right of Mexican "green card" aliens to live and work in the United States has stirred new fears among Mexican-Americans already hard hit by rising unemployment.

There is an infinite number of ways to get mugged in New York, some of them more surprising than others. The other day, shortly before 9 A.M., Jack Orr left his apartment on the West Side and walked up to Broadway to buy a newspaper. When he returned to the apartment, he found two boys in the lobby.
The crash today of Trans World Airlines Flight 514 n a Blue Ridge. mountaintop jolted the government's classified Mount Weather installation only a mile and half away.
" The People's Choice Awards," a two-hour television special, will present the results of a national poll to select the public's favorite television shows, motion pictures, actors, entertainers,
CALCUTTA, India -- In a feeding kitchen in Calcutta, 80year-old Aizaz Bux stands barefoot with a tin pot and waits for a dole of overcooked gruel. "My only meal," he says in Bengali.

Kareem Abduhlabbar scored 29 of his 35 points in the second half tonight as the revived Milwaukee Bucks gained a 117-112 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball. Association game.

A recent study of the water supply of New Orleans reveals that it contains traces of several known cancercausing agents. This research, conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency, has prompted E.P.A. to begin an immediate, nationwide study of drinking Water.

Dr. Malcolm Tqdd, president of the American Medical Association, urged America's doctors today to uphold their professionalism but to fight Federal intervention in any proposed national health insurance programs.

A study of reports by 92 nursing homes in New York City discloses that operators paid themselves $3,225,000 last year in salaries for undefined services. About one-third did not claim to have done any work at all, while the rest said they served from three to 80 hours a week.
During the last six years crime has stabilized or decreased in many of the city's most dangerous neighborhoods. But at the same time the rate of reported serious felonies rose in all other precincts.

The Soviet armed forces newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda hinted today at military dissatisfaction over one aspect of the tentative strategic arms accord reached a week ago at Vladivostok by President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader. In a commentary; the paper attacked foreign military bases as "a source of war danger."
President and Mrs. Ford went to church today and heard a sermon questioning United States policies on spending for military defense and food for the world's hungry people.

St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Maxine Hope Cromwell, daughter of James H. R. Cromwell of New York and the late Maxine MacFetridge Cromwell, to Dale Edgar Hopkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Hopkins of Long Meadow, Mass.

In a statement read today in churches throughout Warsaw, the Roman Catholic primate of Poland, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, criticized the Government for having demolished a church in what he called an act "unprecedented since the war."

Laszlo Pakozdi of Hungary, a heavyweight, decisioned Marvin Stinson of Philadelphia to give the Hungarian Olympic team a 5-5 tie with the United States National Amateur Athletic Union team last night. The crowd of 3,800 booed the decision in the final match. Stinson went down for the 8 count in the second round.

CARACAS, Venezuela-Venezuelan Government officials are expressing hopes that a working formula reached with two United States companies in an iron ore expropriation will provide a model for taking over the far more important oil industry, which produces the bulk of Venezuela's foreign exchange and government revenues.

The first scattered voting today by striking coal miners, balloting early on a tentative agreement with the mine owners that is strongly backed by Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers, gave only the narrowest margin of approval to the proposed settlement.

For 29 days the prosecution at the Watergate cover-up trial presented witnesses, documents and tape recordings in an effort to prove that the five defendants had conspired to obstruct justice through such means as payments of "hush money" to the seven Watergate burglars.
A 25-year-old rabbi was shot and slightly wounded by one of two young men who attempted to rob him near his home in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn last night, the police reported.

Like two bloodhounds sniffing across the solar system, Pioneer 10 and Pioneer 11 have traced to Jupiter bursts of highenergy radiation whose occurrence near the earth has long puzzled space scientists.

A huge storm shrouded the eastern half of the nation in a patchwork of snow, sleet and rain yesterday, an intimation of winter that brought the long Thanksgiving weekend to a close with hazardous driving and other headaches for homebound travelers.
TORONTO - This rapidly growing city has put the brakes on development while its people try to decide what they want their streets to look like.
Joseph M. McCrane, the for mer New Jersey State Treasurer, faces a new setting but some old charges today when he goes on trial for the third time--this time in Scranton, Pa.

In what has become painful repetition, this time before a nearrecord number of no-shows, the New York Giants dropped a 16-13 decision to the Chicago Bears today on a 24yard field goal by Mirro Roder with 36 seconds left.

Adelphi won Decision II and Brockport State near Buffalo took Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournaments last Saturday, and now Hartwick College of Onsonta can make it a sweep for the State of New York by winning Division I.

A Trans World Airlines 727, battling a driving rainstorm, slammed into a wooded slope near a secret government installation today, killing all 92 persons aboard. It was theworst air disaster of the year in the United States.

The difference between playing a piece of music and performing it is vast, and probably cannot be taught. One of the performers, and already a major one at age 19, is the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, who gave an extraordinary recital yesterday at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., stoutly supported at the piano by Peter Schaaf.
A powerful retriever, with a coat of rich gold, struck paydirt today at the Boardwalk Kennel Club show. The retriever, Ch. Cumming's GoldRush Charlie, was named best of 3,809 dogs at Convention Hall.

Prime Minister Ian D. Smith gave a clear indication in an interview today that he is engaged in fresh talks to achieve settlement with the black majority in Rhodesia as well as an improvement of relations With his southern African neighbors.
The treasurer of the Opposition Christian Democrat Party escaped unharmed in the sauna of his home at Kronberg near here when a gunman fired three shots at close range through the door last night.

The crash of the Trans World Airlines jetliner in Virginia yesterday was the second major disaster this year among domestic commercial airlines in the United States, the Associated Press reported.

The cost of electricity from Consolidated Edison went up yesterday by $3 a month for the average customer. The 9.7 per cent increase, the latest major increase granted the utility this year, was approved by a 3-2 vote of the state Public Service Commission on Nov. 12. It is expected to raise Con Ed's revenues by $164-million a year.

WASHINGTON - The Watergate cover-up trial has dramatized the fact that, when President Nixon published his tape transcripts last April, crucial passages were left out. But it is not yet generally realized that the new tapes played at the trial could lead to further prosecutions-of those involved in cutting incriminating material from the transcripts.

There is a growing controversy in journalism over the nature of investigative reporting, a controversy that has left much of the American press self-conscious and sometimes defensive about the subject.

A security guard is posted on the sidewalk and a sturdy fence surrounds the yard, but otherwise the two-story beige bungalow looks like any other in this comfortable suburb a few minutes north of Tel Aviv.

NASHVILLE-The World Food Conference in Rome, like many other United Nations gatherings, turned into a hate-America session. Delegates from Communist and ,so-called nonaligned nations charged that "imperialists" were responsible for the food shortages in the Southern Hemisphere.

Ground was broken today for a $10-million International Space Hall of Fame complex in what Gov. Bruce King described as "the birthplace of the first atomic space age" as he turned over the first spadeful of earth.
Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today. that he intended to remain in his job next year despite recent demands for his resignation.
Cutbacks in Federal welfare funds are planned for states with the poorest record of placing welfare recipients in steady jobs, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

There is a growing confroversary in journalism over the nature of investigative reporting, a controversy that has left much of the American press self-conscious and sometimes defensive about the subject.
It might be a little late for this season, but the Jet juggernaut continued trampling the opposition yesterday, defeating the San Diego Chargers, 27-14, for its fourth straight victory.

Eleven teen-aged members of a Bronx gang were arrested yesterday and charged with robbing at least 60 subway change booths of approximately $60,000 in tokens and cash over the last two months, averaging about $1,000 a day since Oct. 1.

A 13-year-old girl who had been missing for two days after she fell while horseback riding was found yesterday afternoon,. tired and wet but in high spirits. The police said the girl, Diana Lynn Hicks, was found at 4 P.M. by employes of a stable in Wall Township.

Frederick T. Merrill, who was the State Department's Director of East-West Contacts from 1956 to 1960 and deputy chief of mission in Rumania from 1960 to 1962, died yesterday of a heart attack in Arlington, Va.
grim outlook for both unemployment and "wage inflation" emerged today from new economic studies published by the Brookings Institution.

Two gunmen, cornered in a supermarket during a holdup attempt today, seized seven store employes as hostages. One gunman was captured quickly but the other bargained for nearly seven hours with the police before he released the last hostage and surrendered.

President Ford made public tonight the details of a tentative agreement on arms control that he and Leonid I. Brezhnev had reached in Vladivostok. He said the accord put a "firm ceilling" on the arms race and created a "solid basis" for future arms reductions. [Opening statement, page 28.]
A 63-year-old woman was hospitalized with a fractured skull yesterday after she apparently put up a struggle when she was mugged a block from her home in Flushing, Queens.
Judge John J. Sirica strongly suggested today that he intended to let the Watergate cover-up case go to the jury without waiting to get testimony from former President Richard M. Nixon.

"Depression, addiction, venereal disease, chronic disability, psychiatric treatment, loneliness, insomnia, institutionalization, poverty, 'discrimination,' unemployment and nightmares"-these, says George Gilder, are "the dirty sheets and unmade mornings" of the majority of swinging single males. Getting what they want seems to bring them more problems than pleasures.
A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with strangling his former wife whose body was found Sunday night in a vacant lot in Rockaway, Queens.
Lebanese artillery opened fire on an Israeli vessel that tried to approach the coast near Tyre in south Lebanon today, the Defense Ministry said.

When Adnan M. Khashoggi was a student at Chico State College in northern California 20 years ago, his father sent him $10,000 to buy a new car like the ones driven by other Arab students. Instead, young Mr. Khashoggi put the money in the bank.

UNESCO, worried by unfavorable reaction to measures taken against Israel in a recent meeting of the organization said today it hoped that Israeli scientists, educators and scholars would continue contributing to its work.

The City Planning Commission is nearing completion of a proposal for the development of the South Richmond area of Staten Island, desqgned to preserve the rustic charter of the existing small towns and surrounding landscape in what has come to be called "the city's last frontier."

" The Red Badge of Courage," Stephen Crane's short hovel about an 1863 battle in Civil War, has been fitted out for a television adaptation that, although it runs less than 90 minutes, seems interminable.

We don't hear much of the music of Andrzey Panulink in this country. He was born in Poland in 1914, established a reputation as a conductor and avant-garde composer, and then moved to Britain in 1954. He remained there.

A small New Jersey stockholder, relying largely on a general warning issued by a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, filed suit here yesterday to block an offer by Cornwall Equities, Ltd. to buy back its own stock at $4 a share.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today filed a $49.6-million interim rate-increase request with the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners that, if approved, would go into effect on Jan. 1.

The Democrats in the House of Representatives voted today to divest the Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee and the panel's chairman, Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, of the authority to make committee assignments for 'other Democrats.

Dave DeBusschere, Willis Reed, Jerry Lucas and Dean Meminger are gone, but the Knicks have a better record now than at this time a year ago.

Corporate bond prices broke drastically yesterday as a glut of merchandise and the suddenleveling off in short-term interest rates produced the biggest sell off since the huge rally began in mid-September.

Lindsay F. Johnson, who retired in 1970 as president of the New Jersey Zinc Company and a director of Gulf Western Industries, Inc., which acquired it in 1965, died Saturday in Southern Pines, N.C. He was 67 years old.
Poland has told Western countries that it will meet only half of its sugar export contracts for 1974, diplomats said here today.

President Ford said tonight that the nation now faced the triple challenges of inflation, recession and an energy crisis, but warned that "our greatest danger today is to fall victim to the more exaggerated alarms that are being generated about the underlying health and strength of our economy."

WASHINGTON--It isn't easy to get rid of a used war. One small but volatile symbol of this truth exists on a missile-ringed island in the mid-Pacific, another at a military base in Mississippi, where drums containing 2.3 million gallons of Orange herbicide are stored, rusting and occasionally leaking.
The State Supreme Court indicated today that a dispute over outof-state dumping of garbage in New Jersey might eventually have to be resolved by the Federal courts.

Defense Secretary Schlesinger's effort to get sixteen combat divisions instead of thirteen out of the Army's 785,000 men-200,000 fewer men than the sixteen-division Army of pre-Vietnam 1964--is an ambitious, longoverdue and much-needed reform.

The House Judiciary Committee has developed evidence contradicting Nelson A. Rockefeller's assertions that he was not privately told of the White House wiretapping and the secret operations in Chile before their newspaper disclosure, well-informed sources said today.
Mrs. Urho Kekkonen, wife of Finland's President. died of a heart attack today at the Helsinki University Hospital. She was 74 years old.
When Chick Corea performed at the Newport Jazz Festival last summer, his guitarist, Albert DiMeola, had only been with the quartet a few days, and understandably played a rather retiring role.

Britain's Labor party has managed to embarrass its own Government and widen an already bitter division in its ranks over the issue of membership in the European Common Market. In a vote dominated, as always, by the bloc votes of the big trade unions, the party's annual conference has demanded a virtually complete restructuring of the European Community as the price of continued British participation.

LITTLE CREEK, Del. -If you want to learn about a man, share a goose pit with him. A' goose pit, for the uninitiate, is a hole in the ground, usually with a cover that can quickly be moved out of the way, in which hunters lurk waiting for geese to come to the decoys that are set on the ground around their hideaway.
The Swiss National Bank took a further move to day aimed at steming the flow of foreign funds into switzerland.
A balanced transportation system is a crucial priority for a mobile society, Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, told officials of the nation's cities today.
The Federal. Energy Administration issued regulations today to equalize the cost of crude oil among refiners and the cost of fuel oils among distributors.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that Offshore Power Systems, its joint venture with Tenneco, Inc., would reduce operations at Jacksonville, Fla., and cut the: work force to 250 from 700 by yearend.

High winds in the wake of heavy rain walloped the soggy metropolitan area yesterday during the morning rush hour, flooding highways, uprooting trees, disrupting rail lines and fraying the nerves of commuters returning to work for the first time in five days.

Edward Bennett Williams, the lawyer and owner of the Washington Redskins professional football team, testified today that he twice urged Gerardo V. Catena, the reputed Mafia leader, to answer questions about organized crime.
The exodus of Nixon Administration holdovers from the Ford White House staff continued yesterday with the resignation of Dean Burch, counselor to the President on political affairs.

The Federal Government again opened its campaign-fraud case against t Joseph M. McCrane, the former New Jersey State Treasurer, as a jury of seven women and five men was selected today from several Lackawanna Valley communities, an area considered remote enough from New Jersey politics to insure a fair trial.

Dave DeBusschere, Willis Reed, Jerry Lucas and Dean Meminger are gone, but the Knicks have a better record now than at this time a year age. They have surprised the fans who have stayed away and those preseason prognosticators who said the team's chances. for a National Basketball Association playoff berth were slim.

Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today there was growing evidence that marijuana is "no harmless lollipop," and that legalizing its use would pose a health problem as well as a law enforcement problem.
Iraq has agreed to lend the French Treasury $1-billion to help France pay for Iraqi oil and offset her growing foreign trade deficit, official sources said tonight.
RIO DE JANEIRO-Divorce Brazilian style -- or legal separation-is spreading and the reason generally given is the new economic independence of women.

The FarEast, until recently an uncultivated area of the game, is currently making great progress. Last summer at the Nice Olympiad, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia and the Philippines entered teams and the Philippines sextet qualified for the championship finals, finishing 12th out of 16.
Anita Brenner, a journalist and author of several books on Mexico, was killed yesterday in an auto accident about 300 miles north of here. She was 69 years old. She is survived by a son and daughter.
Fred Brown scored 5 of his 23 points in the last three minutes tonight to help the Seattle Supersonics outlast the Kansas City-Omaha Kings in a 110-106 National Basketball Association triumph.
Stronger energy conservation measures--including gasoline rationing-may be announced by President Ford early next month according to a senior United States energy official.

Ralph E. Fliedner, who founded the Fliedner funeral establishment in Great Neck, L.., in 1933, died yesterday at his home, 190 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck. He was 68 year old.
Directors of Burlington Northern, Inc., authorized yesterday a $243-million capital expenditure program for 1975. Louis W. Menk, chairman, said $235-milion of the total would be for rail operations,

Pioneer II transmitted the first pictures. of Jupiter's south polar region tonight and then, after a perilous journey through what is believed to be the most intense part of that planet's radiation belt, soared into a trajectory that will carry it across the solar system in five years to Saturn.
James T. Lynn, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, reduced today interest rates from 8.5 per cent to 8,25 per cent in the Federal plan for conventional home mortgages.
Under an Army Corps of. Engineers proposal, 1,550 residents of Baytown, Tex., would be relocated from a flood plain in the Houston suburb.
At the Tombs, through whose gates at least a halfmillion accused men have passed since 1941, inmates and guards are already taling of the venerable prison in the past tense.

For the seventh consecutive trading session, world sugar futures dropped the daily limit of 2 cents a pound yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The 14-cent, decline took the price of the key March delivery to 51.20 cents a pound yesterday.
The city will pay the highest interest rates ever--an average of 9.479 per cent--to borrow $600-million in short-term municipal notes in a market apparently glutted with New York City notes.

More than 2,000 Democrats Congressional figures, party officers and a great majority of untitled local party activistswill gather in Kansas City, Mo., this week in their first national convention without a Presidential nomination at stake.

All 160 soldiers and policemen on this Eastern Caribbean island went on full alert this week to enforce an order to disband made to a black guerrilla group blamed for the murder of several whites. The 300-member group.

Lajos Zilahy, a novelist and playwright, died Sunday night near Novi Sad, Yugoslavia, where he had been working on the filming of one of his stories. He was 83 years old and lived in Woonsocket, R. I.

Larry Robinson, scored both goals and Bunny Larocque earned his first shutout of the season tonight as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Atlanta Flames, 2-0. The victory moved the Canadiens into a first-place tie with the Los Angeles Kings in the National Hockey League's Norris Division.
The nation's Republican governors agreed today that they had fallen on hard times, but they could not agree on what to do about it.

Bombs exploded in Addis Ababa today, damaging the City Hall and a downtown hotel and reportedly injuring 13 persons. Later, gunfire and at least two hand-grenade blasts were heard on a road in the eastern part of the city.

City Council President Paul O'Dwyer accused contractors on the troubled Third Water Tunnel project yesterday of unfairly tarnishing the city's repustation for dealing with private companies in public-works contracts.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy said tonight that he would propose creation of a $50-million United States loan fund to he divided equally between. Portugal and her African territories that are gaining independence.
Hamilton College announced today that W. Lawrence Gulick, chairman of the Dartmouth College Psychology Department, had been named dean of the New York school.

A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a $2.5-million personal injury suit filed by the Oakland Raiders defensive end, Bubba Smith, against the Tampa Sports Authority and the National Football League.
Investigators began today to unravel the cause of the nearvertical plunge last night of a Northwest Airlines 727 charter jet into a wooded area of Harriman State Park.

The police searched the Vineland area for one of two youths who escaped from the State Correctional Institution at Annandale last Friday. A police spokesman identified the youth as Larry Peterson, 16 years old, of Vineland. The second youth, Raymond Jones, 17, of Englewood, was captured Saturday in New York City, after the pair had allegedly robbed a restaurant in Clinton and abducted one of its owners.

The Soviet Union launched today an improved Soyuz spacecraft with two veteran astronauts aboard into orbit around the earth in a major systems test for the Soviet-American space rendezvous scheduled for next July.

The first price reduction in sugar in 20 months was announced yesterday by three of the nation's largest refiners. The price action shaved the price of sugar, which has been the most volatile food product this year, by about 5 cents a pound.

The Securities. and Exchange Commission invited today public comment on whether it should ease.its registration requirements to permit more foreign investment companies, notably mutual funds to operate in the United States.

Elizabeth Bagaaya, the former Uganda Foreign Minister, has been questioned by the police in Uganda where she is under house arrest but no charges have been brought against her according to reports reaching London from Kampala.

Alan Greenspan, chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, said tonight that if stimulus for the economy became necessary to head off rising unemployment, the stimulus should take the form of tax cuts rather than larger Government spending.

" I am Suleiman the Munificent," said Suleiman the Munificent to Santa Claus. "Ho, ho, ho," the old gentleman laughed. "You must be from the oilrich Middle East. Climb right up here in my lap and tell me what I can do for you."
A confessed gambler testified Westchester County Court today that he had paid bribes amounting to "$800 or $900" a month to Mount Vernon police officers, including a captain.

The winter's first heavy snowstorm in the Appalachian coal fields forced the United Mine Workers of America today to add two extra days for membership balloting and to extend through Wednesday today's scheduled rank-and-file voting on the coal industry's proposed contract.
Judge John J. Sirica strongly suggested today that he intended to let the Watergate cover-up case go to the jury without waiting to get testimoney from former President Richard M. Nixon.

Peru's Premier and two other men prominent in the military Government escaped assassintion last night, the Interior Ministry announced today.
The Government said Monday that Lucio Cabanas, Mexico's best known guerrilla leader, was killed in a mountain gun battle with Mexican soldiers.

High winds in the wake of heavy rain walloped the soggy metropolitan area yesterday during the morning rush hour, flooding highways, uprooting trees, disrupting rail lines and fraying the nerves of commu-' ters returning to work for the first time in five days.

To the Editor: Two energy time bombs are planted along the road the United States must travel in the next two or three years. The first threat is the prospect that there will be a fifth round of the Middle East war-and a second embargo--probably sometime in 1975.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had received an order for 195 diesel electric locomotives costing more than $100-million from the Federal Railway System of Brazil. The order is the largest overseas award for rail power ever received by G.E., according to Hoyt P. Steel, vice president and general manager of' G.E.'s International sales division.

Vanderbilt, the defending Southeastern Conference champion, defeated coldshooting St. John's, 73-53, tonight. Butch Feher, Jeff Fosnes and Joe' Ford led the Vandy attack with 20, 20 and 18 points, respectively.

The Jimmy Connors-John Newcombe controversy heated up yesterday, with the Australian accusing the American of ducking him by pulling out of the Commercial Union Grand Prix Masters tournament starting next Tuesday in Melbourne. Newcombe mocked Connor's excuse that he had a tooth problem.

The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Nov. 23 was 16.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago which included the Thanksgiving Day holiday.

Several New York partnerships were strongly placed in the major events at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight. In the Life Master Men's Pairs, a new combination of Alvin Roth and Peter
Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

One of the key problems facing both management and labor in their continuing relationships in the performing arts, particularly at the nonprofit institutions, is the question of dwindling financial support, Alan Olson, assistant to the executive secretary of the American Guild of Musical Artists, said yesterday.
Bernard King, University of Tennessee--42 points. Thomas King, West Virginia Wesleyan College--23 points. Albert King, Fort Hamilton High School, Brooklyn--36 points.

Plunging toward Jupiter for its perilous loop around that planet tonight, Pioneer 11 has cast its electronic eye on Callisto, second largest of the Jovian moons, and revealed what seems to be a small polar cap like that on Mars.
