Senate Democratic leaders announced tonight growing support for a $700-million state tax program to fill an impending budget deficit and to comply with the State Supreme Court order to refinance New Jersey's system of funding public schools.
William M. Miller, best known for his nickname "Fish Bait" and his cry of "Mistah Speakaaaah," heard in the House of Representatives for 24 years, lost his job as doorkeeper today.

The city has rejected recommendation by Arvid Anderson, chairman of the Office of Collective Bargaining, that an impasse panel be created to make a binding decision in the city's pay parity dispute with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
The Senate passed a bill today designed to settle a century old land dispute by dividing 1.8 million acres in Arizona equally between the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes.
The United States Army is disciplining 22 soldiers who went on strike at their unit here last week in a dispute over haircut regulations.

A French and Spanish bookstore' and distribution center, with more than one million volumes including a large percentage of bilingual books, opened yesterday at 115 Fifth Avenue at 19th Street. The Consul General of Spain, Alberto LopezHerce, presided over the official inaugural reception.

New York's disorderly but democratic planning processes, marked equally by vision and paranoia, sometimes produce surprisingly good results. The latest issue that has struggled to a notably improved solution is the controversial rebuilding of the West Side Highway.

The Pan American Phoenix, known for years as an impeccable source for the finest in Mexican handcrafts, has moved from Lexington Avenue to elegant new quarters at 927 Madison Avenue between 73d and 74th Streets.

TRENTON, Dec. 2-Senate Democratic leaders announced tonight growing support for a $700-million state tax program to fill an impending budget deficit and to comply with the State Supreme Court order to refinance New Jersey's system of funding public schools.

The first price reduction in sugar in- 20 months was announced yesterday by three of the nation's largest refiners. The price action shaved the price of sugar, which has been the most volatile food product this year, by about 5 cents a pound.
A senior member of Japan's Parliament, Takeo Miki, was selected today to become Premier. He will succeed the incumbent, Kakuei Tanaka, in about 10 days.

The Court of Appeals has reversed a $31-million condem nation award to a private housing developer for 370 acres taken over by the city 11 years ago for Breezy Point Park, on the western end of the Rockaway Peninsula.

In a significant retreat from earlier optimism, Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said today he was not sure a seven-point Government program could save Pan American World Airways from financial Failure.
A 31-year-old man arrested for allegedly creating a disturbance in a Harlem subway station Sunday night was found hanged early yesterday in a cell in a police station at 120 East 119th Street.

The Democrats in the House of Representatives voted today to divest the Democrats on the, Ways and Means Committee and the panel's chairman, Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, of the authority to make committee assignments for other Democrats.
Concern that short-term interest rates may have leveled off and over the outcome of the miners' vote to end the coal strike depressed the stock market yesterday in sluggish trading.
The United Auto Workers union has filed a $10-million lawsuit against the United States Labor party alleging that the group illegally uses the name of the U.A.W. newspaper for a paper of its own.

Paul Hellman, honorary chairman of B. Blumenthal Co., Inc., button manufacturer, of which he was president from 1938 to 1968, died Sunday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was 81 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills who had been widely regarded as the most powerful single member of Congress, today was the object of derision and scorn among his colleagues because of his relations with a striptease dancer.
Post Office officials sifted through more than three tons of undelivered, charred, waterlogged mail today after firemen found it in the burning home of a young substitute mailman.

About 2,000 striking faculty members at eight state colleges returned to their classrooms today as an impartial mediator, appointed last Thursday to help settle the labor dispute, set up a meeting for resumption of negotiations between the teachers and the state's Office of Employee Relations.
The Soviet Union has agreed to supply Egypt with a nuclear reactor, a Soviet publication said today. It is viewed as a step toward restoring close relations at the expense of the United States.

When the House of Hermes, the French leather and perfume company, decided that the time had come to advertise Caleche its women's fragrance, and Equipage, its men's fragrance, on American television it wanted to mike a splash.
A senior member of Japan's Parliament, Takeo Miki, was selected to-day to become Premier. He will succeed the incunbent, Kakuei Tanka, in about 10 days.
The Spanish Government tonight announced limited freedom for Spaniards to form political associations for the first time since the end of the Civil War 35 years ago.
The director of President Ford's office of Management and Budget, Roy L. Ash, has a little list. On it are the names of all the Senators and Representatives who made
Takeo Miki, long LiberalDemocratic leader and. high Government official has frequently been a candidate for the. Premiership but was never really taken seriously.

The New Jersey Racing Commission approved winter and spring thoroughbred meets at Garden State Park today, continuing the track's competition with Pennsylvania's new Keystone Park in suburban Philadelphia.

The Great Western Corporation said today that it had appealed United States District Court Judge William Taylor Jr.'s denial of a preliminary injunction against the tender offer made by the sons of the late Texas billionaire H. L. Hunt.
Vivian Dixon Wanamaker, who had been prominent socially here and in Palm Beach, died Sunday in Westmins er Hospital, London, after a brief illness. She was 57 years old and lived in Rome.

A defense-policy specialist of the Brookings Institution has recommended that the United States reduce the number of tactical nuclear warheads it deploys in Western Europe from the present total of 7,000 to 2,000.

Roy L. Ash, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today it was likely that the jobless rate for November would act as a trigger for the Administration's $2,7-billion public service employment program.

Specialists in the world of finance, in and out of Wall Street, were jolted last week when the House Rules Committee abruptly blocked final action on far-reaching legislation to restructure the nation's stock exchanges along less monopolistic and anachronistic lines.
Dorothy L. Irvine, executive director since 1968 of the American-Korean Foundation, died yesterday in Hastings-onHudson, N.Y. She was 61 years old and lived at 305 Lexington Avenue.

Family Court Judge Martin Ginsberg waived a jury trial today as his trial opened in County Court here. The 43year-old judge is charged with grand larceny by extortion, perjury and receiving a bribe, all allegedly committed while he was an Assemblyman in 1970 and 1971.

President Ford said tonight that the nation now faced the triple challenges of inflation, recession and an energy crisis, but warned that "our greatest danger today is to fall victim to the more exaggerated alarms that are being generated about the underlying health and strength of our economy."

Phil Iselin, the Jets president, said yesterday that the club would not be lulled into a false sense of security by their four-game winning streak, which not inconceivably could reach a seasonclosing six.
Some $15-billion will have to be spent to lift production of oil from the North Sea to 3 million barrels a day by 1980, Cazenove Co., the Britishbased investment banking house, said here yesterday.

The, United States Bureau of Mines said today it would, take an initial capital investment of more than $522million' to build an oil-shale mining and retorting plant capable of producing 100,000 barrels 'of oil a day in Colorado.
The Chief of Staff of the French Army has warned the Minister of Defense that if he does not improve morale and living conditions among the military, a revolt may be provoked.
A bill to put 70 miles of the New River in the Wild and Scenio Rivers Systems was jeopardize today when Representatives James A. Haley and Roy A,
Committees of the American Medical Association's House of Delegates met today to thresh ouUt recommendations on 65 resolutions, including a controversial definition of death.
In almost. every National Football League game last Sunday, including the GiantsBears at Chicago, the team that won the coin toss elected to receive the opening kickoff, in traditional fashion.

Lieutenant Governor-elect Mary Anne Krupsak said today that the Legislature had to reform itself through "institutional change" that would free Assemblymen and Senators from "dominantion" by a few legislative leaders.
President Ford announced today the transfer of an additional 21 parcels of land in 16 states and Puerto Rico for recreational use under the Legaey of Parks Program.
Frankie and Wilfredo Benitez, the teen-age boxing brothers from Carolina, P.R., won unanimous decisions in their co-featured eight-round bouts last night at the Felt Forum.
Congressional investigators charged today that big oil companies, despite their "obscene profits," pay a lower percentage in Federal income taxes than the average private citizen.

Aides to Controller Harrison J. Goldin who helped him draw up his estimate of a $650-million gap in the city's expense budget defended their procedures yesterday and said that if they had erred at all, it was on the side of conservatism.

The national debate on the roles of race, ethnic heritage and sex in employment, academic admissions and job promotion is continuing without a letup. Whether or not we blacks have benefited from improper preferential treatment, many whites are convinced that we now have it made because of our color.

The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation realized a 102 per cent increase in net income for its fourth fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30, and a 206 per cent climb for the full year, the Texas-based integrated oil company reported yesterday.

Thomas A. Murphy, the new chairman of the General Motors Coporation, said yesterday that G.M. would support higher Federal gasoline taxes if the Ford Administration should decide they were necessary to reduce petroleum imports.

At his televised news conference, President Ford made public the details of a tentative agreement that he and Leonid I. Brezhnev had reached in Vladivostok. He said the accord put a "firm ceiling" on the arms race and created a "solid basis" for future arms reductions. "It's a good agreement and I think the American people will buy it," Mr. Ford said. [Page 1, Cols. 2-3.]

Alvin Dark, the manager of the Oakland A's, told a church congregation last weekend in Charlotte, N. C., about his relationship with Charles O. Finley, his boss, and called the controversial owner his "best friend."

As the first major American performing artists to appear onstage in Havana since the United States and Cuba broke off relations in 1961, Cynthia Gregory and Ted Kivitt of American Ballet Theater, found themselves continuously followed -- by Cuban ballet fans.
A Nassau County grand jury refused today to indict members of the County Police Department who searched the home of a Roosevelt pharmacist without a search warrant.

The last obstacle to the convening of a Common Market meeting in Paris next week fell today as the nine member countries agreed on the principles of a common fund to help economically backward regions in Europe.

All across the country these days public officials are wrestling with excruciatingly difficult dilemmas caused by rising costs and shrinking revenues-except in New Jersey. It's not that New Jersey doesn't have problems. It does, in spades. It's just that the Legislature in Trenton so far hasn't had the courage to grapple with them.

The latest Soviet-American nuclear arms deal was worked out only after the Russians agreed to exempt American nuclear bombers stationed in and around Europe and to limit the total level of missiles, bombers and multiple warheads permitted on each side, according to authoritative Administration officials.

Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday a 1-cent-a-gallon increase nationwide in its price for all grades of tractor and diesel fuel, No. 1 and No. 2 heating oils and kerosene to a!! classes of trade, effective last Friday.
The United States warned today that, until suitable alternatives were devised, the arrangements that have preserved peace on the Korean peninsula for more than 20 years should not be abandoned.
Saul Slomiak, chief counsel since 1972 of the United States Customs Service, died yesterday of cancer in Holy Cross Hospital, Silver Spring, Md. He was 45 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

One of the F.B.I.'s first women agents, Sheila J. Regan, who was assigned as a bodyguard for Attorney General William B. Saxbe's wife, died along with another agent Sunday in the crash of a Trans World Airlines plane near Dulles International Airport.
Dinner-jacketed boxing fans hurled champagne gasses, empty bottles and ice cubes-into the ring at the Hilton Hotel tonight in protest against a referee's decision.

Louis L. Levine, State Industrial Commissioner, said yesterday that he had asked a Federal court for permission to continue financing until May 1 the controversial New York Plan, which expired over the weekend, to "protect" the 800 trainees currently enrolled.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, who had been widely regarded as the most powerful single member of Congress, today was the object of derision and scorn among his colleagues because of his relations with a striptease dancer.

Steel production for the week ended Nov. 30 fell to its lowest level since the end of the third quarter of 1972, but the decline was far less than might hale been expected 'in light of the continuing coal strike.

Two recording devices that investigators hope will disclose the cause of the Trans World Airlines crash in which 92 persons died Sunday were recovered yesterday from the wreckage on a mountain slope 23 miles west of Washington's Dulles International Airport.

The Arkansas Gazette, the largest newspaper in the state, called on Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, in an editorial today to either forgo "his public indiscretions" with Annabel Battistella, a stripper, or resign.

San Francisco has it Golden Gate Bridge, its Coit Tower and its famous Bay. It also has the Sutb. The Stub is the mile-long, unfinished Embarcadero Freeway, begun about two decades ago, stopped almost midway by a citizens' revolt in 1959, and left jutting into the sky unfinished.
Dec. 2-Diplomats from all regions of the world joined today in eulogizing U Thant, former United Nations Secretary General, who died last Tuesday at the age of 65.
Premier Aldo Moro tonight outlined a broad economic program for his new Government aimed at fighting inflation and bolstering the nation's sagging economy.
The impressioinst exhibition just ended at the Grand Palais--it is soon to open in NewYork at the Metropolitan Museum of Art--was visited

The Eliot Feld Ballet is back for a five-week New York season, care of Joseph Papp and his Public Theater on Lafayette Street. On Sunday night the Feld opened shop at the Newman Theater, with a program that, while not, containing anything new, seemed carefully calculated to show the company off at its best.

One of the 11 teen-age gang members accused of staging a two-month robbery spree of city subway token booths had been free on bail awaiting trial on charges of robbing a booth that he was accused on Sunday of holding up again.

Bishop Stephen Gill Spottswood, board chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a retired spiritual leader of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, died Sunday night of cancer at his home in Washington. He was 77 years old.

At his televised news conference, President Ford made public the details of a tentative agreement that he and Leonid I. Brezhnev had reached in Vladivostok. He said the accord put a "firm ceiling" on the arms race and created a "solid basis" for future arms reductions. "It's a good agreement and I think the American people will buy it," Mr. Ford said. Representatives of the State Education Department and of the private vocational school industry joined yesterday in attacking the Federal Trade Commission's proposal to regulate the industry.

Bishop Stephen Gill Spottswood, board chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colbred People and a retired spiritual leader of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, died Sunday night of cancer at his home in Washington. He was 77 years old.
The tiny oilproducing Arab sheikdom of Kuwait was the mystery buyer that acquired about 14 per cent of Daimler-Benz, maker of Mercedes automobiles, last week, the Dresdner Bank disclosed today.

The New Jersey State Commission of Investigation announced today that it would begin public hearings Wednesday into allegations of official corruption and illegal land deals in the Borough of Lindenwold in CamdenCounty.

BOGOTA, Colombia--With sugar priced at 9 cents a pound, gasoline selling at 11 cents a gallon and minimum wages just raised 25 per cent, this country should by all current economic yardsticks be in an enviable position.

The United League of Composers and the International Society for Contemporary Music, United States section, opened this season's series of five concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night with a rather less hard-line program than one might have anticipated.
A 20-year-old suspect in a car theft was fatally shot by a plainclothes police officer last night after he allegedly pulled a toy gun when he was confronted by the officer in a stolen car.
The disclosure that the United States Government plans to sell 2 million ounces of gold in January, prompted a sharp decline in the metal today on the European bullion markets.

A spokesman for former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller confirmed yesterday that the state police had used electronic devices to protect Mr. Rockefeller from being "bugged" at the 1968 Republican National Convention in Miami Beach.

It was early in the Jets' game against Miami two weeks ago, and Bob Griese, the Dolphin quarterback, backpedaled as if to set up for a pass. But Joe Schmiesing, the Jets' right tackle, read the play correctly, and when Griese handed off to Larry Csonka, Schmiesing was ready to pounce.
The House passed by voice vote today a measure that would nullify an agreement former President Richard M. Nixon made with a government agency giving him possession of his tapes.
Dr. Harold L. Ross of Hawthorne, an expert on marine biology who helped make the undersea movie "20,000 Leagues Under The Sea" in 1915, died today in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 91 years old.
Against a background of turbulence in the money and capital markets yesterday, the Federal Reserve apparently began the delicate process of easing credit another notch.
The buildup of manufacturers' inventories slowed in October from the rapid pace of the preceding six months, the Commerce Department reported today.

For a dozen years or more Roswell Rudd has been an anomaly among the jazz avantgardists with whom he has usually played his trombone, Although he could contribute lustily to the tumult customarily stirred up by his avantgarde associates,
A 55-year-old Harlem woman and her 19-year-old niece were stabbed to death in the hallway outside their apartment after the younger woman opened their door to an early-morning caller yesterday.

As is commonly known, at the age of 21 Nathan Hale was hanged as a spy by the British. With his supposed death words, "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country," this potential footnote became a famous martyr.

Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon announced today that the Treasury would sell at auction two million ounces of its gold-worth about $360-million at current world market prices-on Jan. 6, a few days after Americans are legally permitted to own gold bullion beginning Dec. 31.
A lawsuit that "could test or topple" the legal structure of baseball was being considered today by the attorneys for George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the New York Yankees.

More than 300 club members, celebrities and other friends of The Lambs turned out for a fund-raising gala last night to help celebrate the theatrical club's 100th birthday and to prevent it from sinking under a $350,000 mortgage.

The White House, reacting to accusations that President Ford was not adequately dealing with economic problems, intensffied its attack on Congress today for not having acted on Mr. Ford's economic proposals.
Dick Martin pumped in four goals tonight, pacing the Buffalo Sabres to a 5-3 victory over the Washington Capitals in the National. Hockey League.
The restless young lions of Japan's governing Liberal-Democratic party have mounted their first open challenge to the party elders and have emerged with enhanced influence.

Efforts to forge a tax proposal to resolve New Jersey's fiscal crisis foundered again today when none of the proposed revenue components could gain conclusive support among the Democratic majority in the State Senate.
A Senate-House conference committee cleared tonight, for probable final passage by Congress next week, a strong Federal law to curb the environmental abuses of strip or surface mining for coal.
Vasa K. Bracher, a retired real estate broker and longtime resident of Dongan Hills, S.I., died Monday in Carolton House, a nursing home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 92 years old.

The clanging of rising metal shutters on the store fronts signaled the end of the leisurely lunch break. Businessmen and ranchers filled the tree-shaded street cafes. Indians reopened their small sidewalk stands under a bright, subtropical sun. And the usual procession of trucks heavily laden with sugar cane churned the dust around the central plaza.
SHARP 'BURR' a new Off Off Broadway play by Charles Hallett, a teacher at Fordham University, titled "Aaron Burr" is splendid theater.

France has now obtained the support of Middle Eastern oil-producing countries for her plans for an international conference of oilexporting and oil-consuming nations, according to French officials here.
Mordecai J. Golinkin, senior rabbi of the Orthodox community in Worcester, died today at the age of 90.

On Jan. 7, 1958, Wilbur Daigh Mills became chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and one of the most powerful men in Congress. Today he was in Bethesda Naval Medical Center, his health uncertain, his personal life the subject of rude jokes and his power slipping from his hands.

In the face of a long and openly skeptical cross-examination by the Watergate prosecution, H. R. Haldeman sought repeatedly today to rebut the inferences that the prosecution has drawn from the White House tape recordings.

Members of the National League of Cities are preparing to adopt, and lobby for, a new national urban policy based on the theme that survival for America's cities depends on a sweeping Federal and local commitment to make better use of existing urban resources.

ATLANTA-Lana, a chimpanzee who has learned enough of a modified English to converse with people through a computerized keyboard, has made significant progress toward a more sophisticated use of language since her earlier achievements were reported on this page six months ago.

With preliminary data pointing to a decline of 4 to 5 per cent in the real gross national product in the current quarter, James L Pate, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said yesterday that the present United States recession may be the longest since World War II.

Mayor Beame rejected yesterday a recent proposal by City. Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. for a scofflaw amnesty period, contending that the program would be counter-productive and encourage motorists to break the law.

Dr. Arthur J. Vorwald, a specialist in occupational medicine and respiratory diseases, died Friday in Green Bay, Wis. He was 70 years old. Dr. Vorwald received his medical degree from the University of Chicago in 1931 and a doctorate in pathology there in 1932.

President Ford's latest press conference is an almost perfect illustration of his struggle with himself in his new job. Confronted by devilish economic problems, he tried to say the American people should take the inflation, the recession and the energy crisis seriously, but not too seriously.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market dropped again yesterday as traders were discouraged by a prolonging of the coal strike, the recent upturn in short-term interest rates and other factors.
Ai Senate-House conference committee cleared tonight, for probable final passage by Congress next week, a strong Federal law to curb the environmental abuses of strip or surface mining for coal.
President Ford is trying to buck up business and public confidence on the state of the economy. "Times are nowhere near desperate enough," he said at his news conference this

To his credit, Governor-elect Carey has dealt a potentially lethal blow to the ill-conceived project of extending Long Island's Sunrise Highway from Shinnecock Hills to Amagansett. Mr. Carey has declared himself "dead set against" the planned addition to the expressway, a throwback to the days of highway mania.

The Reynolds Mining Corporation has agreed, after three months of negotiations, to pay increased levies on its operations in Haiti. The Government would receive more than $11-million a year as a result of the readjustment of royalties and taxes paid by the subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company, compared with an average revenue of $1.8-million up to now, President Jean-Claude Duvalier announced yesterday.

The British Petroleum Company, smallest of the world's seven major international oil companies, announced yesterday a 22 per cent increase in profits, to $221-million, or 67 cents a share, for the third quarter of 1974, up from $181million, or 49 cents a share, for the 1973 period.

Marlo Thomas, who looks like a sprite and talks like a waterfall, has taken on a new activity, all in the cause of feminism. The actress, who has never sewed and probably never will, has been appointed director of women's interests for the McCall Pattern Company.
The ormer president of an electrical contracting company pleaded guilty today to making an ilegal corporate contribution of 5,000 to President Nixon's 972 re-election campaign and was fined $1,000.

Britain's Defense Secretary announced plans in Parliament yesterday to cut defense spending by reducing manpower, ending new programs, closing bases and bringing troops home from Southeast Asia. Forces on Cyprus would be reduced as well as most of those in Singapore and some in Hong Kong.
Addis Ababa went into a virtual state of siege today as the military Government arrested eight more persons in the continuing hunt for terrorists setting off bombs in public buildings.

Fanne Foxe tripped and hurt her knee, and last night she canceled her engagement in New York. Miss Foxe said she was canceling because her knee hurt, although a friend said it was because of Wilbur Mills. The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee went into a hospital yesterday, and this, the friend said, upset Miss Foxe.
Hundreds of disappointed Papua-New Guinea tribesmen began returning home today after a threeday expedition to see the announced crucifixion of their cult leader.

The Bowmar Instrument Corporation said yesterday that it had begun legal proceedings in the Federal Court for the Northern District of Indiana in Fort Wayne, alleging violations of the Sherman and Clayton antitrust acts by Texas Instruments, Inc.

The stock holdings of the Rockefellers as disclosed yesterday give support to the Vice President-designate's repeated insistence that his family does not exercise control over major American companies or industries.

" Curtain Call," an exhibition of paintings, posters, sculptures and costumes focusing on the great women of the New York stage, opened yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York to the delight of the old and the curiosity of the young.
Upstate welfare rolls have been holding steady while New York City's have started moving up again, the State Department of Social Services reported yesterday.

Jody Johnson was married here last evening to Morton Alan Rutherfurd, a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant and a great-grandson of Levi P. Morton, Vice President under President Benjamin Harrison and later Governor of New York.

Contracts in October for future construction totaling $7.2billion dropped 18 per cent below the level of October, 1973, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

Mrs. Hamilton Fish, wife of Hamilton Fish Sr., former Republican Representative from Orange County, N. Y., died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was in her sixties and lived at 655 Park Avenue.

Dr. James Hall, dean of adult and continuing education at York College in Queens, testified yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission's proposals for regulating private vocational schools were necessary to prevent the schools from taking advantage of "unsophisticated" students lured to the schools by misleading advertisements.

Just when it seemed as if Rod Laver had exhausted his goals in big-time tennis, he suddenly is finding fresh challenges lobbed teasingly toward him. The 36-year-old Australian will face Jimmy Connors, the top-ranking American, for the first time in a $100,000 challenge match Feb. 2 in Las Vegas.
A major reorganization of the French automobile industry involving two mergers of major companies was announced here today by the Government.
A policeman shot and killed one customer and wounded an other in a Chinatown restaurant yesterday as, the police said, he tried to subdue eight alleged members of a youth gang.

Thompson was amused. "You can, eh? Who are you? A player?" "Roscoe Word," the young man said. "I am in high school." For the hell of it, Thompson timed him. He beat everybody. "I tell people I'm cocky,"
The second stage of a most unusual double was completed in the early hours of this morning here at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Chaminpionships.

With Muhammad Ali at ringside looking him over as a possible opponent, Joe Bugner, the European heavyweight champion, stopped Alberto Santiago Lovell of Argentina tonight in the second round of a scheduled 10round bout.

Delmonica Hanover, a 5-year-old mare owned during the racing season by Delvin Miller of Meadow Lands, Pa., and Arnold Hanger of Lexington, Ky., has been voted the 1974 harness horse of the year. The selection was made in balloting conducted by the United States Trotting Association in conjunction with the United States Harness Writers Association. Delmonica Hanover received 48 votes.
A Queens landlord was shot to death and his brother was wounded shortly before noon yesterday in an attempted holdup of the renting office in the Dexter Apartments, 147-25 88th Avenue, Jamaica.
The British Government announced plans today to cut defense spending by reducing military manpower, ending new programs,

The State of Vermont joined New York today in calling for more environmental studies before a decision was made on construction of a flood control dam on the Richelieu River near St. Jean, Quebec.
The American Medical Association adopted a resolution today urging that physicians-not legislators-decide when death occurs.

E. Parker (Cy) Twombly, former athletic director and golf and swimming coach at Washington and Lee University, died today at a Savannah, Ga., hospital. He was 77 years old.

The City Council approved a bill yesterday that would give the city more effective powers to recover $17.5-million owed by landlords for emergency repairs to their buildings-repairs that were paid for by the city. The Council, acting on a message of necessity from Mayor Beame, passed the bill 38 to 0. The Mayor will sign the bill within 10 days.

I asked my students whether or not a human life was worth at least $5. One student replied that the question was improper since no monetary value could be put on the priceless "gift of life." Another student asked me to be more specific.

Abbey Simon returned to Carnegie Hall on Monday night with a characteristic program of large-scale Romantic pieces: Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue; Brahms's F minor Sonata and the 12 Etudes in Chopin's Opus 10.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation filed suit today to prevent its acquisition by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana. It was also disclosed in Congressional testimony here by Armand Hammer, Occidental chairman, that Arab interests had bought several million shares of Occidental stock two weeks before Indiana Standard tried to acquire Occidental on Nov. 15.

Trustees of the Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday that the huge bankrupt system had operated at a net loss in October of $5.4-million and that its deficit in the first 10 months of this year reached $130.2-million.

More than 100 youthful drug pushers were rounded up today by police officers after a twomonth investigation of narcotics sales in the city's high schools. Assistant Police Chief Daryl Gates said the roundup by 80 Los Angeles police officers began at 6 A.M.
Aides to the Mayor and to the .Controller argued over their differing estimates of the size of the city's expense budget deficit yesterday, and after a two-hour meeting agreed to disagree.
Ira Grayson, a top aide to former Gov. William T. Cahill, was found shot to death in his home today in what the state police said was an apparent suicide. Mr. Grayson was 47 years old.
A Louisville businessman John Y. Brown Jr., said that several American franchises were intefested in having Senator Marlow Cook, Republican of Kentucky, become the next commissioner of the league.

The record goal og three Super Bowl victories in a row now seems plausible for the Miami team. The Dolphins, who by their own admission respond only to challenges, indicated last night they were ready for the playoff route ot Super Bowl IX, to be played in New Orleans on Jan. 12,

Representative Ralph H. Metcalfe, Democrat of Illinois, spiked reports today that he might accede to appeals by black community leaders that he run for Mayor next year.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia granted KLM Royal Dutch Airlines today a sevenday stay in its dispute with the Civil Aeronautics Board despite the C.A,B,'s argument that no such stay was needed.

Archie Griffin of Ohio State, currently the most famous of seven football-playing brothers from Columbus, Ohio, became the 40th winner of the annual Heisman Trophy yesterday as "the outstanding college football player in the nation."

The World Cup skiing season opens tomorrow in this Alpine resort village. Although most of last season's major winners are still racing, a change in the scoring rules has given an advantage to the all-round skier, one who competes in the downhill as well as the slalom and giant slalem events.

A Frontier Airlines 737 jetliner with 102 persons aboard accidentally landed last night at a small landing field used mainly by private planes. The flight landed safely at Salt Lake Airport No. 2, which has a runway of only 5,600 feet, compared with one of 10,000 feet at Salt Lake International, where it was supposed to land.

Every army hay has its decoration day--an occasion for recognition when. officers and rank in file soldiers are summoned forward to be cited for extraordinary acts that may serve as inspiration for others.
The Consolidated Edison Company asked yesterday for state permission to stop taking new applications for natural gas service after Jan. 15 be cause of "severe cutbacks" in supplies.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills entered a hospital today soon after House Democrats voted to reduce further his vast power and began steps to remove him as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

Buck Thornburg rode the 2,000th winner of his career by sending a long shot, Marybelle York, to the winner's circle in the fifth race at Garden State Park and then notched No. 2,001 in the sixth with Umiga's Worth.

Laurence Wilson took on an all-Brahms program in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. Aerosol antiperspirant sprays containing zirconium may cause lung disease and probably are not much better at fighting odor than sprays without the chemical, according to a government report.

A new political storm has erupted in his home state in the wake of Representative Wilbur D. Mills's latest escapade with his nightclub stripper friend.

The International Harvester Company reported yesterday Idwer net income for the final quarter but a record net for the full fiscal year ended Oct. 31. Sales set records for both perjods, reflecting strong demand for agricultural machinery, in. dustrial and construction equipment.

Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that the city "should be on notice that there isn't any new source of state aid" in prospect to help ease the budget problems Mayor Beame has been emphasizing.

Two Soviet astronauts orbiting the earth for the second day adjusted the life support system of their Soyuz 16 spacecraft today to rehearse for the joint Soviet-American space rendezvous planned next July.
Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon announced today that the Treasury would sell at auction two million ounces of its gold-worth about $360-million at current world market prices-on Jan. 6.
William N. Ormsby, a member of the Brown University team that played Washington State in the first official Rose Bowl, died yesterday. He was 82 years old.

President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger issued separate warnings today that a failure by Congress to adopt the Administration's trade bill could have disastrous consequences for the world economy.

Lucio Cabanas, Mexico's slain guerrilla leader, was buried without ceremony in the Atoyac municipal cemetery, Gov. Israel Nogueda Otera of Guerrero state said today. Mr. Cabanas, a folk hero to some poor peasants and a criminal to the authorities, was killed in a shooting battle with soldiers yesterday, the army said.

The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it would condition its approval of the Union Pacific Railroad's acquisition of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad on a requirement that Brown Brothers Harriman Co. of New York become a party to the merger application.
The Society for Ethical Culture moved in State Supreme Court yesterday to end the landmark designation of its 65year-old meetinghouse here by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

The new Democratic caucus in the House of Representatives has a major achievement to its credit a month before the 94th Congress is even to convene. The party that will be overwhelmingly in control of the House has voted to break the power of the Ways and Means Committee-a bastion almost as formidable as the old Rules Committee in the days of Howard W. Smith.

The State Education Commissioner, Fred G. Burke, ordered a homosexual teacher to comply with an order by the Paramus Board of Education and submit to a psychiatric evaluation. Pending the outcome of the psychiatric evaluation and a decision based on the medical screening of fitness to teach, Mr. Burke reinstated the teacher, John Gish, who was suspended by the Paramus board on Sept. 18, 1973.

Leon Dennen, a special correspondent for the Newspaper Enterprise Association and a specialist on European affairs who spoke 15 languages, died yesterday of acute leukemia at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 134 West Fourth Street.

The 84 members of the Rockefeller family are worth more than $1billion in securities owned outright and in trusts from which they benefit, the House Judici'ary Committee was told today by the family's senior financial adviser.

Efforts to forge a tax proposal to resolve New Jersey's fiscal crisis foundered again today when none of the proposed revenue components could gain conclusive support among the Democratic majority in the State Senate.
The Alvin Alley City Center Dance Theater is back with us again for another three-week season, and last night at the City Center it presented a rather interesting company premiere.
" Lakers" was spelled out across the front of their uniforms, but there was an unfamiliar look to the Los Angeles Lakers, beaten last night by the Knicks, 100-95, at Madison Square Garden.

Coach Bill Arnsparger summoned Ron Johnson, his running back, to his office the first thing this morning at the New York Giants' training camp. But whether the 45-minute talk resolved their "dispute" may not be clear until Sunday.

The Government's announcement last night of limited freedom of political association dropped like a dud today on the Spanish political world in one of the most notable anticlimaxes in this country's recent history.

Pioneer 11, having "flown into the jaws of the fiery dragon," as one of space agency official put it, licked its wounds this morning and made new close-in observations as it soared over, Jupiter's northern hemisphere and headed for Saturn.

A mother and her three young children were found dead yesterday in the charred wreckage of their automobile stranded in deep snow along State Highway 251, The victims were Mrs. Sharon Cook, 24 years old, of Beaver Falls, and her children, Carl Jr., 6, Fred, 4, and Silvia, 2.

The French Government announced today that France and Iraq had agreed on a series of business deals worth $1-billion, but it denied reports published yesterday that Iraq had granted France a $1-billion loan.

PARIS-The only great country that gains factually, not just relatively, from the international oil crisis is China. The superpowers, America and Russia, are sufficiently supplied with resources to survive the energy shortage intact if careful; but other major countries such as Japan, India and the European Community have all been severely hit.

Gov. Christopher S. Bond of Missouri, the incoming chairman of the Republican Governors Association, warned his colleagues today that the cure for their party's ills did not lie "in binding ourselves to some narrow ideology that denies the constructive role of government in our society."

Prime Minister Wilson of Britain flew here tonight to confer with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing in an attempt to smooth prospects for the meeting next week of leaders of European Common Market countries.

Players for the Birmingham Americans said today they were disenchanted and dissatisfied, but that they would relent and play in World Bowl I against the Florida Blazers on Thursday night.

Israeli leaders have met at least twice with King Hussein of Jordan to try to settle the issue of the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, the newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth said today.

Johnny Bucyk and Carol Vadnais scored goals 18 seconds apart in the final two minutes of play tonight, enabling the Boston Bruins to gain a 4-4 tie against the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game.

The Upaca Towers apartment building, a new, 32-story addition to East Harlem's skyline, was dedicated yesterday by Federal housing officials who hailed the project as "a brilliant example of city planning."

For Abdeaiiz Ameur, a 48-year-old agricultura worker with seven children, Algeria's Agrarian revolution means living in a solid house with a floor, electricity and running water and sharing in the proceeds of 1,200 acres.
France has signed a contract to supply $800-million in arms to Saudi Arabia. The contract was confirmed by the Defense Ministry here after Lebanese newspapers quoted the Saudi Defense

Negotiators for about 3,000 college faculty members met here today with representatives of the state's Office of Employe Relations in an attempt to settle the labor dispute that closed- the eight state colleges for about two weeks just before Thanksgiving.

A report that the United Mine Workers Union had 'approved their new coal contract enabled the stock market to mount a brief rally and finish mixed in slower trading following three losing sessions in a row.

The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Clarence M. Kelley, says he will not direct the agency to conduct counterintelligence operations in domestic cases without consultation with Attorney General William B. Saxbe and President Ford.

More than 300 American businessmen were told yesterday not to "try to put two cars in every Saudi-Arabian garage," if they hope to do business successfully in the Middle East and benefit from the huge flow of money into the area.

Silver and world sugar futures held center-stage yesterday in commodity futures markets. Trading in silver was marked by exceedingly heavy volume and wide price swings but ended with prices showing little change.

A state judge fined 21 union leaders of a city bus strike $50 each today and sentenced them to jail terms for ignoring court orders to go back to work. District Judge Robert R. Murray sentenced 19 of the men to 20 days in jail and two others to five days in jail.

With Representative Wilbur D. Mills hospitalized and effectively removed as chairman, the other Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee discussed this morning what appeared or its face to be a plan to counter reform and lock themselves into influential positions.

House Democrats further undercut today the conservative-oriented seniority system, bolstered the power of the Speaker and added to the sweeping reforms whose effect will be felt at the White House as well as on Capitol Hill.

Chiang Ching's dance company credibly performs works in a variety of styles but shows special sensitivity to traditional Chinese dance. A selection of these pieces was given Tuesday evening at Hunter College along with some newer works, two of which, "Soliloquy of a Bhiksuni" and "Pien," were premieres.
Security forces today moved against a black terrorist movement called the Dreads, arresting several members. A police spokesman said no violence had been involved in the arrests.

" Monitor," the 20-year-old weekend potpourri of news, entertainment and features, will be terminated in February for a new radio network service devoted primarily to news, information and sports, NBC Radio announced yesterday.
" Before he departed, when he was quite lucid, General Peron asked me to take care of Isabel," said Jose Lopez Rega, the Minister of Social Welfare. "In my way, I have done as he wished."

A City Council committee yesterday debated what women members of the Council should be called. In discussing a bill to change the City Charter designation of Councilman to Council Member, Miriam Friedlander, a sponsor of the bill, said that there had been a change in the atmosphere of the Council and an awareness that four of the 43 members are women.

Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, told a gathering of city officials today that they were neglecting the needs of the poorest constituents in spending Federal revenue-sharing funds.

A reconstruction of the events in the Sunday airliner crash in which 92 persons were killed shows that, just a few minutes before the plane hit, a crewman may have questioned whether the plane was flying too low.

Liquor bills, parking fines, a college tuition fee, a new Chrysler and donations to political and religious organizations all have been entered in the books of the Towers Nursing Home and billed to Medicaid.
When Premier Yitzhak Rabin: spoke to several hundred high school students in Nazareth last week, hostile questions and catcalls turned the question-and-answer session into an angry row.

Senator-Elect John Durkin Democrat victor by 10 votes after a recount, asked a Federal judge today to block the New Hampshire Ballot Law Commission from considering an appeal from the man he defeated, Republican Louis Wyman, R-N.H.

Paul (Bear) Bryant, head coach of Alabama, the college football team ranked No. I by United Press International, was. named Southeastern Conference coach of the year for the fifth time yesterday. He was selected in a poll of fellow coaches in the S.E.C.

The long and painful process by which the city will arrive at an expense budget 'that could approach $13-billion for the fiscal year 1975-76 will begin this morning, when officials of the New York Botanical Garden will appear before Budget Director Melvin N. Lechner to ask for more money to maintain its flower beds.
Frances Kleinfeld Nelkin, for nearly 40 years a leading millinery designer, died Tuesday in Pompano Beach, Fla. Mrs. Nelkin, formerly a resident at 880 Fifth Avenue, was 65 years old.

The New Milford, Conn., school board scoffed yesterday at complaints that its policy of requiring sixth-grade boys to study home economics is leading to "homosexuality" and "moral decay." J. Thomas Eagen, the president of the school board, said the policy would continue despite threats by two Baptist ministers to begin court action and bring the wrath of God upon the Candlewood Lake community.

The number of full-time employes on the payroll of the City of New York increased by 12,950 in the first four months of the current fiscal year, a new set of figures from the Controller's Office showed yesterday.
The annual Delaware-Penn State football awards luncheon, known to some as the Lambert Awards luncheon, will-be held today at the Roosevelt Hotel.
Lawyers for Frank (Pancho) Martin said yesterday they would take "some affirmative action" before Sunday in an effort to block the horse trainer's 60-day suspension.

Many New York stores and their suburban branches turned in their worst decline last month in more than four years. A monthly survey of seven of the city's largest department stores found that they had an average decline of 4.7 per cent in November, compared with the 1973 month.

All 191 people aboard a chartered jet taking Moslem pilgrims to Mecca were presumed to have been killed last night when the plane crashed in the central highlands of Sri Lanka - formerly Ceylon-and burst into flames, an air force spokesman said today.

Three players made strong bids to collect a second national title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals today. Gerald Caravelli of Des Plaines, Ill., who won the mixed pair championship here earlier in the week, turned in a strong performance with Larry Cohen of Los Angeles in the Blue Ribbon pair championship, a six-session event limited to players with proved tournament records.
There has to be set in motion a machinery to disseminate art. This itself is remarkable for art itself has nothing to do with machinery. It is a human endeavor, springing from human passion.

Wiltrud Drexel said she had "an absolutely faultless rice" and Annemarie Proell Moser admitted she had made one mistake. As a result, Miss Drexel won the women's downhill race today as the World Cup skiing season opened and Miss Proell, the defending champion, finished seventh.

Federal Judge indicated today that he would soon appoint a trustee to help the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation divest itself of its controling interest in Avis, the No. 2 car rental company.

Sotheby's announced a record price of $552,000 for a painting by Georges Braque sold at auction today. The cubist painting, "Clarinet and Rum Bottle on a Mantelpiece," was sold to Cassimira Porro, identified by Sotheby's as a Milan agent for an unnamed buyer.

The Environmental Protection Agency praised today the methods o fan Atomic Energy Commission study on the chances of a serious reactor accident, but the agency concluded that deaths and injuries resulting from such an accident could be 10 times higher than suggested by the commission study.

WASHINGTON--The Atomic Energy commission was abolished recently, and for good reason. We are now nearly thirty years into the nuclear age, but still not near the point where we can safely harness the peaceful atom as a major substitute for oil.

In mid-November, the Food and Drug Administration put off until June 30, 1975, the effective date for the introduction of nutritional labeling on all food products for which nutritional claims are made. The delay was ordered primarily on the ground that the "inflationary impact" of the regulations had not been studied.

The prosecution read to the jury at the Watergate cover-up trial today the transcripts of two previously undisclosed conversations held in April, 1973,in which former President Richard M. Nixon offered $200,000 to $300,000 in cash to John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman.

Joseph Papp as a producer. has many qualities, but the two most unusual are loyalty and grit. When he commits himself to a playwright it Appears to be a total commitment. It is much the same with actors. Mr. Papp has a sense of company, a sense of a continuing institution.

By and large, Richard LaManna does not think he got much out of his years in jail. As the 32-year-old admitted burglar, drug dealer, heroin addict and armed robber put it last night, "I'd do a year straight and then get out, turn around and do another year for the same thing."
In an effort to lift future production, the Federal Power Commission today fixed the uniform price of natural gas at 50 cents a thousand cubic feet, an increase of 8 cents.

Bill D. Moyers, who gave up his three-year-old public television series. "Bill Moyers' Journal," last May after it had won three Emmy awards, is mounting a new series for the Public Broadcasting Service that will deal entirely with international affairs.

Darryl Brown scored 16 points in the first 10 minutes of the second half last night to help break open a close game as Fordham defeated Yale, 72-57, at the winner's Rose Hill gymnasium.
The Postal Service today lifted an embargo on mail to France that had been imposed as a result of a strike by French postal workers. The strike was settled last week.
Jack Miller has been listening to New York Giant fans grumble in the back of his caxi all season, searching for answerss to the club's woes.
Acting on evidence of fiscal mismanagement and payroll padding, School Chancellor Irving Anker yesterday suspended the elected community school board of District 9,

Laurance S. Rockefeller, making his second appearance before a Congressional committee in connection with. his brother's Vice-Presidential nomination, disclosed today that in 1961, he made a loan of, $30,000 to William E. Miller, then chairman of the Republican National Committee.
The International Commission of Jurists said today that it had documentary evidence that the military Government in Chile was exercising political control over public and private schools.
The grand jury that indicted the Watergate burglars and then the top aides of former President Richard M. Nixon was discharged today with official thanks after two and a half years of service.
The Crown Zellerbach Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the price of its 30-pound newsprint to $280 from $245 a ton in the western regional market.
First there was the Rose Bowl, 1902. Then there were other bowls culminating in the Super Bowl, anno 1967. Tomorrow night there is the World Bowl.
William J. Evans, founder of the Evans Transportation Corporation, a harbor lighterage firm, died Tuesday. He was 81 years old and lived at 364 Stewart Avenue in Garden City, L.I.
For the benefit of those diehards who believe the only good hockey available in the National Hockey League is played by the original six establishment teams, forget it -- those days are gone forever.

An owner of a payrollprocessing company whose dealings with the Board of Education are under state investigation. has declared that the company gave Christmas gifts of perfume, umbrellas and radios. to "hundreds" of board employes.
The Great Western United Corporation said yesterday that the Hunt brothers had offered to increase their tender offer for the company if the board of directors agreed to resign.

Britain's bakers, normally the least millitant of workers, struck this week for higher pay, leaving consumers with only about a fourth of their normal bread supplies. And Britons haven't been typically British about it.

Johnny Bucyk and Carol Vadnais scored goals 18 seconds apart. in the. final two minutes of play tonight, enabling the Boston Bruins to gain a 4-4 tie against the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game.

Portugal won an accolade today for the way she is helping her former possessions to attain independence. The chairman of the Special Committee on Decolonization, Salin A. Salin of Tanzania, in a formal statement praised the "positive and concrete steps" taken by the Portuguese Government.

The Securities and Exchange Commission gave in slightly to the New York Stock Exchange here today on the future of the industry's pricing policy. But the commission reaffirmed that there was little likelihood it would back away from its firm position that stockbrokers must do away with fixed minimum commission fees by next May.

More than 50 opposition party members of the National Assembly broke into the Assembly hall today and began a sit-in to back demands for changes in South Korea's stringent Constitution.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a tender offer of Cornwall Equities, Ltd., to buy back 250,000 shares of its own stock at $4 each and then to "go private," sources close to the Government agency disclosed yesterday.

A group of Soviet artists who work outside officially approved styles has turned down an offer by the Moscow City a Council to let them hold an indoor exhibition of their noncon- d formist works later this month, one of its organizers said today.

A Gallup survey of rank-andfile preferences for Democratic Presidential candidates in 1976 indicates that no Democrat can yet claim as much as 20 per cent of the field, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is the leading choice with 19 per cent.

Six Brooklyn resident sfiled suit yesterday in State Supreme Court there in an effort to prevent the Beame administration, Borough. President Sebastian Leone and the State Sports Authority from proceeding with a feasibility study for a 15,000seat indor sports arena i n Brooklyn.
The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday it was refunding $4-million in fees collected from cable television concerns rather than try to recompute their bills under a Supreme Court order.
Three thousand employes of 115 milk processing and distributing plants that supply nearly all milk consumed in New York City and on Long Island went on strike last night.

Minnesota, Los Angeles, Oakland and the American Conference Central Division champion will be the host teams in the opening National Football League division playoffs. Minnesota, the National Conference Central winner, takes on the Eastern champion-St. Louis or Washington-on Saturday, Dec. 21. Los Angeles faces the N.F.C.
The grand jury that indicted the Watergate burglars and then the top aides of former President Richard M. Nixon was discharged today with official thanks after two and a half years of service.

MINI-GLOBE TROT Today at noon the World Trade Center's annual winter festival of music, dance and exhibits from many lands opens with the 28-voice Newark Boys Chorus in a one-hour performance. An array of exhibitions will depict holiday traditions in Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Britain, Haiti, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malta, New Zealand, Norway, the Philippines, Poland, Rumania, Sweden and Russia.
Four persons died yesterday in a fire that swept through a Pullman car on a Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus train.

Donald Schonchin, wearing a black cowboy hat, a quilted jacket and dark tinted glasses, was one of the first through the back door of the bank this morning, and he put his $103,000 into an account that he plans to use to buy cattle and land.
A bus and a truck collided head-on today, killing tour persons and injuring 16, the police said.

Assembly man Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, who is expected to be the Speaker of the assembly after Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey takes office, suggested today that the state seek to help ease the fiscal problems of New York City.
The American decision to auction 2 million ounces of gold from its reserve stocks on Jan. 6 depressed both gold and the United States dollar in Europe today.

After earlier gains, stock prices turned lower yesterday in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the Over-the-Counter market. The Amex market value index closed off 0.22 to 61.37 after being up 0.13 at 11 A.M.

The North Atlantic figure-skating championships began today with competition in school figures at the Twin Rinks Arena. Duane Austin, a 16-yearold from Yonkers, led the junior men's event after the compulsory figures.

The prosecution read to the jury at the Watergate cover-up trial today the transcripts of two previously undisclosed conversations held in April, 1973, in which former President Richard M. Nixon offered $200,000 to $300,000 in cash to John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman.

A Federal judge says the United States Jaycees entered into "a private conspiracy" with the Palm Springs, Calif., chapter to deprive the chapter here of the Ten Outstanding Young Men convention next month.
Mayor Renzo Menardi of Cortina d'Ampezzo arrived in New York yesterday to start a campaign to bring the Winter Olympic Games back to his colorful,

Washington Dodge, an investment adviser who survived the Titanic sinking in 1912, died here Tuesday of a heart attack. His age was 67. He was 5 years old and returning from Europe with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Washington Dodge of San Francisco, when the liner hit an iceberg on her maiden voyage.
President Ford, in office less than four months, nov has the worst batting average in veto confrontations with Congress of any President in this century.

The Board of Estimate decided yesterday to defer until at least Jan. 9 a decision on whether to authorize sharply Increased payment for completion of the Third Water Tunnel, a project that has run into costly delays and has threatened to embroil the city and a sixcompany consortium of contractors in protracted lawsuits.
A bill to authorize a $75-million Federal program to help poor families heat their homes was introduced today by Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.

BALTIMORE (A)--Traded Dave McNally, pitcher; Rich Coggins, outfielder; and Bill Kirkpatrick, Pitcher, to Montreal for Ken Singleton, outfielder, and Mike Torrez, pitcher. CALIFORNIA (A)--Traded Bill Glibreth, pitcher, to Cleveland for Rusty Torres, outfielder, Ken Suarez, catcher, and Charlie Hudson, pitcher. All are minor leaguers.
Aldo Trippini, former bureau manager and regional executive for United Press International in Spain, died at his home here last night. He was 51 years old.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia--Abdulaziz al Quraishi, an American - educated public administrator, has been appointed governor of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency, which manages this oil country's enormous financial reserves.

LONDON ASSURANCE, Bouclault comedy from the Royal Shakespeare Company, directed by Euan Smith, incidental music by Guy woolfenden, at the Palace Theater, Broadway and 47th Street, 6:30. THE DESPERATE HOURS, a play by Joseph Hayes, directed by Robert Brink, presented by the Equity Library Theater, 103d Streat and Riverside Drive, 8, through Dec. 15.

A Federal jury awarded Robert A. Maheu $2,823,333.30 damages today in his defamation suit against the billionaire Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation. It was one of the largest compensatory damage awards in United States judicial history.

Leaders of the United Mine Workers will announce tomorrow that the coal miners' strike will end on, Friday as a result of ratification of the industry's contract offer. About 55 per cent of the union members voting are expected to have approved the offer.
When the Solingen Chess Club won the team championship of West Germany recently in West Berlin, its success came as a surprise to no one.
The Big Ten revised its controversial Rose Bowl selection procedure today by approving a new method that virtually eliminates a conference vote.
Paul Shyre, who is a specialist in character anthologies will star in his own adaption of "Blasts and Bravos, an Evening With H. L. Mencken, which will open on Jan. 6 at the Cherry Lane Theater.

Hours after the capacity crowd had filtered out of Bergenfield's stadium on Thanksgiving Day, coach Bob Taglieri sat in the quiet solitude of the hometeam dressing room in a state of soul-searching, attempting to discover where he had failed.
Domestic car sales fell 33.5 per cent to 178,497 units in the Nov. 21-to30 period from 268,459 units a year earlier, indicating no easing of the new-car sales slump.

The Rheingold brewery, coin-operated laundries and other highvolume water users were shutdown and a state of emergency was declared today after six 70year -old pipes burst and crippled the city's water supply.

The Philippine Government announced today that it would soon put on trial a former Manila newspaper publisher and the son of a defeated presidential candidate who allegedly plotted to kill President Ferdinand E. Marcos.
Konstantin Melnikov, one of Russia's leading avant-garde architects, died in Moscow a week ago at the age of 84. Word of his death was received here yesterday.

Double - your - money- back offers have been used over the years by packaged-goods manufacturers seeking new markets. Now one agency, Marsteller, Inc., is making a double-your-salary offer to Federal Trade Commission regulators of nutritional disclosures in advertising.

The Dalton School's board of trustees announced yesterday the appointment of a new headmaster--Dr. Gardner P. Dunnan, who has been district principal in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., since 1969. Dr. Dunnan will take over his new post at the private school on Jan. 2.

Leaders of the United Mine Workers will announce tomorrow that the coal miners' strike will end on.. Friday as a result of ratification of the industry's contract offer. About 55 per cent of the union members voting are expected to have approved the offer.

With Representative Wilbur D. Mills hospitalized and effectively removed as chairman, the other Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee discussed this morning what appeared on its face to be a plan to counter reform and lock themselves into influential positions..

John E. Sheehan, who was named to the Federal Reserve Board in 1971 by President Richard M. Nixon, yesterday accused the Ford Administration and Congress of failing to take the lead in fighting inflation.

The Senate narrowly approved a $2.67-billion foreign aid authorization bill today after having voted to delay a cutoff in aid to Turkey.

THE TRIUMPH OF ART NOUVEAU: PARIS EXHIBITION 1900. By Philippe Jullian. Translated from the French by Stephen Hardman. 216 pages. Illustrated. Larousse. $19.95 until Dec. 25, 1974; $25 thereafter. Though it anticipated the official birth of that movement by some 30 years, the Paris Exhibition of 1900 was undoubtedly the greatest surrealist event of all time.
Vincent Joseph Brosnahan, who retired in 1970 as advertising sales manager of Sports Illustrated magazine, died yesterday in Baltimore. He was 62 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam-- If any dish was ultimately responsible for a visit that entailed several thousand miles of travel to South Vietnam, it was cha gio, considered by many to be the national dish of the country. It is pronounced zhah-zhaw, and we first sampled it several years ago in a few of the flourishing Vietnamese restaurants of Paris.
Members of the Forest Hills South Tenants Association gathered outside their seven-buillding apartment Complex in Quens to protest security provisions in the building and to announce a rent strike.

While purchasing executives throughout the country are predicting a further deterioration in business conditions, they expect the worst will be over by the middle of 1975. This was the consensus of a majority of executives surveyed last month by the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc.

The Major League Baseball Players Association has offered the club owners what amounts to a no-strike pledge in return for early bargaining and binding arbitration of unresolved issues after a cutoff date.

Jurors won't sit, lawyers take vacations and witnesses are hard to locate. So this year the traditional two-week Christmas holiday has been reinstituted for most of the State Supreme Court Justices in the five boroughs.

House Democrats further undercut today the conservative-oriented seniority system, bolstered the power of the Speaker and added to the sweeping reforms whose effect will be felt at the White House as well as on Capitol Hill.
Japan's Premier-designate, Takeo Mikd, said today that the governing Liberal-Democratic party was in its "greatest crisis" and needed "drastic reform."
Premier Yitzhak Rabin has suggested that Israel may soften her demand for a formal Egyptian renunciation of belligerency as a conditionn for a further Israeli pullback in occupied Sinai.

A 4-year-old boy and a 40year-old man were killed in two separate fires in the Williamsbridge section of the North Bronx last night, fire officials reported . The boy, Anthony Oliver, was trapped by a fire that swept a three-family dwelling at 724 East 224th Street.
Dick Allen, the missing man of baseball, surfaced long enough today to say "no thanks" to Atlanta, but nobody took him too seriously as the major leagues' winter trading market kept booming along.
For the benefit of those diehards who believe the only good hockey available in the National Hockey League is played by the original six establishment teams, forget it-- those days are gone forever.
Three thousand employes of 115 milk processing and distributing plants that supply nearly all milk consumed in New York City and on Long Island went on strike last night.

The Kuwait Foreign Investment Company, a nongovernmental concern, will take at least a one-sixth share in a $400-million wood and paper mill to be built in Brazil, the newspaper Al-Qabas reported today.
Helen Appleton Read, art critic and art historian, died Tuesday at her home. She was 87 years old and lived at 146 Hicks Street, Brooklyn.

The Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance served the directors of a landlord association, the Community Housing Improvement Program, with two restraining orders signed in Brooklyn and Manhattan Housing Courts to prevent its members from shutting their boilers down today.

Hearings into questionable investments of pension and welfare funds of Amalgamated Union Local 355, allegedly involving persons with underworld ties, were closed yesterday by the State Commission of Investigation.

The State Public Advocate today filed suit to prevent new patients from .being admitted to Greystone Park, the state's largest psychiatric hospital.

The Most Rev. Vincent S. Waters, Roman Catholic Bishop of the Diocese of Raleigh, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home. He was 70 years old. Bishop Waters had headed the diocese since 1945 when it included all of North Carolina.
Food prices in the city increased 1.2 per cent last week, the largest rise since last Jan. 24, when the rise was 1.4 per cent, the Consumer Affairs Department announced yesterday.
About 14 million Italians walked off their jobs today to demand guaranteed employment, more social security benefits and higher cost-of-living adjustments.
In assessing the importance and the consequences of Wilbur D. Mills's fall from power, the crucial point that was to be remembered is why he had the power In the first place.
Fernando Gerassi, a painter and resident artist at the Putney School in Vermont, died Tuesday in University Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 75 years old and lived in Putney.
Democratic leaders changed the rules of their charter conference today to let the party write a sweeping resolution the nation's troubled economy at the conference next weekend.
Communist-led forces ambushed a South Vietnam Government military convoy in the Mekong Delta southwest of Saigon, killing 15 militiamen and wounding 45, military head-quarters here reported today.
Life has dealt a strange hand to Claire Alexander of the Toronto Maple Leafs, who last Monday became the oldest rookie in the National Hockey League.

A special three-man military tribunal began trying former Government officials today on charges of corruption and maladministration, a spokesman for the military Government said.

About 500 production workers at the G.T.E.-Sylvania plant here will be laid off indefinitely, starting Dec. 13, company officials have announced.

The first official estimates for the key sector of business investment in plant and equipment in 1975, covering the first half of the year, indicated today a weakening in this key prop under the economy.
Less than two years before the nation observes the bicentennial of the American Revolution, the British are once again occupying New York, at least the part of it that is called Broadway theater.

About 100 women, most of them unmarried and many carrying their lunches in brown paper bags, trooped to the "Y" yesterday for a noontime lecture. The subject: "The Single Woman." The speaker was Eileen' Setzman, a 32-year-old unmarried psychotherapist and past member of the New York Radical Feminists, who said her private practice on Central Park West was confined largely to women patients who are often referred to as "the new woman."

The two houses of Parliament today elected Foreign Minister Pierre Graber to serve as President of Switzerland for 1975. Mr. Graber, who will be 66 years old on Friday, received 187 of the 209 valid votes cast. He was unopposed in accordance with the tradition that calls for the Presidency to be rotated annually among the seven members of the collegialtype government.

Nothing is up to date in Kansas City. Like generals who are always preparing to fight the previous war, Democrats at their midterm conference have focused on the issue that ruined their 1972 convention: quotas.

Three black African Presidents were meeting here today amid intense speculation about moves toward a Rhodesian settlement. Radio Zambia said that Presldents Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania and Sir Seretse Khama of Botswana would be "having routine consultations with President Kenneth Kaunda on matters of common interest."
Bernard A. Schmickrath, a former executive in the aviation engine industry, died Tuesday at Tucson; Ariz., apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
Prices moved up yesterday in the corporate, municipal and Government bond markets recovering some of the ground lost on Monday and Tuesday.

President Ford's chief economic advisers said today that the nation's slide into recession had accelerated recently but insisted that Administration policies would be able to restore stability over the long run.

Amid speculation among some politicians that his days as Brooklyn Democratic leader are numbered, Meade H. Esposito insisted this week that he intended to serve until his term ends in September, 1976.

Leonard Bernstein, the conductor and composer, testified yesterday that he had never evaluated a music library donated to the University of Wisconsin by Skitch Henderson, the musician charged with income-tax evasion.
The House voted today, 212 to 176, to accept a compromise with the Senate that could effectively ban the busing of schoolchildren to achieve racial desegregation.

Three investment bankers anil two spokesmen for public utilities told state regulators yesterday that they must be more responsive to the asserted needs of utilities for greater profits or risk deterioration of service to the public.

Occasionally, there's a movie that almost bestows a lifelong allergy to close-ups. After watching the huge faces awash with repressed emotions or the great meaningless grins and mild scowls in Stephen Dwoskins's "Death and Devil," you may never again want to see a mug that's larger than your own.
The Seattle problem Is among several topics to be taken up tomorrow as the formal meetings of baseball's big leagues begin.

When Karen M. Kopsa, a 23-year-old media coordinator at Peitscher, Janda Assoociates, Inc., a Chicago advertising agency, learned that she had won Esquire magazine's Christmas Gift Contest, she not only got the right to choose $2,500 worth of gifts but she also became "an instant celebrity."

The number of full-time employes on the payroll of the City of New York increased by 12,950 in the first four months of the current fiscal year, a new set of figures from the Controller's Office showed yesterday.

Nine-year-old Kevin Johnson sat on Santa Claus's lap at Macy's yesterday morning and asked for a bicycle. "He said he would put it on order at the North Pole and that I would get it," Kevin reported solemnly. Angel Vale, also 9, was not as positive as his friend.

President Valry Giscard d'Estaing is preparing for his first meeting with resident Ford next week with in air of optimism that he can ??ase French-American disputes in several key issues, among hem the oil crisis.
A small storm is brewing in Key Biscayne, Fla., over attempts by Richard M. Nixon and two of his millionaire friends to have the street on which they have homes be made a private road.
Former President Richard M. Nixon's health is improving, but he suffers from a slight case of pneumonia in his right lung, his surgeon said today.

AGRESS--Jacob, Beloved husband of Jane, devoted father of Geraldine, Phyllis and Mortimer. Cherished grandfather. Funeral services today, 10:30 A.M. at the P. J. Morris Inc. Funeral Home, 9701 Church Ave., at Rockaway Pkwy., Bklyn.

Donald Schonchin, wearing a black. cowboy hat, a quilted jacket and dark tinted glasses, was one of the first through the back door of the bank this morning, and he put his $103,000 into an account that he plans to use to buy cattle and land.

Cardinal Cooke will officiate at a special mass tomorrow for U Thant, former Secretary General of the United Nations, who died last week. The service will be held at 9:30 A.M. in Holy Family Church, on 47th Street between First and Second Avenues.
The American Stock Exchange will admit to listing and dealings tomorrow $20-million in Mitsui Co., Ltd., 8 1/4 per cent sinking fund convertible debentures due Sept. 30, 1989.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is expected to announce today that he has prepared legislation to require licensing of most gold dealers doing business in New York State.
