Tenants of the Forest Hills South Apartments gathered yesterday morning in front of the neatly landscaped gardens of their seven-building complex to announce the beginning of a rent strike over security provisions in the buildings.

France has signed a contract to sell $800million in arms to Saudi Arabia. The Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan ibn Abdel Aziz, was quoted in Lebanese newspapers as having said that France would provide antiaircraft missiles and antitank weapons and would strengthen his country's tank force.

When the United States Custims Service seized 333,045 pounds of lobster tails more than two years ago, the shipment was worth $1.5-million. At a court ordered auction yesterday, six bidders paid $453,300 for the lot-about $1.37 a pound.

The will of H. L. Hunt, the Dallas oil billionaire, has been filed for probate, and one of its stipulations is that anyone who challenees it will forfeit all rights to benefits and property listed in the will.

The State Public Service Commission yesterday ordered the New York Telephone Company to stop providing a flatrate intrastate Wide Area Telephone Service-the WATS lines that let a customer make unlimited long-distance calls inside the state for a single charge.

A Federal jury awarded Robert A. Maheu $2,823,333.30 damages today in his defamation suit against the billionaire Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation. It was one of the largest compensatory damage awards in United States judicial history.

All day long, on the news bulletins, the big news-was that President. Ford was going to hold. a press conference. The President will answer questions tonight, the announcers breathlessly told us. He will have two statements. His spokesman, Ron Nessen, refuses to say how "major" they will be.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau told President Ford today that Canada intended to pursue a mote protective, nationalist policy on energy resources, ultimately ending the export of oil to the United States.

The Belgian Government and the Belgian Banking Commission have approved a proposal to merge the Banque Lambert and the Banque de Bruxelles, S.A., sources close to the two banks said today. The sources said the merger would be announced officially tomorrow, with action to put it into effect starting Friday.
In an effort to lift future production, the Federal Power Commission today fixed the uniform price of natural gas at 50 cents a thousand cubic feet, an increase of 8 cents.

She has not been performing in public, her friends say, because she does not want to appear unless the conditions are precisely right.

David Thompson broke an Atlantic Coast Conference individual scoring record for a single game tonight with 57 points, and top-ranked North Carolina State rolled over Buffalo State, 144-88.

The Italian Senate today voted its confidence in the Government of Premier Aldo Moro. The vote was 190 to 113.
Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Sr., the widow of the publisher who died in 1951, died yesterday afternoon at her home, 4 East 66th Street. She was 92 years old.
Members of South Korea's two opposition parties began a sit-in inside the national Assembly today, calling on the Government to revise the Constitution.
In the end, the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer semifinals saw the favorites win tonight, but not before the opposition offered strong resistance, especially in the second game.
An expert from the Middle West headed confidently for his second title in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

Talks between three African presidents and Rhodesian black leaders were held today amid speculation that a breakthrough was near in Rhodesia's dispute with Britain over progress toward black-majority rule.
The House Judiciary Committee completed its hearings today on the Vice-Presidential nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller, which now seems certain to be approved by both houses of Congress.
Emile F. du Pont, a member for many years of the board of E. I. du pont de Nemours Co. and director of its employ-relations department, died yesterday in Wilmington, Del. His age was 76.

Approval of the coal strike settlement by rank-andfile vote marks an impressive advance in the march of the United Mine Workers away from a half-century tradition of union autocracy.

Business loans at major New York City banks continued to increase in the week ended Wednesday, but their rise was smaller than a week earlier, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

A military court sentenced three Croatian nationalists today to 12 years in prison for having hijacked a Scandinavian Airlines System jetliner from Sweden to Spain two years ago.

The nationwide coal miners' strike, which halted production of nearly 70 per cent of United States coal for three weeks, had only a slight impact upon the economy over all, Government officials and business economists said yesterday.
Dwight Davis and Bobby Smith combined for 43 points to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 124-91 victory over the Kansas City - Omaha Kings in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
Three young Coast Guardsmen stationed on Governors Island were killed in an automobile accident last night on East River Drive in Lower Manhattan.

The snow-laden roof of Teheran's newly enlarged. airport terminal caved in on the main lounge yesterday, and Government officials said that 34 bodies had been recovered and as many as 30 more might still be buried in the rubble.
United States District Judge John J. Sirica ruled today that former President Richard M. Nixon need not testify either on the witness stand or through deposition in the Watergate cover-up trial.

Spokesmen for the natural gas industry said yesterday that the increased price set by the Federal Power Commission Wednesday was a step in the right direction but was no substitute for a complete deregulation of prices.

An American soldier who has been in prison for more than two months for refusing to get a haircut has been set free because the United States Army discovered it had tapped a conversation about him by his lawyer-after swearing in court that it had not.
Virginia C. Lavelle, executive assistant in the Ford Foundation's division of humanities and arts, died of cancer Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
Officers of the United Mine Workers signed a new three-year labor contract with the coal industry today, officially ending the 24-day miners' strike at midnight tonight.
Archbishop Makarios advised Acting President Glarkos Clerides today that he had postponed his return to Cyprus by one day and would arrive Saturday.

Richard A. Sprague, Philadelphia'sfirst assistant district attorney, who as a special state prosecutor won a murder conviction of W. A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers, was discharged today for alleged insubordination.
A three-alarm fire swept through the top two floors of a six-story brick apatrment building in the Tremont section of the Bronx last night, injuring six firemen, one seriously.
The Saginaw Steering Gear division of the General Motors Corporation will lay off 458 hourly employes indefinitely to. morrow. It represents 5 per cent of the division's work force.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the Over-theCounter market fell again yesterday for the fourth session as bullish news continued to be scarce.

Postmaster General E. T. Klassen forecast today new postal rate increases as early as July. The Postal Seervice is still operating at a loss. Mr. Klassen said that the 1974 deficit would probably be "in excess of $400million" and the one for 1975 perhaps twice that much.

A sit-in yesterday by 200 parents and auxiliary employes at the headquarters of Community School District 9 in the Bronx apparently delayed the plan by School Chancellor Irvving Anker to replace the elected board with an appointed trustee.

The Soviet-American nuclear arms agreement negotiated two weeks ago at Vladivostok has been hailed by the Ford Administration as a cap on the arms race and attacked by its critics as, in effect, permitting that race to continue.

Hazel Hotchkiss Wightman, who won 45 national tennis titles in 45 years, died last night at her home in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Mrs. Wightman, who was active until recently when she fell at home, was 87 years old.
Senior Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee reasserted their temporarily dormant power today to quell further efforts within the House to limit their authority.

Flight 95 from New York had roast chicken and pizza on the menu, and Robert F. Wagner, Stanley Steingut and Albert Shanker in the passenger compartment. Charter flights don't get much more eclectic than that,
Dr. Ernest E. Keet Jr., Who had been chief of medicine at Jamaica Hospital, Queens, died Tuesday in Saranac Lake, N.Y., where he moved in 1970. His age was 61.

Prices moved up again yesterday in fixed-income securities, buoyed partly by the signs of a deteriorating economy that clobbered the stock market, now testing a 12-year low in the Dow Jones industrial average.

Co-counsels were named in Trenton to a legislative inquiry into the $625,000 given to Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, by Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller. The gift was disclosed in Washington during Congressional hearings on Mr. Rockefeller's nomination. Mr. Rockefeller said the money was given to Dr. Ronan when he was head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York City.

The National Football League awarded its expansion Seattle franchise yesterday to a group of businessmen headed 'by Lloyd W. Nordstrom and gave the Tampa franchise to a Florida attorney, Hugh F. Culverhouse.

Members of an organization representing 15,000 American municipalities adopted today a national urban policy that calls generally for a Federal policy of conservation of the nation's urban resources and specifically for such things as the creation of at least one million public service jobs.

Dennis Awtrey's 18-foot shot with 1 minute 29 seconds to go in the second overtime proved to be the margin that gave the Phonix Suns a 108106 National Basketball Association victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight.
For ordinary citizens of New York, the art of making budget projections, as practiced by their public officials, is as arcane as the technique of spinning prayer wheels in Tibetan lamaseries.

The American and National Leagues created their first joint committee on baseball expansion today to avoid what one club owner denounced as "the stupidity of the past."

HOLBROOK, L.I.--The mobile-homeowners were not activists when they started. Mostly they were people of limited income, trying to solve their housing needs as best they could. But some of them are activists now.
A small package wrapped in brownn paper exploded today as an employee of the United Parcel Service was opening it. The employee was killed and eight persons were injured, none seriously.

Premier Yitzhak Rabin said. today that Israel was prepared to take far-reaching territorial compromises with the Arab nations in return for peace, but he ruled out a return to the borders that existed before the 1967 war.

Mention the word baking to Mary Ellen Shaeffer and she sighs. "I think it's gotten out of hand," she says, with the kind of grin that indicates she has no intention of doing anything about it. "I've reached the point where I'm now competing with myself."

Takeo Miki, who is due to become Premier of Japan Monday, is widely expected to seek advice on economic policy from the former Finance Minister, Takeo Fukuda, who devised the current tight-money policy of fighting inflation.
The Justice Department today accused three major transporters of mobile homes with illegal price fixing and monopoly.
A leading Soviet writer has assailed Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn for having expressed doubt that Mikhail Sholokhov was the author of the novel "And Quiet Flows the Don."
For centuries, hunters have been using various "blinds" to hide themselves from waterfowl they intend to kill or capture.

Three of the central figures in a yearlong state inquiry into alleged official corruption in Lindenwold, in Camden County, refused to testify at a public hearing today and initial steps for an arrest warrant were ordered for a fourth subpoenaed witness, who failed to appear.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and President Ford agreed today to work toward bringing France into the joint effort of' Western industrial nations to cope with the international energy crisis and attendant financial problems.
Disagreeing with the Secretary of the Treasury, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told Congress today that it was a mistake to permit Americans to own gold starting Dec. 31.

The city's Board of Ethics announced yesterday that it would await the outcome of other investigations now under way before proceeding with its own inquiry into whether Joseph Monserrat, a member of the Board of Education, was involved in a conflict of interestin connection with the award of a board contract in 1971 to a company for which he had been a paid consultant.
Frances Hardin Reid, wife of Cornelius J. Reid Jr., chairman of the board of RBH/Reid Carr, Inc., died yesterday at her home on Horseshoe Road in Mill Neck, L. I. She was 43 years old.

President Ford virtually wrapped up yesterday the executive branch's role under the 1964 Wilderness Act by urging Congress to add nine million acres to the federally owned property set aside to be kept in a wild, unspoiled condition.
The British Government today announced further financial aid to Rolls-Royce, Ltd. for development of a more powerful version of the controversial RB211 engine for use in Boeing jumbo jets.

Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, the chairman of the county Republican committee, and the County and State Civil Service Commissions were named in a lawsuit filed today and alleging kickbacks to the Republican party by Civil Service employes as a condition of employment or promotion.
Consumer installment credit rose by the smallest amount this year in October and the increase in total consumer credit was the smallest in four years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

David Randolph's Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra opened its annual series of "Messiah" concerts Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. The first of the five seemed rather early in the holiday season, 11 days before the next (the others are twice on Dec. 22 and once on Dec. 28, the last at Carnegie Hall.
The stock market continued yesterday to react to negative economic news, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing within less than 3 points of its lowest close in more than 12 years.
Dr. Virginia MacDonald Moore, a psychiatrist, died Wednesday at Signal Mountain, Tenn. She was 73 years old.
Pietro Germi the film director gained fame in the United States for his Oscar-winning "Divorce Italian Style," died of hepatitis today in a clinic here. He was 60 years old.
As quickly as he became a hero, Clint Longley just as quickly has returned to his standby role for tomorrow afternoon's Cleveland- Dallas game.

The scheduled return to Cyprus tomorrow of President Makarios, nearly five months after his ouster in a coup ordered by Greece's disintegrating military dictatorship, Is unquestionably a symbol of both moral justice and constitutional order. But even some of his supporters fear that the Archbishop's homecoming at this time will diminish prospects for fruitful negotiations looking toward a peaceful political, economic and social reconstruction of the island republic.

" What are we going to do with the King?" said a cafe owner, as he served tiny cups of Turkish coffee. "We don't need him, he's not necessary. If I vote for him now, my children will live under him. I can't vote for someone who will rule my children."
A gunman held three French dip- a lomats hostage for five hours in the French consulate here today before he was disarmed by police.

Lazar has announced plans-long overdue-to crack down on utility companies that have been cutting up city streets with scant concern for the convenience and comfort of the people who have to use them.

Richard Foreman, as play-wright, director and designer, leads his company through paces carefully described in his script.

Two major oil companies announced yesterday wage increases of 7 per cent and 8 per cent for all nonunion employes, The Associated Press reported. Texaco, Inc., said it had granted effective last Sunday a salary increase of 7 per cent for its nonunion workers in the United States. The Atlantic Richfield Company raised wages 8 per cent effective last Monday of all nonunion employes except the company's officers.
Apparently defying a Federal court order, New Hampshire's all-Republican Executive Council rescinded today the certification of John A. Durkin, a Democrat, as the state's new United States Senator.

The audience Wednesday night at the Felt Forum was immediately on its feet in tribute to the mystique of the Allman musical family however many Matches--the usual end-ofconcert tribute--were even being lighted during the opening performance by the accompanying group. Ken Congemi, a 12-year-old from Commack, L.I., won the juvenile boys title today in the North Atlantic figure skating championships at the Twin Rinks Arena.

The Federal Government has quietly given up its long fight to put Meyer Lansky, reputed to have served as a financial wizard for the underworld, behind bars. Dough aid McMllan, the Federal prosecutor, confirmed in Miami that the Justice Department would not appeal a decision by the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit that threw out the only conviction the Government ever obtained against Mr. Lansky.

Frank (Pancho) Martin, New York's leading horse trainer, agreed yesterday to withdraw his court challenge to a 60-day suspension and let the State Racing and Wagering Board hear his appeal. He is seeking relief against the action of the stewards who penalized him for alleged illegal use of medication on two of his horses.

Victor Galindez of Argentina and Len Hutchins of Kalamazoo, Mich., meet here tomorrow night for the vacant World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title. It will be the third attempt by an Argentine light heavyweight in less than six months to win the title, but the first time in front of a home crowd.

The Jersey Bicentennial Commission has announced a statewide competition for professional and amateur cameramen. There will be entries for the following categories: black and white prints, color prints, pictorial color slides and color slide historical essay.
William K. O'Connell, merchandise manager of B. Altman Co. here, died yesterday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.
Christine Casson, director of publicity for Farrar, Straus Giroux, book publishers, was married yesterday afternoon to John Kevin Madden, advertising director of New York magazine.
Prime Minister. Indira Gandhi, in a rare speech on birth control, conceded today that India's family-planning program "had not been very impressive."

The quickest hands in pro basketball went to work tonight in the second half. With the help of Walt Frazier, the Knicks came up with 10 steals, eight in the second half, and "stole the game" from the Philadelphia 76ers.

As a result of the new coal miners' contract agreement, electric utilities and steel producers will be asked to pay producers $3 to $10 more per ton of coal than at present, the head of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association said yesterday.

Talley Beatty's explosive dance work "The Road of the Phoebe Snow" was a staple for many years of the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater. Sometimes it was not so well danced, and at other times it was danced very well.

The police said today that a package bomb that exploded at the United Parcel Service here yesterday, killing one employee and injuring 10 others, was addressed to the Spectrum Custom Cycles Shop in Leechburg, Pa., about 35 miles northeast of here.

Three African Presidents today continued efforts to bind Rhodesia's splintered black nationalist movement into a unified front' that could hold new constitutional talks with the white minority Government of the former British colony.

With Rich and Laura Thomasey, track and field is an "all in the family" proposition. Rich is the coach of the Summit High School track and field team, while his wife, Laura, became the first woman coach of a boys' high school cross-country team in New Jersey this fall when she took the job at Middlesex High.

The Navy found a 19-year-old seabee guilty of assault and battery today for hitting his commanding officer in the face with a chociate creame pie despite testimony from Supy Sales, the comedian, that the incident wasa harmless joke."

BishopLoughlinHighSchool swept three events in the Monsignor Farrell Catholic schools winter relays yester-. day on Staten Island, Loughlin won the four-mile relay in 18 minutes 19.1 seconds and also captured the sophomore four-mile and freshman two-mile events.

Representatives of the American partners in the Arabian American Oil Company have left for London for what may well be the final act in the long drawn out 100 per cent takeover by the Saudi Arabian Government of what is said to be the world's most important petroleum operation.

President Ahmed Hassan alBakr of Iraq, who has been absent from official functions for three weeks, is critically ill after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage, according to Arab and Communist diplomatic sources.

Texaco, Inc., has announced that it is adopting the last-in, first-out method of inventory accounting for its domestic inventories of crude oil and petroleum products, effective Jan. 1.

The poet Richard Wilbur was elected 13th president of the American Academy of Arts and Letters yesterday at the organization's annual meeting. He succeeds the composer Aaron Oppland, who had served the usual three-year term.

The State Health Department said yesterday that it had conducted partial audits of 14 nursing homes that it considered to be affiliated with the Bernard Bergman syndicate and had found $1,186,933 in overcharges to Medicaid.

Communist-led forces mounted a shelling and ground attack yesterday against a district capital in the Mekong Delta and radio contact with the town was cut off for more than 24 hours, military sources here reported.

Bjorn Borg played his best tennis since arriving in Australia from Sweden and gained a straight-set victory today over Uli Marten of West Germany in the quarterfinals of the South Australian lawn tennis championships. Borg, the top-seeded player, won, 6-1, 6-1, to join Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, Onny Parun of New Zealand and Colin Dibley of Australia in the semifinals. Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey named two committees yesterday to study the state's economic problems. The first is to recommend measures to strengthen the state's economy and the second to suggest measures to meet "the short-term emergency situation of high unemployment" in the state.

Charles Wuorinen's Second Piano Concerto, which was given its premiere yesterday afternoon by the New York Philharmonic, begins and ends on a plain, unvarnished C. In the 25 minutes that the work takes, a great deal happens-some of it of interest to the mind and almost none of it appealing to the senses.

Grain prices tools a tumble yesterday. Soybeans led the decline in futures prices. Traders cited the sharp, drop in the stock market as one factor, along with the increase in the unemployment rate to 6.5 per cent. Also, some Democratic part leaders, meeting in Kansas, City, indicated that they would pass a resolution urging passage of wage and price controls.

The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction in the discount rate it charges on its loans to banks. The action was interpreted as being the clearest message since late August that the central bank wants to make credit conditions easier.
The senior women's event, tile main competition of the North Atlantic figure skating championships, began today at the Twin Rinks with Barbara Salomon of Hempsead, L. I., holding a solid lead.

A Federal judge today denied a second attempt by John A. Durkin, the Democratic candidate in New Hampshire's United States Senate race, to block state review of his razor-thin victory.

Efforts by conservationists to block a sixday deer hunt scheduled to start Tuesday in the Great Swamp of Morris County failed today when a Federal District Court judge refused to grant an. injunction preventing the hunt.

Atlantic Richfield Canada, Ltd., said today its decision to withdraw from the Syncrude oil project in the Athabasca tar sands in Alberta probably will result in an after-tax writeoff of $20-million. Arcan said it decided to withdraw principally because inflation has driven the estimated cost of the project to more than $2-billion from an original $1.2-billion.

The jury at the Watergate cover-up trial informed Federal Judge john J. Sirica today that it did riot want the trial to be hurried unduly just so that it could be releasedd from sequestration in rime for Christmas.

Skitch Henderson denied on the witness stand yesterday that he had backdated any documents to make his donation of a music library eligible for large deductions on his Federal income returns for 1969 and 1970.
Near a coconut-palm fringed beach on fashionable Victoria Island here a $20-million 500-room luxury hotel is taking shape.

The bodies of two Americans were among the 17 bodies recovered so far from the ruins of the Teheran airport passenger lounge, where a snow-covered roof collapsed yesterday, officials said today. Another American was injured.

A caravan of ranchers and 47 ahead of cattle hit the concrete trail to Washington today to carry their protest against high costs, low profits and Federa! farm policies to Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz.

A committee of the International Skiing Federation announced today that it had voted to disqualify two American men skiers from the next World Cup giant slalom race because of an alleged violation of the rules fore the event here yesterday.

Milk dealers and their striking employes reached a tentative accord early today that brought prospects for an end of the two-day walkout tomorrow and resumption of deliveries to the city and Long Island by Monday.

Christina F. Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Fisher Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married there yesterday afternoon to Olaf Holvick 2d, son of Mrs. Olaf Holvick, also of Grosse Pointe, and the late Mr. Holvick. The bride is known as Tina and her husband as Tim.

Through a maze of criteria that seemed to be based on a combination of hieroglyphics and cuneiform, the Buffalo Bills have assured themselves of a spot in the American Conference playoffs. Now they'll try and dethrone the Miami Dolphins, who have been Eastern Division champions the last three years.

The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., told a Federal Appeals Court today that a $30-million steel industry discrimination settlement should be abandoned because it had blocked individual suits against the companies.
For nearly five months Chinese newspapers and broadcasts have been filled with earnest homilies on the need for unity.

If words were as good as deeds, the lower house of the New York State Legislature-described recently by Common Cause, the national citizen's lobby as "one of the most secretive, unresponsive and oligarchical in the nation"-would be well on its way to revolutionary reform.

Mayor Beame's Budge Bureau said yesterday that the number of full-time employes under mayoral jurisdiction had declined in the first four months of the current fiscal year during an austertiy drive and had not increased as indicated in a computer printout produced by the Controll'ers office.

The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction in the discount rate it charges on its loans to banks. The action was interpreted as being the clearest message since late August that the central bank wants to make credit conditions easier.
At an unexpected cost of $18.4million, the Defense Department believes it has broken a production bottleneck that has sharply limited the supply of tanks for the United States Army and for Israel.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's one - act opera, "Amahl and the Night Visitors," is back, today and tomorrow at 5 P.M. at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where the one-hour work won acclaim last year. Edward J. King, the highest paid public official in Massachusetts, resigned his $59,500 post as executive director of the Massachusetts Port Authority today.

The former general manager of a large contracting company testified today that it had made a $15,000 donation to the 1969 campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahaill's campaign after Republican fund raisers offered a way of deducting the gift on Federal income taxes.
The senior women's event, the main competition of the North Atlantic figure skating championships, began today at the Twin Rinks with Barbara Salomon of Hempsead, L. I., holding a solid lead.

The state of Michigan presented the 1974 White House Christmas tree to Betty Ford today. Less than an hour later, a congressman's aide ran into the tree with his automobile in the White House driveway. "Oh, the sun blinded me. Oh, yeah.

Two men and a construction company were indicted by a Federal grand jury for allegedly masterminding a scheme to swindle four international airlines out of $36,650. United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said the scheme involved arranging for a travel agency to receive 25 airline tickets to various parts of the world and declare itself bankrupt before the tickets were paid for.

The City Investigations Commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, said yesterday that his office was looking into alleged fiscal irregularities in United Harlem Drug Fighters, a four-year-old detoxification and rehabilitation program based at Harlem Hospital.
The Board of Education has modified its voting procedure to record individual "ayes" and "nays" of members on all items that come before it, board officials said last night.
The Veterans Administration is preparing to distribute $300million in retroactive G.I. education benefits and says it hopes to deliver most of the 1.2 million checks by Christmas.
A fairly strong earthquake jolted a largely rural area along the California-Mexican border early today, shaking people awake and causing minor damage.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market continued their downward trend for the fifth straight session yesterday.

Hanging over the rails of the corral, the fifthgraders from P.S. 33 in Chelsea, Manhattan, held out handfuls of hay to the young steers and the little calf inside. Anthony Gonzales, Mark Lalljee, Chinhon Huang, Lisa Fischer, MarkKornegay and most of the others strained forward ardently, trying to pat or even touch the steamy-breathed animals.
Two youths under police surveillance attempted to rob the wife of the Pakistani Ambassador to the United Nations last night on an Upper East Side street.
The stock market fell sharply yesterday in heavier trading as more depressing economic news sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest closing level in more than 12 years.

John A. Clements, former public-relations director for the Hearst Corporation, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Hotel St. Mortiz, 50 Central Park South. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

A' dramatic reversal of fortune in the final session of the blue ribbon pair championship here last night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals ended the hopes of all the leading contenders.

Nancy June Conklin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard K. Conklin of Burlington, Vt., was married last evening to Dr. James A. Malcolm 3d of Burlington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Jr. of Jericho, L. I., and Pawlet, Vt. The Rev. Gary Kriss, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Pawlet.

A father attempted today to shift to his wife blame for the death of their 13-month-old son, who was found beaten to death in his playpen in their Nutley home last June.

The first crystalline flakes of the Christmas season "Nutcracker" cascade fluttered merrily down at the New York State Theater on Thursday. The New York City Ballet returned with its lush annual production of the children's classic, and now there are only 22 performances left until Christmas.

New York Deinocrats had the chance to compare their old and new leaders at a state party caucus last night here at the national midterm convention.

Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights, begins at sundown tomorrow and Jewish leaders drew a parallel yesterday between the ancient maccabees' quest for religious and political freedom with Israel's determination to remain secure.

To the Editor: Recent articles in The Times indicate that the New York State Education Department is reviewing Ph.D. programs and recommending that some be dropped, others be put on probation and still others given full endorsement.
Uganda's former Foreign Minister, Elizabeth Bagaaya, has been released from house arrest, according to- a Government statement issued here today.

Agostino Ferranta di Ruffano, a retired Italian diplomat who had served as Consul General in Boston, Philadelphia and Ottawa and had been Ambassador to Paraguay, died Wednesday at thehome of his son Roberto in Mendham, N. J. He was 89 years old.

Ethiopia's of military rulers today announced a shuffle of 14 top civilian and military posts, a move apparently aimed at purging opponents. New foreign and defense ministers and new commanders of the country's air force and national police were named.

Acknowledging that voluntary efforts to curb oil imports were not going as well as had been hoped, a White House spokesman said today that President Ford planned to announce new energy-conservation proposals next month.

Convinced that they had made a historic breakthrough toward co-operation and had achieved a detente between the American and National Leagues after decades of jealously guarded sovereignty, the major league club owners adjourned their annual winter meetings today with little to announce but much to anticipate.
Sargent Shriver said today that Alabama Governor George C. Wallace's paralysis from the waist down would present a handicap to his performnance as President.

Raymond S. Stites, for more than 20 years the curator of education at' the National Gallery of Art here and a leading scholar on Leonardo da Vinci, died today of a heart attack at his suburban Maryland home. He was 75 years old.

Wooster Street, a gray and grimy vestige of blue-collar Manhattan, carefully camouflages its emergence as something of a performing arts center of SoHo.

School principals and the district superintendent in Community School District 9 in the Bronx pledged loyalty yesterday to Chancellor Irving Anker's appointed trustee, but he remained locked out of the district's headquarters by parents and employes protesting his take-over.
Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the proposed new arms agreement with the Soviet Union would lead to larger strategic forces than previously planned by the United States.
Henry Wadsworth "the perennial juvenile" stage and screen actor, died Thursday in St Luke's Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.

Four men in their twenties, at least one of whom was armed with a gun, held up the passengers of a homewardbound commuter express bus last night on the Major Deegan Expressway and escaped with about $900 in cash and an estimated $2,100 in assorted jewelry, the police reported.

Harry S. Dent, White House tide under President Nixon, resigned today as general counsel to the Republican National Committee. Mr. Dent has been reported to be negotiating with the special Watergate prosecutor's office over a plea in connection with a secret political fund to Support candidates favored by Mr. Nixon.

The state today shut down shellfish beds off the coast of Cape May County because of pollution from raw sewage. The Environmental Protection Department said that this week's storm had damaged sewerage facilities.

Efforts by conservationists to block a sixday deer hunt scheduled to start Tuesday in the Great Swamp of Morris County failed today when a Federal District Court judge refused to grant an injunction preventing the hunt.
The deeper meaning of the Democratic mini-convention under way here may lie in the building where the 2,038 delegates have gathered.
President Isabel Martinez de Peron asked Congress today for broad powers to call up the armed forces to fight subversion and to set up a centralized national defense program under the presidency.

Palestinian guerrillas raided this kibbutz just south of the Lebanese border early today and wounded two Israelis. An Israeli soldier shot and wounded one of the terrorists and then burned him to death with a phosphorous grenade, an Israeli officer said.

One of Wall Street's chief spokesmen defended the industry here today against the strong attack made yesterday by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. The New Jersey Democrat charged that the industry had sabotaged the reform bill that would have ended price fixing.

Layoffs in a wide variety of industries were disclosed yesterday. Many of the announcements came almost simultaneously with the release by the Labor Department of November unemployment figures that showed the number of unemployed Americans had risen by 482,000 to a total of 5.98 million.
The Israel delegation to UNESCO today took strong issue with recent statements by the Paris-based organization attempting to play down actions taken against Israel.

Acknowledging that voluntary efforts to curb oil imports were not going as well as had been hoped, a White House spokesman said today that President Ford planned to announce new energy conservation proposals next month.
Two American outsiders, Debbie Austin and Judy Meister, broke the women's course record with 69's today for the opening-round lead in the Far East golf tournament.

A state appeals court ruled today that four former Jackson Township Committeemen accused of extortion have not been denied a speedy trial, though it has been nearly four years since they were first charged and tile case has still not gone to trial.

The British Government announced today, long-term plans to control the rate of oil production from the North Sea, but made it clear that it wanted to leave the exploration companies a return on investment sufficient to keep them active in the area.

Tony Aulisi's third placement kick provided unbeaten Brick Township High School with its 10th victory and the South Jersey Group 4 championship, a 21-20 triumph over Camden tonight before 5,200 at Convention Hall.

The two Soyuz-16 astronauts said today that they had completed their experiments in space to prepare for next July's linkup with an American Apollo crew and were about to start packing for their homeward journey.

Two Broadway productions, one long-lived and one shortlived, are closing. The all-male production of Shakespeare's "As You Like It," which opened at the Mark Hellinger Theater on Tuesday, will close tomorrow after eight performances.

A last-ditch effort is expected to be made next week by the House Agriculture Committee to keep the expiring Sugar Aci alive. According to industry reports yesterday, a three-or sixmonth extension is to be proposed in order to maintain existing quotas on sugar imports and subsidies to domestic sugar-growers.

Dr. Geoffrey H. Bourne, director of the Yerkes Primate Research Center in Atlanta, yesterday called off a scheduled televised discussion. of the controversial documentary "Primate" with its producer, Frederick Wiseman.

The elusive Bill Walton permitted the mystery of hisfuture to deepen yesterday, leaving club officials to wait until tomorrow to discover whether or not he will walk away from a $2-million contract.

With the figures rising day by day, the need is immediate for action by the Ford Administration and Congress to ease hardship and revive the job-generating potentialities of the economy.

A Rome court today acquitted an American newsman, Jack L. Begon of charges of having faked his own kidnapping. Mr. Begon, 63 years old, who formerly worked for the Rome bureau of the American Broadcasting Company, disappeared last year on July 22.
A 50-year-old woman was robbed and raped in a deserted section of the IND station at Jay Street in Brooklyn at 10 A.M. yesterday, the transit police reported.
The nation's unemployment rate shot up in November for the third consecutive month and reached 6.5 per cent of the labor force, the highest rate in 13 years, the Labor Department reported today.

Despite piclesting in at least four states by mine construction workers, the nation's 120,000 minars began trickling back to work today after their 25-day strike ended. Although some miners were still unhappy over terms of the new United Mine Wrokers contract, those companies that chose to open today reported turnouts of 50 to 80 per cent, which officials terms "normal" for the first day.
A strike by the orchestra of the New York City Ballet was averted yesterday after the musicians and management settled a "misunderstanding" about a contract negotiated a year ago.
The New York Nets starting five came alive in a 64-44 second half tonight and defeated an undermanned San Diego team, 113-92, in the Q-s first visit of the season to Nassau Coliseum.

Hundreds of students demonstrated against the administration of the State University Center at Stony Brook, L. I., dispersing at about 7 A.M., after two students were arrested following a pushing match with campus security officers. Some of the students' demands were met by the administration, according to Genald Manginelli, the president of Polity, the student government.
Ambrose J. Kennedy of 79-15 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, and a member of the Pratt Insitute staff for 20 years, died Wednesday at the Veteran's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.
The Federal Reserve Board said, today it would permite commereial banks to issue a new long-terr' consumer certificate of deposit paying up to 71/2'per cent interest a year.

For the first time, Temple Israel of the City of New York has named a woman to serve as its president. She is Eleanor S. May, a member of the board of trustees since 1967, a former vice president of the congregation and president of its Sisterhood from 1966 through 1970.

The Woolworth store at 44th Street and Broadway, a Times Square landmark for nearly 40 years, will close on Jan. 25 because it cannot afford the additional costs of a new lease, according to the F. W. Woolworth Company.

President Ford signed legislation yesterday amending the United States Legal Code to toughen a provision requiring disqualification of Federal judges in cases where they are shown to have a bias or conflict of interest.

Milk dealers and their striking employes were reported late yesterday to be close to an agreement on a new contract following the second day of the walkout, which has seen New Yorkers scurrying to buy diminishing milk supplies.

William T. Farr, a reporter who had been jailed for 46 days on contempt charges in connection with his reporting on the trial of Charles Manson, has come another step toward freedom from further imprisonment in the case.

Corporate bonds and Government securities staged a dynamic rally yesterday in their initial response to Friday's late reduction in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve.
In a 2 to 1 decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld today a desegregation and busing plan ordered for schools in Kalamazoo, Mich. in 1971.

Negotiators for the city's private nursing homes and its unionized employes reached a tentative contract settlement early today, thereby averting a srike that had been threatened for midnight last night.
Small companies have found that it has become increasingly difficult in this depressed period to maintain a market for their shares.

At least one of 18 bogus checks involved in an alleged scheme to defraud the city of Los Angeles of several million dollars through computer manipulation was cashed in New York, city officials said here today.
Ten European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced plans here today for arms increases next year to improve the military capacity of the alliance.

Three vulture-headed parrots from New Guinea went on display yesterday at the Bronx Zoo's World of Birds. The birds are called Pesquet's parrots and are among the most unusual parrot species.
Burton G. Philbrick, whose testing led to the use of cartons instead of bottles for the distribution of milk, died Saturday at a hospital in Salem. He was 93 years old.
Robert C. (Sonny) Carson, the black activist whose criminal past became the subject of a successful movie, was convicted in Mineola, L. I., along with four other men, of kidnapping.

Market reports suggesting that Persian Gulf oil-producing states were no longer willing to take sterling in payment for their stateowned oil drove the pound to historic lows today and forced the Bank of England to spend an estimated $250-million in an effort to support the currency.

Now, with the economy slithering deeper into recession, housing stuck deep in its slump, auto sales falling off "frighteningly," in the view of auto industry leaders, banks and businesses worrying about their

Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said today that President Ford was willing to negotiate a broader public service employment program with Congress but the President still insisted on a "trigger" mechanism to start and stop the ptogram when the unemployment rate reached specific levels.

Following the third riot in four months at the Felt Forum, the chairman of the State Athletic Commission warned Madison Square Garden last night that he would halt boxing at the Forum if there were one more disturbance there.
Not quite every National Football League question was answered by Monday night's 23-17 victory the Washington Redskins scored at Los Angeles, but many were.

Commodity futures were marked by dull trading on most exchanges yesterday, and there was little news or even rumors reported by commodity men as affecting their markets. Grains were relatively stable as traders awaited the crop report due after the close.

From the Jones-Hagen-Sarazen era into early 1974, Joe Dey Jr. was Golf's prime administrator, the "Mr. Golf" who supervised the big tournaments, who knew and worked with thousands of golfers, the great ones and the unknowns.

The police said yesterday that a 16-year-old youth who had spent almost all of his life in institutions for the mentally ill raped and mutilated a 20year-old girl in Crotona Park in the Bronx last Friday evening.

The Third Secretary of State of the African country of Sierra Leone was among 10 customers and sales personnel held up yesterday in a midtown clothing store by four gunmen who escaped with more than.$3,600 in cash and an undetermined amount of personal jewelry, the police reported.

Reports that the Persian Gulf oil-producing states would stop taking the pound sterling in payment for their oil touched off a run on the currency, driving the pound to historic lows. The Bank of England had to spend ai estimated $250-million in an effort to support the currency.It fell by more than 11/2 cents against the dollar to $2.3195. [Page 1, Column 5.]

A citizens commission called yesterday for the.appointment of an ombudsmanil and other measures to protecti the city's public school' puil{s: against corporal purnishmenft .and im-s proper suspensions.

Opening public hearings this week to help design a substantive national energy policy for the Ford Administration, Interior Secretary Morton touched on a pervasive myth when he asked, "How much conservation can the economy stand?"
The state will have to borrow some $38-million from the Federal Government to make its jobless benefits payments in January, the Labor and Industry Department said today.

Like statements Dy Leoma Brezhnev and Mao Tse-tung, the words of Joe Namath have become a hot subject for dissection and interpretation. But seldom have Soviet and Chinese watchers had as much fun poring over words as Namath watchers are having these days.

Contending that its members had been forced to absorb too much of the losses resulting from plummeting new car sales, a national association of Ford dealers called on the Ford Motor Company yesterday to cut wholesale car prices by hundreds of dollars to stimulate sales.

The prosecutor who tried the murder case of William R. Phillips knew one week before the verdict that a member of the jury had applied for a job in the District Attorney's Office but did not report it to the judge or defense attorneys, testimony in State Supreme Court disclosed yesterday.
The Soyuz 16 astronauts said today that their six-day flight went without a hitch and pronounced their improved spacecraft ready to rendezvous with' an American Apollo.

Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey brushed away a fly from a 16year-old youth whose hands were tied to the bed above his head-a mentally retarded hemophiliac who was being prevented from hitting himself. Then Mr. Carey had to flick the fly away again.

As an indication of today's uncertain economy Bobby Unser, the 1974 driving champion of the United States Auto Club and winner of the California 500 race, received a prize yesterday afternoon not in the form of

An appeals court ruled today that the historic Willard Hotel at 14th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue could have its interior torn out and its facade demolished in the course of remodeling it as an office building.

Officials of the milk industry and the striking teamsters union worked yesterday to devise a contract proposal that would be acceptable to a disgruntled membership that rejected a tentative pact last Sunday.

H. Malcolm Gillette, who had served 40 years with the Rockefeller Foundation, died yesterday in a hospital in Wakefield, R.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Wakefield and formerly lived in Tenafly, N.J.

BADMEN OF THE WEST. By Robert Elman. 256 pages. Illustrated. A Ridge Press/ Pound Book. $14.95. "Come and die. It will be great fun." This is what the English poet Rupert Brooke wrote home to his friends from the trenches in World War I-and this is the sort of spirit that several generations of Americans have attributed to the lawbreakers of the old Wild West.

Marian Knighton Bryan, who started the modern-dance program at Sarah Lawrence College in the nineteen-thirties, died Monday in New York Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 200 Boulder Trail in Bronxville, N. Y.

John Gordon, editor-in-chief of The Sunday Express, died last evening, He celebrated his 84th birthday the day before. Over the years Mr. Gordon was outspoken, forceful, ironic and often amusing in his comments on the world scene and its application to Britain.
New York City's Joffrey Ballet received a tumultous ovation here tonight when it opened a seven-performance modern-dance engagement in the Operetta Theater.

Congress gave final approval today to only 18 per cent of a multi- million - dollar spending cutback proposed by President Ford as an anti-inflationary move and directed him to spend the rest of the funds.

At the age of 29, Thomas Pasatieri has composed 11 operas, including a one-act comedy, "Signor Deluso," which is currently on a double bill at the Manhattan Theater Club along with Holst's "Savitri," also a oneact work.
Dr. Walter G. Cady, professor emeritus of physics at Wesleyan University, died Monday in an East Providence. (R. I.) nursing home on the eve of his 100th birthday.

Criticizing what he termed "the hodgepodge of bank regulation as it has evolved in this country, John E. Sheehan, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, yesterday supported the idea of a single Federal banking regula tory agency.
Gumermo vilas toppled John Newcombe today, 6-4, 7-6, in the opening round of the $100,000 Commercial Union Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament.
Spain's biggest real-estate investment and tourist promotion company appears to be on the point of collapse after suspending payments both to employes and investors.

One of the five gunmen who robbed the Sherry-Netherland Hotel Monday of jewels, cash and travelers' checks, now estimated to be worth $300,000, left behind a white vinyl glove, the police said yesterday.

In the last 10 years an average of 1,200 persons a day have been hired for public jobs. Almost all of the growth was at the state and local level, making state-local government the fastest-growing segment of the nation's work force.

Deere Co., a major agricultural equipment maker and producer of construction and industrial equipment, reported yesterday 13.4 per cent increase in net income for its fourth quarter ended Oct. 31. The report also noted, however, that annual earnings were off 2.5 per cent despite record sales.

Mayor Beame is expected tc announce today the dismissal of 3,000 more city workers, including an estimated total of 400 members of the city's three uniformed services and 125 high-level appointed provisional employes.

Opera productions in this modern age have long gestation periods. Plans for the "Boris Godunov" that the Metropolitan Opera is presenting Monday night date three years, from the present Bliss-Chapin regime back through the Chapin regimeito the Gentele regime.
Minnie W, Boehm, a former pianist who had accompanied a number of performers, died yesterday at her home. She was 89 years old and lived at 179 East 79th Street.
Japan's new. Premier, Takeo Miki, moved Ion several economic frontsit.today but ran immediately into skepticism and opp6sltion from within the ruling Lestablishment.

Terence Rattigan's play "In Praise of Love," which opened at the Morosco Theater last night, is sentimental, facile and inconclusive, but it does. have Rex Harrison and Julie Harris being 'their customary charming selves, which may well be enough for some theatergoers.
A court-martial today began trying the first of some 170 former Ethiopian officials and military leaders held in the cellars of the Grand Palace.

Walt Frazier took on the Kansas City-Omaha Kings in the second half last night and the Knicks' winning streak grew to six games. The Knick captain scored a season high of 34 points, 27 in the second half when New York roared back from an 11-point,

PARTICIPANTS--Local 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing 3,000 drivers and plant employes who process and deliver milk to 10 million consumers in the metroDolitan New York area.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is scheduled to submit salary demands today in its contract dispute with the city. The association had been seeking an end to the parity system whereby they get the same pay as firemen, and under which sanitationmen get 90 per cent of the other two.

Wayne Woodrow Hayes, architect of young manhood, student of military history and defender of the old-time faith, held a press conference yesterday. Nobody explained why. However, Ohio State's football coach was in New York for last night's dinner of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame and tomorrow night's presentation of the Heisman Trophy to the' Ohio State tailback, Archie Griffin,

PARADES. SHALL FOLLOW, a play created by Gary Nebiol and Donald Mar cus, written by Donald Marcus. Setting by Kert Lundelt; lighting by Michael. Watson; production stage manager, William Yaggy; technical director, Steve Crowley. Presented by the Ensemble Studio Theater, Curt Dempster, director. Jerry Zacks, producer, at 549 West 52d Street.

Cities and businesses across the country are lighting up for the holidays this year, after a Christmas cutback in 1973 prompted by the energy crisis. "We're back with lights this year," said a spokesman for Rich's Department store in Atlanta, which cut back its decorations last year.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger warned the Atlantic allies today against any stampede to cut back military strength for economic reasons on the supposition that American power would be sufficient to protect them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)--Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California, contended today that illegal ailens were "the greatest single factor in the economic recession" on the ground that they were taking 1.2 million jobs from American citizens.

A natural gas industry spokesman told Government officials today their effort to cut oil consumption 1 million barrels per day would slow the economy about 3 per cent and impose austerity on the nation.
The Department of Justice reinstituted antitrust suits today against the three national television networks, charging them with monopolizing evening programing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--President Ford is being criticized severely and sometimes even savagely these days. Even his supporters are giving him what Damon Runyon used to call a "medium hello." But in fairness, there is another side to the Ford story, which has to be balanced alongside the charges against him.

Nelson G. Gross, former New Jersey Republican chairman, asked a three-judge panel of the Federal Court of Appeals in Philadelphia to overturn his conviction earlier his year on charges of criminally masking, as a Federal tax deduction, a $5,000 contribution to the 1969 election campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill.
Dr. Joseph G. Hoffman, a scientist who helped develop the atomic bomb in World War II and later did cancer research, died here Sunday at him home. He was 65 years old.

The Senate delayed again today its consideration of the sweeping Administration trade reform bill, but despite approaching Congressional adjournment the legislation still is given a fair chance of passage. Once the bill reaches the floor its fate will depend, according to numerous Congressional sources,
The General Assembly's Legal Committee recommended today that proposals for United Nations action against international terrorism be put off for consideration for another year.
Last April the American Management Association's session on in-house advertising agencies attracted some 60 interested parties. The current three-day seminar has 16.

Stock prices staged a strong rally yesterday, buoyed by expectations of Government action to combat the deepening recession. Analysts noted that the advance reflected the growing convictions of investors and traders that President Ford would announce new stimulative programs for the economy in an address at 9 o'clock tonight.

The Pentagon announced plans today to abolish the Air Force's Pacific Command. The action is the latest in a series of moves designed to trim the number of military headquarters in the United States and abroad to save manpower and money.

Leaders of the nine European Common Market countries ended their two-day conference here tonight with a declaration reflecting moves toward compromise on the key issues of oil diplomacy and the terms of Britain's membership.

Interior Minister Ahmed Medeghri died here today at his home after what an official bulletin called "a tragic accident." He was 40 years old. Mr. Medeghri joined the Algerian liberation movement at the outset of the war against France in 1954.

The National Gallery of Art canceled the press preview today of an exhibition of Chinese archeological finds rather than agree to Peking's demand that Chinese Nationalist, South Korean, South African and Israeli newsmen be barred.
Rockets fired today from automobiles parked in crowded streets here caused heavy damage to three offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but- only minor injuries were reported.

The I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, Inc., the nation's largest baker of bread, was accused by the government today of attempting to monopolize the wholesale baking business through the use of a large number of illegal predatory practices.

Krishan Bhatia, an Indian newspaperman and author, died Monday in Washington, where he was correspondent for The Hindustan Times of New Delhi. He was 49 years old and lived in Sumner, Md.

Food prices are likely to continue to rise at an annual rate of 15 per cent, at least through the first half of next year, and the outlook could be worse if another year of bad weather should hamper crop production, a top economist at the Department of Agriculture said today.

From all accounts, the Administration's decision on the level and purposes of this country's food assistance program for the coming year is finally to be made this week. Along with budgetary questions affecting aid levels, there is a debate within the Administration which, roughly stated, is between those who want American food aid to be used for political purposes and those who want it to be used for humanitarian purposes.
Valentin Moroz, an imprisoned Ukrainian historian, has ended a 20-week hunger strike after Soviet authorities promised to improve his prison conditions, family sources said here today.

The New York Stock Exchange hinted strongly before the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it was prepared to fight in the courts to keep fixed brokerage commission rates unless the switch to negotiated rates is accompanied by safeguards for the exchange's auction-market system.

While Americans are being urged to eat less grain-fed meats in order to free grain for the world's hungry millions a companion grain-saving measure has been suggested that hits at another American institution --alcohol.

A Federal grand jury indicted a South African company and two United States companies today on charges of conspiring illegally to fix prices and allocate customers and territory for sales of industrial diamond abrasives.
Efforts by backers of the Federal strip-nine control bill to get it finally passed by the House of Representatives before Congress'adjourns in about 10 days suffered a further setback today.
Rudy Hackett pumped in 25 points and Chris Sease added 17 tonight as unbeaten Syracuse downed St. John's. 75-66, for its fourth college basketball triumph. The Redmen have a 2-2 wonlost mark.

BOSTON-I have in mind one night in 1965. Becky and I had parked my old VW and we were walking up the side of Beacon Hill. All year long, we had been working, though in different ways, within the black community of Boston:

A physician testified here today that he had found multiple bruises all over the body of Charles Pernasiiice, a defendant in the Attica prison rebellion trials who contended that he had been beaten senseless by jail guards earlier in the day.

Drawing an outburst of cheers from antitextbook forces, Elmer Fike, owner f -a chemicalplant, told a 'Nati'nil Education Association research panel today that disputed school books would trigger "a breakdown.,of, the American svstek."

Former Gov. Tim M. Babcock of Montana pleaded guilty today to allegations that he illegally channeled $54,000 from a millionaire oilman, Dr. Armand Hammer, into President Nixon's political treasury in 1972 and, 1973.
Negotiations for full nationalization of the Arabian American Oil Company by Saudi Arabia were suspended here today, and no plans for a resumption were announced.

The House Ways and Means Cornmittee approved legislation today that would make some of the interest on savings accounts tax-exempt, But it also paved the way for its bill to be amended on the floor of the House.

PARIS, Dec. 10--Leaders of the nine European Common Market countries ended their two-day conference here tonight with a declaration reflecting moves toward compromise on the key issues of oil diplomacy and the terms of Britain's membership.

A Federal judge today dismissed 7 of 11 counts against Joseph M. McCrane, former Treasurer of New Jersey who is on trial here on tax fraud-conspiracy charges. Judge William J. Nealon Jr., presiding at the trial of Mr. McCrane, told the jurors that they would be asked only to determine Mr. McCrane's guilt or innocence on the remaining four counts of the indictment.

Retail sales continued to sag in November, a preliminary Commerce Department estimate disclosed today. On a seasonally adjusted basis, sales in November were down 1 per cent from October. The cumulative decline from the August peak was 3.2 per cent.

It was 9 A.M., an hour when most high school students are bent over their desks, pens poised, noses buried in their textbooks. But yesterday about 1,000 Bronx teen-agers went to a Manhattan movie theater, where many of them were bent over the candy counter, munching popcorn and sipping soft drinks.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia--This is the time of the sacred hajj, the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, and hundreds of thousands are thronging through this Red Sea port to the birthplace of the Prophet Mohammed.

The Xerox Company said today it would shut down its Webster, N. Y., manufacturing facility and secondary equipment refurbishing and machine conditioning centers elsewhere in the United States, laying off 6,000 workers.

The first agreement between the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the Soviet Union's new Copyright Agency obligating the Russians to pay royalties for live performances of American music was signed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Administration announced today that it was prepared to renounce most military uses of tear gas and herbicides to obtain Senate approval of the 1925 Geneva protocol banning chemical and bacteriological warfare.

According to the records, Mary Lou Williams is now 64 years old. Seeing her at the Cookery, University Place and Eighth Street, where she is playing piano Mondays through Saturday to Jan. 23, this seems unlikely and, on hearing her, it is obviously beside the point.

Nearly three-fourths of the Senate today sent President Ford a letter saying that United Nations support for the Palestine Liberation Organization undermined the world body as well as American foreign policy.

The State Senate will vote Thursday on a 5 per cent state tax on Federal income taxes. The tax-only on income earned in New Jersey-would raise $282-million to finance a new system of financing public schools.

Few noticed and those who did averted their eyes as a major milestone in the history of this embattled island passed by today without commemorative speeches, editorials or public recognition of any kind.
Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn took possession today of the Nobel 4 Prize for Literature that he was unable to claim when it was. awarded to him four years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10-The Senate approved today the nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller to be Vice President, by a vote of 90 to 7.

Fifteen bandits including three women, robbed two banks of $200,000 today, killing five policemen and wounding two, the authorities said. The raiders, in stocking masks, signed "CommandoAlfonso Rojas Dias, 23d of September Communist League," a police spokesman said.
President Ford held an unusual session here yesterday with key associates of Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller to hear their views on world energy, raw-material and food problems.

Demonstrators hurled rocks and bottles when Eisaku Sato, the former Japanese Vrime Minister, arrived at Oslo University to receive the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize today in a ceremony attended by Sing Olav of Norway.

Julia Coopersmith, whose Soviet relatives left Philadelphia after two months and two days, said yesterday that the couple had found it difficult to learn English and to adapt to the American way of life.

Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey announced yesterday that he would visit Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo tomorrow to discuss the fiscal problems of those cities with their Mayors and other public officials.
Manuel Komroff, novelist and writer, died yesterday in Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N.Y. He was 84 years old, and lived in nearby Woodstock.
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a creditor can repossess goods purchased on installments without granting the buyer any formal court hearing.
Lady Wilkins, widow of Sir Hubert Wilkins, the Australian polar explorer by plane and submarine, died Sunday in the Orange View Convalescent Home in Anaheim, Calif. She was 73 years old.

As an indication of today's uncertain economy Bobby Unser, the 1974 driving champions of the United States Auto Club and winner of the California 500 race, received a prize yesterday afternoon not in the form of a check or cash,

John D. Ehrlichman, testifying in his own defense, continued today to implicate former President Richard M. Nixon in the Watergate cover-up. He did so quietly and at times sadly, breaking down at one point and crying as he told how Mr. Nixon asked him last year to resign.

District Attorney William Cahn of Nassau County said today that he had used $18,000 in expense money given to him over the last five years by the National District Attorneys Association to pay a confidential informer.
Judge John M. Hanrahan of the Connecticut Common Pleas Court died yesterday of a heart attack while walking near his home. He was 57 years old and lived at 112 Michael Road.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., expects lower earnings in 1974 despite at least a 15 per cent Increase in sales, the chairman of the giant chemical maker, Irving Shapiro, told analysts today.
PARIS--Sandwiched between summit meetings and diplomatic negotiations, this week is supposed to mark significant events in the 25-year-old North Atlantic alliance.
Gov. George C. Wallace called today for the creation of a national Democratic primary "to let the people decide" the party's 1976 Presidential nominee.

In what Nassau County Excutive Ralph G. Caso called a move reflecting the county's deepening financial crisis, he said yesterday that he was giving up his cabana at Nassau Beach, his county-owned chauffeured limousine and $2,500 of his $60,000 annual salary. The cabana, which would rent for about $400 a year, according to Mr. Caso,

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, relinquished today the chairmanship of the House Ways and Means Committee that he has held since 1958. House Democrats began making good on promises to name younger Congressmen to important committees.

The Vatican expressed "pain and grief" today at the sentencing by an Israel Court of the Most Rev. Hilarion Capucci, Greek Catholic Archbishop of East Jerusalem, for smuggling arms to Palestinians. The Vatican statement said:

More than 125 hunters moved out across the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge here this morning to kill deer, only minutes after a three-judge Federal Appeals Court panel in Philadelphia denied a bid by conservationists for a ban on the hunt.

The, State Senate will vote Thursday on a 5 per cent state tax on Federal income taxes. The tax-only on income earned in New Jersey-would raise $282-million to finance a new system of financing public schools. The State Supreme.
Joseph E. Dynan, a longtime foreign correspondent for The Associated Press, died today at the American Hospital in suburban Neuilly. He was 62 years old.
Henry Schlenger, co-founder of the R S Auto Accessory chain stores in New Jersey, died Monday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in West Orange, N. J.

Terence Cardinal Cooke was singing, smiling gently, looking through steel-rimmed glasses, and offering a rendition of "Love Makes the World Go Round." He was doing it in a voice that was neither tenor nor baritone,

In 1952, exactly twenty years before the 1972 Presidential campaign, Richard Nixon's political career was threatened by the disclosure of a secret slush fund which he, as General Eisenhower's Vice-Presidential running mate, had established with the help of some personal friends and supporters. Mr. Nixon survived the charges then leveled against him, not by disproving them but by diverting public attention with the demagogic triumph of the Checkers speech.

The House today passed a bill authorizing $2-billion in Federal loan guarantees for the nation's railroads and sent it to the Senate for further action. If a conference with the Senate can be arranged quickly, the bill could be passed before this session of Congress adjourns at the end of next week.
Halting a six-session-slide prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed in stepped-up trading yesterday In the over-the-counter market Prices were higher also in in creased trading.
Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that a Federal audit of the city's $5-million youth job training program would be completed and "open for discussion" by the end of the month.

The State Environmental Protection Department approved 10 outdoor recreation projects today that will generate up to 300 new jobs through more than $2-million in construction.
The New Jersey Legislature, struggling to meet a State Supreme Court deadline of Dec. 31 to find a more equitable way of financing public schools, finds itself with plenty of company.

South Vietnamese casualties rose to a total of more than 2,000 today in the fifth day of intensified fighting, the Saigon command reported. The command said that 325 Government soldiers had been killed and 1,374 wounded and that 320 were missing, most of them in the Mekong Delta,
Edmond H. Booth, a Dartmouth College professor emeritus, died at his home here. He was 79 years old. Professor Booth taught English at Dartmouth from 1920 until his retirement in 1962.

Three young boys who pursued a robber were among 29 civilians who were presented at Police Headquarters yesterday with commendation certificates and bar-type badgs for "outstanding acts of heroism in going to the aid of police officers."
The Federal Reserve Board granted approval today to Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, of the nation's fourth largest bank, to acquire the Ritter Financial Corporation of Wyncote, Pa.
Randy Smith and Garfield Heard led a third-quarter rally that helped the Buffalo Braves -gain a 101-91 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
Compromise legislation to continue five health programs and to establish several new ones, including a national research effort to combat rape, was approved today by the House.

An administrative law judge of the Federal Communications Commission, in an initial decision yesterday, granted WPIX, Inc., the renewal of its license to operate on Channel 11 here and disqualified the application of the challenging group,

The I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, Inc., the nation's largest baker of bread, was accused by the government today of attempting to monopolize the wholesale baking business through the use-of a large number of illegal predatory practices.

Congress today approved a program to accelerate the testing of atomic weapons before a new atomic-test treaty with the Soviet Union went into effect, but provided less than half the money requested by the Administration.

The ?? at community School District 9's offices in the Bronx ended after six days yesterday as a State Supreme Court justice issued an injunction against the protest and as its' leader conceded that she did not "see any purpose" in continuing it.

Representatives of 26 national organizations that support the equal rights amendment announced today that they had picked 10 states in which to concentrate their ratification efforts, under a plan drawn up for them by one of the nation's most successful political consultant companies.

A compromise was reached today in a dispute over opposition demands that the Government publish the results of an inquiry into charges that a Cabinet minister and a member of Parliament from the governing Congress party were involved in an import-license scandal.

A tentative contract agreement for 4,000 striking mine construction workers raised hopes yesterday that the country's coal production would be back in full swing next week for the first time in a month.

The Whirlpool Corporation announcedd yesterday that directors had approved a change an accounting for substantially ill of its inventories to the ast-in, first-out (LIFO) method rom the first-in, first-out FIFO) basis for the year 1974;
Seven years after the Government tried him on charges of refusing to be drafted into the Army, Government officials, including the President, greeted Muhammad Ali in Washington yesterday.

A surprise witness yesterday to at a hearing on a plan to build an a 52-story hotel and office tic building behind the landmark Villard Houses was a greatgrandson of Henry Villard, the railway magnate, for whom the Italian Renaissance brown- ye stones were built in 1886.

Contradicting his previous testimony, the chief witness for the prosecution in the trial of Martin Ginsberg, a suspended family court judge, said today that the defendant-who was then an assemblyman-had returned $5,000 of an alleged $7,500 bribe.

The New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union assailed today the use of hollow-nose bullets and "unjustifiable deadly force" in the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old high school junior by tile Long Branch police early Sunday morning.

Eight of the 26 Democrats in the State Senate yesterday indicated a preference for himself to be the next minority leader, With the job apparently now wide open and all aspirants vowing to avoid a repetition of the long and embarrassing leadership fight of 1965,
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia-This is the time of the sacred hajj, the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, and hundreds of thousands are thronging through this Red Sea port to the birthplace of the Prophet Mohammed.

Christmas parties aren't just for people. At least not as far as members of the Friends of the Zoo are concerned. They're holding "A Christmas Party in Central Park Zoo" Saturday from 1 to 4:30 P.M. and the event's almost as much for the residents of Central Park Zoo and the Lehman Children's Zoo as it is for the children who drop by.

City officials were sharply criticized yesterday for proposing to allocate $380-millionone-fifth of the 1975-76 capital budget of $1.79-billion-for architectural design, planning and other staff expenses when almost nothing will be available to start new building projects.

The striking deliverers and the milk industry agreed yesterday to provide milk for hospitals, nursing homes, day-care centers and schools to the degree that they are able, reopening three processing plants to provide the milk.

The recent crash of an airliner into a hillside west of Washington has brought a Government decision that will require the nation's airlines to install in all jets a cockpit warning device that most exerts believe would have prevented the disaster.
