One avenue of needed help for New York and other hard-pressed cities is being opened in Washington. President Ford and the Democratic-controlled Congress are now moving more or less in tandem on a vastly expanded program of public service employment, with the double purpose of stimulating the economy and easing joblessness.

Plaguec by steady decreases in natural gas allotments, South Jersey's principal supplier of gas petitioned the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for rate increases that could reach as much as 42 per cent.
A partial eclipse of the sun will be visible tomorrow in New York and, to varying degrees, in most of the United States.

European officials expressed gratification today over the ease with which leaders of the European Common Market countries had agreed this week on a series of measures to strengthen the market's institutions.

Just about the best parties in town are the ones given by the Metropolitan Museum Cinderella doesn't have to watch the clock, the guest list is ideally inventive, the food and drink are far better than one might expect, and the show is usually good enough to make people say, "I'll come back tomorrow."
After a day-long debate stemming from increased terrorism in England by the Irish Republican Army, the House of Commons tonight rejected a move to restore the death penalty.
The official in charge of the New York State lottery reported yesterday that creation of a $250,000 top weekly prize had increased ticket sales by about $1-million in one week.

Madison Square Garden opens its 41st season of'intercollegiate basketball tonight with an attractive double-header in which Manhattan plays Rutgers ' after Seton Hall opposes St. Bonaventure in the first game beginning at 7 o'clock.

The preservation of undeveloped areas with ecological significance - including moraines, major wetlands, stream valleys and headwaters - was among the recommendations presented here tonight at the first of three hearings on a draft of the overall policies sections of the Brookhaven Master Plan.

A New York Daily News photographer, Dan Farrell, was named yesterday winner of the top prize of $250 in the New York Racing Association's annual photo journalism contest.
Two guards and a prison medical corpsman were released unharmed tonight after being held captive for 26 hours by eight inmates in a cellblock of the Walpole state prison.
Pledges to endow two $750, 000 chairs at Barnard College were accepted by the college's board of trustees last night. Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger gave one of the chairs in honor of her parents,
Roy Campanella, former Brooklyn Dodgers catcher, is among 14 persons who will be inducted into the Black Athletes Hall of Fame at Caesers Palace in Las Vegas on March 13, it was announced yesterday.
Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corpbration, said yesterday he remained "rather optimistic" concerning his company's operations in 1975.

A move by Sports Illustrated magazine to have the $2.25-million damage suit brought by Joe Namath of the New York Jets thrown out of State Supreme Court was heard yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer. He reserved decision.
A pianist who takes first prize in the Naumberg Competition, as Andre-Michel Schub did this year, is on the face of it a gifted instrumentalist.

Sylvia Dlugasch Bauman, for many years a therapist with the Child Development Center here and a clinical instructor in psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died yesterday at her home, 300 Erskine Road, Stamford, Conn.

Tim Sheeby scored a pair of goals on the only two shots he had in the first period to lead the New England Whalers to a 3-1 victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints
Price decreases for many cuts of red meat reduced the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City by 0.3 per cent last week, the City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

President Ford predicted today that the House would vote overwhelmingly next week. to confirm Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President, although the President said that there could be "as many as a hundred" votes against the nominee.

The nearly 4,000 new layoffs ordered by Mayor Beame yesterday represent a painful but necessary response to the gravity of the city's fiscal crisis. The harsh fact is that, even when added to the first round of layoffs last month, the savings they represent fall far short of what has to be done to avert disastrous new recourse to borrowing in a money market already saturated with New York City obligations.

Elmer L. Nicholson, who last May opposed the Loews Corporation's take-over of the CNA Financial Corporation only to see Loews succeed in its bid late last month, yesterday resigned his posts as CNA's chairman, president and chief executive officer. He resigned also as a director.
Stock prices finished higher yesterday for the second consecutive session in active trading, although some of the earlier gains were trimmed during the Afternoon.

The city's three-year old Comprehensive Health Planning Agency came under fire from the City Planning Commission yesterday for asserted failure to grapple with such pressing problems as poor. distribution of hospital beds, improper placement of nursing homes, and community unrest over the location of domiciliary care facilities.

Two men were indicted by a Cook County grand jury and a third man was charged in a criminal complaint today in connection with illegal dogfighting in Chicago's southwestern suburbs.

The Social Register, New York, 1975, is on the way to its subscribers, and in it are Caroline and John F. Kennedy Jr., listed for the first time, as juniors under the name of their stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Aristotle Onassis.

A 28-year-old man wio fatally beat a 75-year-old woman in the course of a $17 robbery committed within five weeks his parole from prison after serving four years for a similar, but nonfatal, assault has been convicted of murder and other crimes by a Bronx jury.
Three brothers of the President, Thomas, Richard and James Ford, represented him yesterday at the dedication of the Gerald R. Ford Freeway, the first public facility to be named for him.

A crisis of confidence in the British pound gripped foreign-exchange markets today as sterling weakened anew following the disclosure that Saudi Arabia no longer desired to receive any portion of her oil payments in British currency.

Two former officers of the Stirling Homex Corporation were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Rochester, on criminal charges of making payoffs to seven carpenter union officials in violation of the Taft-Hartley Law.
Motorola, Inc., said today that it would lay off 1,550 employes at semiconductor plants in Phoenix, Ariz, in the next 10 days.

The deputy prosecutor in the murder trial of William R. Phillips, a former police officer, testified yesterday that there had been no attempt to cover up the fact that a juror on the panel had applied for a job in the District Attorney's office.

Genevieve de Virel Wisner, wife of the executive director of the State Department's Bureau of Public Affairs, died of cancer last night at the National Institutes of Health. She was 33 years old.

Premier Constantine Caramanlls told the Greek people tonight that they faced a year of austerity and sacrifice as his new Government tried to battle the problems of inflation and stagnant industrial growth.

City schools and day-care centers began receiving emergency milk deliveries yesterday as negotiators for the milk industry and its striking workers continued to grope for a formula to settle the seven-day-old walkout.

Ralph Kiner, former National League home run king who is 'eligible for election for the last time, heads a list of 37 ex-players appearing on baseball Hall of Fame ballots mailed yesterday to voting members of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

Mayor Beame formally dedicated the Urban Academy yesterday as a training school for civil servants and predicted it would make the city bureaucracy "more responsive, more responsible, more efficient and more effective."
President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ordered the release of 622 of the 5,234 people arrested since he proclaimed martial law in September, 1972.

Paul Richards, who had important roles in several television shows, died yesterday of cancer. He was 50 years old. He leaves his wife, Monica; his mother, Edith Grossman, and a sister, Mrs. Howard Gluck.

Senator James L. Buckley of New York, a Conservative-Republican, and Eugene J. McCarthy, a former Senator from Minnesota and a liberal Democrat, announced today that they would jointly challenge the constitutionality of this year's Campaign Reform Act.

Ancorp National Services, Inc., said yesterday that its plan for repayment of about $50-million of debt has received approval from a major'ity of its creditors.

The House Democratic and Republican leaderships named to the Ways and Means Committee today 16 new members who are collectively far more liberal and urban oriented than the current panel.

Premier Takeo Miki of Japan indicated today that his new Government would be unable to hold consumer-price increases down to a critical target set by the previous government, thus risking heightened economic and political troubles.

Premier Jacques Chirac of France will visit Iran from Dec. 21 to 23 to start a giant economic and industrial cooperation program that will include construction of five nuclear power plants, it was announced today.

A Federal judge refused to order immediate processing today of a pardon application from a paroled bank robber who cited former President Richard M. Nixon's pardon as a' precedent for his lawsuit.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger today championed tactical nuclear weapons as indispensable to the defense of Western Europe and reportedly blocked a Dutch proposal that the weapons be de-emphasized.

GOD'S FAVORITE, a comedy by Nell Simon. Directed by Michael. Bennett; settings by William Ritman; costumes by Joseph G. Aullsi; lighting by Tharon Musser; production stage manager, Tom Porter. Presented by Emanuel Azenberg and Eugene V. Wolsk. At the Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street.

The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today legislation that would provide for several hundred thousand federally financed jobs for the unemployed and make up to three million other workers eligible for unemployment compensation.
President Ford conceded tonight that "the economy is in difficult straits," but he declared that he had no intention of introducing any major new antirecession programs.

Racial violence linked to the school busing controversy erupted in South Boston today as a white youth was stabbed by a black in a high school corridor. South Boston schools were closed down and hundreds of whites battled with the police.
The investigation into the plot to defraud the Los Angeles city treasury of several million dollars has been extended to New York and Europe.

Two widely used. mild tranquilizers may cause serious birth defects if the drugs are taken during the first six weeks of pregnancy; according to the findings of an extensive study published yesterday.

Joseph H. Brown, who retired in 1960 as Eastern regional manager of the Linde Air Products division of the Union Carbide Corporation after 40 years with the company, died Tuesday evening at the home of his daughter, Audrey Bollet, in Sands Point, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

Students and workers roamed the streets of Rangoon, the Burmese capital, this morning, setting fire to public buildings. They withdrew when the Governmente sent convoys of troops to back a declaration eof martial law, a United States Embassy official there reported.

Knight-Ridder Newspapers, Inc., is planning advertising and circulation rate increases in the range of 10 per cent next year. Lee Hills, chairman and chief executive of the newly merged company, told financial analysts here yesterday.

The 13-year-old boy accused of the murder last weekend of 7-year-old Danielle Hunter of Rockaway Township was committed to the State Diagnostic Center..in Menlo Park for psychiatric and neurological testing for at least 90 days. Judge Kenneth MacKenzie of Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court also ruled at a hearing in Morristown that psychiatrists appointed by the prosecution and defense could examine the suspect.

An analysis of family budgets over the last six years indicates that an urban .family of four now needs about $18,200 a year to maintain a "comfortable" standard of living, the Conference Board said yesterday.

About 8,500 Turkish Cypriotes, shivering in unheated tents in this British military base area in the south of Cyprus, represent a critical issue in the tense relations between the Greek and Turkish communities and a vexing problem for British diplomacy.

Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that his appointees would be required to disclose all income sources, assets and liabilities during their service, and he pressed Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, the next likely Speaker, to have the Legislature do the same.
A study of electricity conservation has found that the way for the individual household to make the biggest energy saving is to reject such modern marvels as electric can openers and electric knives.

Kuwait has no plans to bar the use of sterling in oil operations, the Kuwaiti Finance and Oil Minister, Abdel Rahman Salem al-Atiqi, said today.

Smith of Rhodesia announced yesterday an immediate cease-fire after years of fighting with black nationalists on the northern border, the immediate release of all detained black Rhodesian leaders and followers, and a conference to be held on how the overwhelming black majority can enter the Government.
An unofficial recount completed today showed Republican Senator Milton R. Young the winner over his Democratic challenger, William L. Guy, by 186 votes in the North Dakota Senate race.

A Senate-House conference committee reached agreement today on a modified version of a bill extending the life of the ExportImport Bank for four years.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reaffirmed today its previous decision that could require busing of school children between Louisville and its suburban areas.

Governor Byrne signed legislation today that designated Nov. 11 as Armistice Day. The Governor initially vetoed a similar bill but bowed to pressure from veterans groups that wanted the holiday restored to its traditional place on the calendar.

Denis E. Dillon, the Democratic District Attorney-elect of Nassau County, said today that upon taking office he would investigate allegations of doublebilling that have been made against William Cahn, the incumbent prosecutor.

A twice-robbed manager of Lundy's Restaurantin Brooklyn held scores of policemen at bay with a shotgun yesterday morning, apparently mistaking them for masked gunmen who had tried to hold him up earlier in the day.

The nomination of Robert C. Seamans Jr. to be chief of the new Energy Research and Development Administration was approved today by the Senate Interior Committee and the Joint Atomic Energy Committee.

A judge of the Federal District Court declined today to order the Charleston area medical center to drop its policy forbidding abortions. The judge, Dennis R. Knapp, said the hospital was a private one and it would not be legal to force it to follow guidelines governing public hospitals.

The Senate voted 68 to 27 today to extend United States fishing rights from 12 to 200 miles off shore, but the bill apparently is already doomed in the House of Representatives. President Ford opposes it, and Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Fisheries subcommittee, has said he would not call it up for action this year.

The layoffs announced yesterday in the Police Department will be the first since the turn of the century, a spokesman said, but, they are expected to have little immediate impact on the public, primarily because they include only slightly more than 1 per cent of the 30,900-man force.

"Environmental dangers inevitably trail after oil, wherever and however it is transported," a recent joint report by three Senate committees points out. This often-ignored truth is underscored by the emerging news of a catastrophic oil spill which occurred on Aug. 9 in the storm-swept Strait of Magellan off the southern tip of South America.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has purchased the television rights for a $100,000 professional mile at the Houston Astrodome' next year, thus moving the race one step closer to the starting line.

Smith of Rhodesia announced yesterday an immediate cease-fire after years of fighting with black nationalists on the northern border, the immediate release of all detained black Rhodesian leaders and followers, and a. conference to be held on how the overwhelming black majority can enter the Government.

The Supreme Court refused this week to relax any further the constitutional requirement that official searches and seizures be conducted pursuant to a Courtapproved warrant. In view of the Court's recent history, this is good news.
Chile's military Government expropriated yesterday the investments of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in the Chilean Telephone Company.

The eighth group home for adolescent children, the first in Manhattan, was opened yesterday by the city at 107 West 85th Street. It will be the home for 10 girls between the ages of 12 and 18 who have been committed to the city's care for reasons that include a lack of parents, who cannot cope with them, school difficulties because of behavior or learning disabilities and court committal.

The official in charge of the New York State lottery reported yesterday that creation of a $250,000 top weekly prize had increased ticket sales by about $1-million in one week. Tomorrow's drawing will be the first at which the so-called colossus prize will be awarded.

The State Health Department requested today that its budget next year be increased by $5.4million for a total expenditure of $24.9-million. Without the additional funds, the state will have to eliminate 15 programs, Health Commissioner Dr. Joanne Finley said.
Hilton Hotels Corporation in Beverly Hills, California has agreed to sell a 50 per cent interest in six of its hotels to the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $83.35-million.

Butch Goring scored a second-period shorthanded goal and set up Danny Maloney with a first-period goal to help the Los Angeles Kings defeat. the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-1, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Sean Connery and Michael Caine will co-star In the film version of Rudyard Kipling's short story "The Man Who Would Be King," which will be co-produced and distributed by Allied Artists and Columbia Pictures.

Racial violence linked to the school busing controversy erupted in South Boston today as a white youth was stabbed by a black in a high school corridor. South Boston schools were closed down and hundreds of whites battled with the police.

Skitch Henderson was found guilty last night of filing a false tax return involving a large deduction that he claimed for his donation of a music library to the University of Wisconsin. He faces three years' imprisonment.
Copper futures dropped 2 cents a pound yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here amid reports that East Germany had sold a large amount of the metal in London, depressing prices.
Word that the, ColgatePalmolive Company will sponsor the women's professional free-style championship series at six sites this winter, while offering $90,000 in prize money,

The reduction in teaching positions announced by Mayor Beame yesterday is part of more-sweeping economies, including tight controls on headquarters spending and possible cutbacks in after-school adulteducation programs, that are being instituted by the Board of Education to save $20-million to $30-million.

A 10-point burst in the first half tonight and the shooting of Scott May and Kent Benson gave thirdranked Indiana a 94-84 college basketball victory over Notre Dame.

The United Mine Worker's 38-member bargaining council voted tonight to send a tentative contract for 4,500 construction workers back to the bargaining table. Union negotiators,; upon hearing of the council's action, said they would seek a meeting as quickly as possible with representatives of the Association of Bituminous Contractors.

Frank H. Heiss, a partner in the New York law firm of Kelley Drye Warren Clark Carr Ellis, died yesterday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived at 1 Fairlawn Court, Rye, N.Y.

In the fog surrounding Joe Namath's future, the iceberg of reality has been hidden. New York is the National Football League's disaster area. Even with their five-game winning-streak, the 'Jets need a victory Sunday in Baltimore to finish with a 7-7 won-lost record.

Reports circulated in the airline industry yesterday that Edward E. Carlson, the one-time hotel bellman who worked his way up to the presidency of UAL Inc., parent company of United Airlines, would be elected chairman of the board of directors in Chicago today.

An expert presented by the state testified yesterday that there had been "substantial" improvements at the Willowbrook Development Center, but that "major problems" remained in overcrowding, the center's architectural design and the need for more competent behavior specialists and middle-level managers.

The city's chief construction inspector in Manhattan and two of his subordinates were indicted yesterday on charges that they took a total of $4,000 in bribes and unlawful gratuities to overlook building violations and expedite documents in a number of separate incidents this year and last.

Harold K. Philips, a former public-relations executive and correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, The Baltimore Sun and The Associated Press, died Wednesday at Largo, Fla. He was 81 years old.

A 76-year-old institution named Golda Meir came here to 228-year-old Nassau this week, and in two days devoted mainly to answering Princeton University students' questions, became a one-woman faculty on the problems of the Middle East.

The House of Representatives, by a voice vote, completed Congressional action today on legislation making criminal violations of the antitrust laws a felony, subject to a maximum prison sentence of three years.

The last time mass layoffs were used to help New York City through a budget crisis, in 1934, the city also imposed payless furloughs on its 140,000 municipal employes, ranging from seven days to a month.
John D. Ehrlichman insisted today, in the face of openly skeptical cross-examination by the Watergate prosecution, that he had been "deceived" by President Nixon.

Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that he would not support his fellow New York Republican, Senator Jacob K. Javits, for the chairmanship of the Senate Republican Conference despite "outside pressures" from New York Republican leaders that he do so.

The state announced today the indictment of Alex Smollock, manager of the Passaic County Vocational School, on charges that he accepted $40,000 in bribes from companies that did business with the school.

It apparently will be another big year for New Jersey parochial schools in basketball, based upon a rich mixture of returning veterans and promising newcomers. The season begins tomorrow with a typically massive Friday schedule, and such teams as Christian Brothers of Lincroft, St. Anthony's of Jersey City, Essex Catholic, Bishop Eustace of Pennsauken and Hudson Catholic already figure to be among the state's pace-setters.
Walter H. Wheeler Jr., honorary chairman and director emeritus of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., manufacturer of meters and stamping machines, died yesterday of a stroke at Stamford Hospital.

The newest of the Metropolitan Opera's double bills, "Bluebeard's Castle" and "Gianni Schicchi," received its first performance of the season last night. This was the somewhat unlikely pair that was introduced last June during the house's off season.

A Federal grand jury here has indicted four more persons, including the executive director of a Bronx.antipoverty organization, on charges of shaking down contractors and bombing building sites throughout the city when their extortion demands were not met.

Some 200,000 workers and students deserted their factories and classrooms today in three Basque provinces of northern Spain in support of political prisoners now being held in Spanish jails and of political freedom in general.

The Board of Education unanimously adopted a plan yesterday redrawing lines in Five Manhattan and two Brooklyn school districts. It then asked the Legislature for a two-year moratorium on the actual redistricting.

As expected, the State Racing and Wagering Board flashed the "official" sign yesterday for Sunday racing next year. at Belmont Park and Saratoga.

The United States and the Netherlands agreed today, during a meeting here between Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Max van der Stoel, to reopen deadlocked talks over a reduction in the number of flights to America by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that colleges receiving Federal contracts may not discriminate against white males while trying to improve employment opportunities for minority groups and women.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., thriving from all its diversified activities except financial services and leisure-time products, told its shareholders yesterday that its net income soared 40 per cent to a record in the first quarter ended Oct. 31.

Soybean prices moved up in active trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The rise appeared to be related to higher soybean oil prices because of processor shutdowns in the West. Farmers have been withholding beans from the market for higher prices and the processors have also been discouraged by unfavorable margins between bean prices and the prices of oil and meal into which they are crushed.

Rick MacLeish deflected a slap shot by Joe Watson into the net with 93 seconds to play tonight, giving the Phil adelphia Flyers a 3-2 victory over the Atlanta Flames in a National Hockey Leaguegame.
A Soviet Jew who received per mission to emigrate. to Israel has been sentenced to death on charges of taking bribes, hiswife said today.
The State Commissioner of Education ex pressed concern today over the possible effects of the cuts in the City University's budgetun der Mayor Beame's austerityprogram.

The Treasury announced yesterday it would sell $2 billion of two-year notes on Dec. 23 in a refinancing that does not call for raising any additional new cash. Proceeds will be used to refund a similar amount of publicly-held notes that mature on Dec. 31. Available in minimum denominations of $5,000, the notes will be sold on a yield basis.

President Ford hailed yester day the canonization of Blessed Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton, who is to become the first na tive-born American saint of the Roman Catholic Church, as a "milestone in our diverse spiritual history."

The Knicks, with an opportunity to take first place in the Na tional Basketball Association's Atlantic Division, wasted a splendid opportunity by go ing scoreless for more than six minutes in the final quar ter tonight, enabling the Buf falo Braves to rally for a 108-104 triumph at MemorialAuditorium.

Vassar College has decided to close Kendrick House, its all back student dormitory, rather an face an expensive and what it views as an "almost in evitably" losing court fight with the State Education De partment, which has charged that the dormitory violates antisegregation laws.

An American law firm in Heidelberg has charged that United States Army intelligence paid an American civilian to pose as a staff assistant last summer, to spy on its work defending soldiers in court-martial cases.
Elliot L. Richardson, who re signed as Attorney General 14 months ago during Richard M. Nixon's "Saturday night mas sacre," has been chosen to serve as President Ford's Ambassador to London.

Black African nationalist leaders, released from long detentions, scattered to their homes in various parts of Rhodesia today, but the white minority Government relaxed its regulations slightly to permit the black leaders to hold some political meetings in advance of a planned conference on the future of the racially divided country.
Higher cash prices for soy bean meal and soybean oil, based on export demand, en couraged a price rise in soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Old-timers argue that the Garden was established on boxing. But that was half a century ago. Old-timers re member when Friday night at the Garden was fight night. Freshly cut wood burns very slowly because of its high moisture content and the heat given off is 60% of that from seasoned wood. Anywhere from one-fourth to one half of live hardwood weight is water. For logs to burn efficiently, this moisture should be evaporated (a process called seasoning) before use in the fireplace.

As more and more amateur photographers become increasingly aware of the satisfaction and rewards of developing and printing their own pictures, the ranks of those who are setting up their own home darkrooms keeps increasing.

Dr. Elmer Kline, . a fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, died today at the Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. His age was 78.
Mrs. Guion Case Morgan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lee Sheila Morgan, to Thomas Reynolds Megna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Megna. Both families are of Lawrenceville, N. J.,

Fran Tarkenton and Bob Berry, sharing equal playing time, each threw two touchdown passes today as the playoff-bound Minnesota Vikings breezed to a 35-15 National Football League victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

Jose Ortega y Gasset described a novelist as one who "moves with cumbrous baggage like circuses or nomadic tribes, carrying the furnishings of the world on his back." In this novel Betsy Byars has chosen to travel light-she has sorted through her cumbrous baggage, exercising great discipline in selecting only essential furnishings and ruthlessly discarding superfluous gewgaws that might distract the reader from her characters.

An exhibit of Chinese archeological finds has opened at Washington's National Gallery of Art, but without the usual press preview. The gallery, on the advice of the State Department, canceled the preview rather than accede to Peking's demand that it control the guest list.

A lone gunman who forced a twin-engine aircraft to fly to Cuba was in the custody of Cuban authorities today while United States officials negotiated for the return of the pilot, officials said.

The General Assembly approved 21 disarmament resolutions last week-a record for a United Nations session. But as usual, it was the policy statements by the big powers that received the most serious consideration and not the substance of the resolutions, which were largely noncontroversial.
Searchers today found the bodies of two policemen who disappeared Friday while investigating the kidnapping of a boy who was released unharmed after payment of a $15,000 ransom.

Yonkers Raceway will open its 64-night winter harness racing meeting tonight with Canada's Herve Filion the featured attraction. During the 12 nights of racing left in the 1974 New York harness racing season, Filion will attempt to top his record of 605 victories in a year, set in 1972.

Responding to demands from union leaders that political fat be cut from the city's deficit budget along with the civil service bone, Mayor Beame promised the other day that any personnel firings would go "all the way up" and would tap many political provisionals. Although the First National City Bank of Jersey City is one of the first banks in the state to have announced that it will sell gold to all comers after Dec. 31, it does not seem overly eager to do so.

Guillermo Vilas, the 22-year-old Argentine sensation of international tennis, captured the. Grand Prix Masters tournament to day with a marathon five-set triumph over the defending champion, Ilie Nastase of Rumania. The scores were 7-6, 6-2, 3-6, 3-6, 6-4.

Despite a long-term trend toward ownership of corporate stock by persons in all income classes, the richest two-tenths of 1 per cent of Americans owned 30 per cent of all the stock as of mid-1971. The richest 1 per cent owned just over half of it.
Milk sales began to pick up yesterday at some stores as they were able to get milk on the first day after the end of the 11-day strike by almost 3,000 drivers and plant employes.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced regulations today to carry out the 1974 law banning sex discrimination in home lending. The board chairman, Thomas R. Bomar, said the regulations amount to a. bill of rights for women applicants for mortgage loans.
Officials of the state hospital for the criminally insane here have begun releasing 190 patients over protests from Texas prosecutors and district attorneys.
Harry Hershfield, the humorist and raconteur, died last night at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 89 years old. Mr. Hershfield, who had been ill for many months, was admitted to the hospital a week ago.
Strollers of Fifth Avenue have been puzzled and bedazzled by a silvery reflective fence running along the edge of Central Park from about East 61st to 65th Streets.

Elisabeth Ellen Kaplan, a member of the educational staff of the junior museum at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Scott Boas, a senior at the Cornell Medical School.

At least two dozen youths rampaged through Public School 46 in Harlem late yesterday afternoon, causing damage estimated by the police at thousands of dollars. Four 16-yearold boys were arrested.

For Engine Company 203, yesterday was a typical day--almost. There were a few false alarms, a few minor fires and one raging "all-hands," the kind of fire that can spread quickly through the centuryold tenements in the company's Red Hook response area of Brooklyn.
The chief honors in Saturday's regional play at the New York Hilton Hotel went to a young Connecticut pair, Ross Grabel of Hartford and Mark Rosenberg of New Havert who. captured the open pair title.

The investigation into the circumstances surrounding the recent fatal crash of a Trans World Airlines jet on its approach to Dulles International Airport in Washington points to a deplorable lack of Federal urgency on the question of flight safety.

City Councilmen will be asked by their leaders to give up $2,500 each--or half of their annual expense allowances, called luluss" - as a contribution toward shaving the city's multimillion-dollar budget deficit.

There is still time to do something about income taxes payable for 1974. And it will pay to do so in the next 15 days if there is likely to be a significant difference in gross income between this year and 1975.
Thousands of whites protested on the Common today against courtordered busing for school desegregation, a day after probusing forces rallied in downtown Boston.
Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey yesterday announced the formation of a 32-member panel to study environmental problems and recommend solutions to present and foreseeable future problems.

Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan said today that the United States would shortly supply 300,000 tons of food to India, but that major assistance by Arab oil producers was crucial.

A former Dallas city planner has testified in Federal Court that the city is one of the most segregated in the nation. John R. 'Greer, former head of the Community Action Program for the City of Dallas,

New Jersey's energy chief said yesterday that the state might be shortchanged on gasoline if Federal energy officials recommended reduction of allocations, as expected this week. G. Gordon M. Large, director of the State Energy Office, said advisers to President Ford were "considering very seriously" a cutback in fuel allocations.

Karin Branzell, for 21 seasons a leading contralto at the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday of an embolism, while recovering from a pelvic fracture suffered at her home in Altadena, Calif., where she had lived since 1969. She was 83 years old and the wife of Fedja Reinshagen who was an operatic stage director.

Don Saleski and Bill Barber each tallied two goals as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the St. Louis Blues, 7-2, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Saleski, who sometimes has been booed here, had his best night of the season, also getting two assists.

Paintings signed by nonconformist Soviet artists, many of whose works were suppressed in the violent disruption of an exhibition in a field outside Moscow last September, were shown yesterday in the peace of a synagogue in New Rochelle, N. Y.

Kenneth H. Condit, dean emeritus of the Princeton University School of Engineering, died yesterday in Boulder, Colo. He was 86 years old. Mr. Condit was graduated in 1908 from Stevens Institute of Technology with a degree in mechanical engineering and in 1913 from Princeton,
About 150,000 tons of food stockpiled as a precaution against nuclear attack will spoil unles it is used within the next few years, an official of the Civil Defense Preparedness Agency said tonight.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

The Traffic Department's parking-enforcement agents (formerly known as meter maids) and traffic-control agents yesterday rejected, 97 to 62, the city's offer of a 14 per cent pay increase in a two-year contract to replace the contract that expired last June 30. Their current salaries range from $7,900 to $8,800 a year.
A police detective on a stakeout in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was shot twice last night in a sudden exchange of gunfire with a man who was wanted for questioning, the police said.

As Joe Namath fades slowly into the sunset, perhaps never to return, the Jets closed the 'record book on Season No. 15. The record book, though, won't be entirely accurate; this year actually represented the Jets' 15th and 16th seasons.

James Lack, the Suffolk County Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, reported yesterday that his department had exacted $1,500, which he called the highest penalty in its history, from the Hills Supermarket chain for short-weight violations.

Legislation that is expected to double the number of elderly persons exempt from rent increases in regulated apartments was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council's General Wtlfare Committee.
Next business inventories rose in October by $5.6-billion, the largest monthly increase this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Congress resolved a four-month battle over school desegregation today when the House followed the Senate's lead and nullified an antibusing amendment in an education money bill, sending the measure on to President Ford.

Legislation to extend the life of the Export-Import Bank was again thrown into doubt today as the Senate voted to send the bill back once more to conference with the House of Representatives on two controversial issues.

The United States indicated today that it would veto any Security Council resolution calling for sanctions against South Africa.
The familes of two teen-agers missing since about 10 P.M. Friday said today that they feared the girls had met with disaster.
The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision that allows, in rare instances, a company to obtain a trademark for a product after its patent has run out.
President Ford and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France announced today that they had reached a compromise agreement to coordinate their energy policies.

A 30-year-old Lower East Side resident with a record of 14 arrests was shot and slightly wounded by a policewoman early yesterday morning after what she said was an attempt to rape her roommate in an East Village apartment.
A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday cleared a white policeman, Frank P. Bosco, of criminal negligence in the shooting death of a 14-year-old black youth last September.

When President Ford announced his clemency program for draft resisters last September, he described his goal as a "national commitment to justice and mercy," an effort to "heal the scars of divisiveness." Though severely flawed in many of its details, the program at least held out hope that a sincere beginning might be made to return its disaffected sons to the nation's fold.

Wheat futures led a decline in the grain market yesterday on a report by Senator Michael J. Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, who is in China, that the Chinese had said they did not plan to buy much more products from the United States. The Chinese were said to be disappointed because so far most of the trade between the two nations has involved exports from the United States.

Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had decided to withdraw from the airline industry's controversial "mutual aid pact," under which airlines shut down by a strike are given payments by other airlines to help cover strike-related losses.

Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard said yesterday that a 58-year old man in whom he implanted a second hear from a 10-year old girl three weeks ago "is doing very, very well" without evidence of the rejection phenomenon and that both hearts were pumping effectively and independently.

A show and sale of art signed by Russian dissidents that opened Sunday at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N. Y., has so far attracted no purchasers, according to a spokesman for the temple. But yesterday some indications of its hitherto undisclosed origins began to emerge.

Ara Parseghian's decision to resign as Notre Dame's football coach was a surprise and shock to his colleagues, many of whom felt it stemmed from his intense nature and the extreme pressures imposed upon a major college coach.
In slightly stepped-up trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market fell yesterday, with declines almost doubling advances.

Criminal Court Judge Bruce M. M. Wright, who has become involved in a series of controversies because of his policy of setting low hail, has been reassigned to Civil Court.

Agreed to review a decision denying two music copyright owners an injunction against a restaurant operator playing their compositions over the radio to his customers without paying a license fee (No. 74-452, Twentieth Century Music v. Aiken).

Dr. Charles C. Edwards, the nation's chief health officer, has submitted his resignation to the White House. He expects to leave in midJanuary to become senior vice president of Becton, Dickinson Co., a maker of medical and surgical supplies in Rutherford, N. J.

Manhattan District Attorney Richard Kuh has unveiled fifteen bills containing significant and constructive proposals to change and modernize the criminal law. They will be introduced in the next session of the Legislature; most of them deserve support. A number of the proposals involve changes in the laws dealing with sex-related crimes.

Fulton Freeman, former Ambassador to Mexico and Colombia, and since 1969 president of the Monterey Institute of Foreign Studies, died Saturday after suffering a heart attack during a golf game. His age was 59.

Stefan Priacel, one of the leading conference interpreters on the international circuit, died here today. He was 70 years old. Mr. Priacel, who was of German and Polish parentage, grew up in Switzerland and Italy before making his home in France.

Sydney G. Harnett, a leading figure in the Knights of Pythias, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and lived on Harbor Island, Fla.

Edward Allen Pierce, the last living original member of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the country's largest brokerage house, died here yesterday in his home. He had turned 100 last Aug. 31.

Anthony D. Schoberl, president of. the bank, said the funds were earmarked to finance up to, 80 per cent of the purchase price of new homes and to cover both construction loans and permanent mortgages.
Several companies announced yesterday plans to change to the LIFO (last-in, first-out) method of inventory accounting from the FIFO (first-in, firstout) basis.

The Houston International Tournament, sponsored by Lynne Babcock and the Houston Chess Club in conjunction with the United States Chess Federation, began Dec. 6 at the Seminar Centre of the Continental Houston Motor Hotel.
Two more of the Lange sextuplets died today, leaving one survivor among the 10 babies born in the last 13 months to a young mother taking fertility drugs.

In this fantasy of mine the washing machine is broken and President Ford, Henry Kissinger and the President's experts have come to the house to deal with the problem. They are all clustered in the living room, shaking hands for photographers and examining reports on the hopeless condition of the washing machine.

It's wall-to-wall people and plenty of profit these days in museum shops across the land as the last surge of Christmas shoppers descends to purchase everything from Christmas cards to Fieldcrest sheets.
A Massachusetts lawyer faces two charges of death by automobile here following a car accident in which he is alleged to have caused the death of a pregnant woman and her unborn child.
Mayor Beame directed First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh yesterday to lead a delegation to Washington tomorrow to seek support for the city's plan to retire 860
The American Motors Corporation, with a backlog of 112 days' supply of cars, announced production cutbacks today that will affect 13,000 workers.
President Ford and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France announced today that they had reached a compromise agreement to coordinate their energy policies.
The Nassau County board of Supervisors today adopted a budget for 1975 that calls for a tax increase of $1.06 for each $100 of assessed valuation.
United Air Lines and the Air Line Pilots Association have agreed to a new contract that will increase wages of the airline pilots by 22 per cent over the next 31 months, the union said today.

Oil-producing nations have said here that they are increasing their 'assistance to needy countries, but United Nations officials say that they cannot find out where that assistance is going or under what conditions.
New York's two Republicans Senators, already embroiled in a public controversy, are now engaged in a second, behind-the-scenes, dispute involving a. forthcoming Presidential appointment.
Crackers cost too much? Wish you had some unsweetened wafers around the house to eat with soup, cheese or just as a snack? There's a way-make them yourself.
A 22-year-old police informer charged with armed robbery and burglary withdrew his notguilty plea yesterday and said he was guilty in both cases and would accept whatever sentence he deserved.
For the second time this year and for the third time in New Jersey's legislative history, the Senate Democratic majority has rejected in caucus a state income tax.

Pope Paul VI today appealed for unity and reconciliation in a church threatened by what he termed the "polarization of dissent." In an apostolic exhortation, the Pope warned that "ferments of infidelity to the Holy Spirit" existed in the church today and were "seeking to undermine her from within."

The city's largest retailer, the New York division of R. H. Macy Co., will take the unusual step starting this Saturday of opening its stores at 8:30 A.M., or an hour and 15minutes earlier than usual.
