Following are excerpts from a communique issued today after the conference between president Ford and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing:

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt has warned that the Middle t East is a bomb ready to explode and that definite progress toward a settlement must be achieved if Secretary of State Kissinger wants to continue his negotiations.

The Senate voted today to give girls the same chance as boys to play Little League baseball. But in a separate action, it voted to exempt such groups as the Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, Campfire Girls, the Y.M.C.A., the Y.W.C.A. and sororities and fraternities from the provisions of Federal sex anti-discrimination laws in higher education.
The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled today that a special election cannot be called in the state's disputed United States Senate race unless it ends up in a tie.

The Center for Auto Safety charged yesterday that "widespread failures" by the Federal Highway Administration were permitting continued construction of highway "booby traps" responsible for an estimated total of more than 18,000 deaths a year.

KIEV, Soviet Union-Zoya Idenko is the model of the young Soviet mother liberated by a local day care center that permits her to hold a job. With her 3-year-old son in a state nursery, she works as a guide for Intourist and sometimes also teaches English at a night school.

Thomas V. Burns, accused of kidnapping 7-year-old George Kaloyerakis Jr. of Rutherford, was ordered to undergo a two-week psychiatric examination that will determine whether he will be prosecuted on Federal charges. Mr. Burns, through his lawyer, James Sattely, agreed to undergo tests at the Federal hospital in Springfield, Mo., during a hearing before Federal Magistrate Harry Lane Jr. in Newark.
Secretary of State Kissinger has ordered shifts at the State Department, including the naming of a woman for the first time to head the Foreign Service.

Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa has suggested a plan to settle the prolonged Rhodesian crisis that, if carried out, would appear certain to bring black rule to Rhodesia within a few years, sources close to the situation reported today.
Arthur Ashe said yesterday that India was wrong to default to South Africa in the final of the recent Davis Cup. "It was definitely a poor strategic move on India's part," he said.
The signs are increasing that Britain is losing the battle against her two most persistent and serious economic ailments -- chronic inflation and an immense trade deficit.

Arthur Ashe said yesterday that India was wrong to default to South Africa in the final of the recent Dayis Cup. "It was definitely. a poor strategic move on India's part," he said. "By not playing, India set back normalization of. racial tensions two or three years. I'm sure there was pressure exerted on India's team.

Walt Disney Productions of Burbank, Calif., said yesterday that it was discussing with Mitsui Co., Ltd., the Mitsui Real Estate Development Company and the Keisei Electric Railway Company, Ltd., the possibility of jointly developing an amusement park and related facilities in Japan.

The Ford-Giscard meeting in Martinique appears to have brought about a significant change in France's position on oil-consumer cooperation from odd-man-out to odd-man-in. The extraordinary concessions made by the United States and France's Common Market partners-all designed to permit France to cooperate in a way differently from the others-were well worth.

Mimi Bushnell Lineaweaver, a partner in Jessup, Inc., interior. decorators here and in Palm Beach, who was known professionally as Mimi Rand, died Sunday at her home, 720 Park Avenue. She was 69 years old.

The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision holding that the Federal Maritime Commission did not have the authority to approve a longrange merger agreement between the nation's two largest container shipping companies.
Frank Dunne, who retired last year as head of Dunne Co., investment securities, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Mineola, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

District Attorney Joseph P. Busch, whose office oversaw the investigation into the slaying of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, said today that he would reopen an inquiry into the murder only if a court, at the request of Sirhan B. Sirhan, Mr. Kennedy's convicted assailant, ordered it.

Prodied by United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Con??ecticut legislative panel investigating state leasing practices issued a statement here tonight saying that it had no evidence that Gov. Thomas J. Meskill had been involved in any illegal acts.
Figures released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange indicate that in November there was a substantial rise in the number of customers' margin accounts vulnerable to margin calls.

To the Editor: A ten-cent-per-gallon tax on gasoline might be acceptable if it could be used to trigger a series of benefits for the nation. If part of the revenue from the tax were used to rebate the cost, say up to $350,
Al Attles never made it as an All-Star in his 10 seasons as a player. in the National Basketball Association, but he may be the first black coach of a major league AllStar team.
Black men who went without treatment for syphilis as part of a Government experiment would receive $37,500 each from the Government under a tentative out-of-court settlement filed today.

Gold hit a two-week high on international exchanges today, pushed well over the $180 mark by reports that oil-rich Arab states plan to buy all or most of the bullion the United States will put up for sale Jan. 6.

Anatole Litvak, the film director, died last night at a hospital in suburban Neuilly at the age of 72. Mr. Litvak, who was briefly married to the late American movie star Miriam Hopkins, leaves his second wife, the former Sophie Steur.

President Ford and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France announced in a communique at the end of their two days of talks in Martinique that they had reached a compromise agreement to coordinate their energy policies. Under the agreement, the United States will take part in a Frenchproposed conference of oil-producing nations, major oil importers and probably developing countries in an effort to bring order to the world market. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

"I'm overaged, overexperienced and overeducated," Max Ferder said yesterday, explaining his problems as one of the 2,525 provisional city employes Mayor Beame intends to dismiss in his effort to balance the city budget.
General Mills, Inc., reported yesterday records for sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended Nov. 24.
The Swiss team championship, which concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regionals at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday, was a triumph for old-fashioned bidding methods.

Chris McCarron, who posted his first career victory a little more than 10 months ago, tied the world record for the most victories by a jockey in a year today. He rode two winners at Laurel Race Course and raised his total to 515.

While Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey has yet to name his first state appointees, he has assembled a private hierarchy of advisers and technicians that already is setting the tone for his administration as a cautious one, very much under his control.
Former President Richard M. Nixon plans to challenge the constitutional right of Congress to provide public access to his White House tape recordings and documents, his lawyers disclosed today.

A three-judge Federal court has ruled that the New York State child placement system, as laid out in the State Constitution and in state statutes, does not on its face violate the Constitution of the United States. One need not dispute the technical correctness of that decision to recognize that the actual operation of the system in New York City can in no way be deemed fair.

Cash withdrawals against a deposit resulting from the forgery of a $902,000 Los Angeles City Treasury check have been made at a Dutch bank, the Los Angeles County District Attorney, Joseph Busch, said today.

The wife of Raleigh's Mayor has been indicted on charges of conspiring to receive stolen Foods. The police said her name had been found in a notebook carried by an accused shoplifter, who reportedly took orders ?o steal expensive clothing and neat.
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a restaurant owner must obtain a license to hook up a radio to loudspeakers and amplify broadcasts of copyrighted musical compositions.

The first break in the retail price of sugar since the sharp increases of November came yesterday when cost of a fivepound bag in some supermarkets dropped to $2.79. The price had climbed in 12 months from 82 cents to $2.21 last October. Then it began i rocketing up. It rose to an average of $2.54 by November, then shot to $3.60.

"At first they laughed at me," former Foreign Minister Michel Jobert said of the reaction of most established French politicians to the political movement that he began last summer. "Now they're afraid of me."
Medical scientists reported today, promising results from use of a new cancer drug against such difficult forms of the disease as bone cancer and recurrent breast cancer.

A woman was Reported to have been killed and 24 people wounded by falling shrapnel in downtown Seoul last night when South Korean antiaircraft gunners fired thousands of rounds at what was apparently a Korean Air Lines jet approaching the city's airport.
A 66-year-old Brooklyn woman was beaten to death with a cane last night by a 52-yearld man in an argument in the woman's East New York apartment, the police reported.

Turkish and American diplomats here say they are convinced that relations between their two countries could deteriorate sharply if the United States Congress extended the ban on military aid to Turkey.

Hysterical reactions aside, the Jim (Catfish) Hunter case was in a fairly understandable condition after yesterday's official announcement that the star pitcher no longer had a valid contract with the Oakland A's, and was, a free agent able to entertain offers from any major league baseball clubs.
The School Committee defied a Federal Court order today by refusing to approve a new citywide plan for busing to achieve school desegregation next fall.

The Supreme Court upheld today the 1973 railroad reorganization plan that Congress enacted to rescue eight bankrupt carriers in the Northeast and Middle West and merge them into a single private self-sustaining system. The vote was 7 to 2.
The United States is prepared to provide Egypt with an atom?? power plant if a companion sale to Israel falls through, the State Department said today.
A mission sent by the United Nations Children's Fund has completed a week's visit here during which it discussed delivery of 20 Swiss-made prefabricated schools to North Vietnam.
The 63d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $500,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $15,624.50 from 310 contributors. The over all figure now stands at $500,765.48.

Jolene Rene, now the only survivor of the Lange sextuplets, is "progressing well" and displaying only mild respiratory problems, doctors say. Her brothers, Jason and Brian, died yesterday of hyaline membrane disease, a disorder common to premature infants in which the lungs cannot absorb sufficient oxgen.

Secretary of State Kissinger was reported today to have said that the United States might be willing to support a "mechanism" that could lead to the lifting of economic and diplomatic sanctions against Cuba.

The first successful launching last week of a giant new rocket has bolstered confidence in the $1-billion Viking program to land two American scientific craft on Mars in 1976 to search for signs of life.

The Senate Judiciary Committee today in effect killer for this session of Congress the controversial nomination of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The Navy has asked the Justice Department to look into the question of possible fraud in connection with a multimillion-dollar shipbuilding claim by the Lockheed Aircraft Corportion.
The Newark Archdiocese is studying the efficiency of its 253 parishes to begin "tightening up" its finances,-the Most Rev. Peter L. Gerety said today.
A serious rift has developed between Egypt and Syria over United States prpposals for a second step in the disengagement of Arab and Israeli armies.

Max Koppel, the 69-year-old rabbi shot to death Monday night in an apparent holdup attempt, was described yesterday by neighbors in Washington Heights and by members of his family as a "gentle man, always seeking to help others" whatever their denomination or color.

The Assembly's Democratic leadership disclosed today that it would push still another state income tax proposal-this one a 2 per cent tax on gross income earned in New Jersey-despite the fact that it had less of a chance of being approved by the Senate than the smaller tax that the Senate Democratic caucus rejected yesterday.

The City Council adopted a strict disclosure bill yesterday requiring elected officials and all city employes earning more than $25,000 a year to report the sources of their income. The vote was 41 to 1.
After 10. often-controverslal years, the symbolic-pillars of the Gateway to Harlem-the Arthur A.. Schom'burg Plaza-were dedicated yesterday.
After 10 often-controversial years, the symbolic pillars of the Gateway to. Harlem-the Arthur A. Schomburg Plaza-were dedicated yesterday.
Forego, big in size and achievement, was named yesterday the horse of the year in thoroughbred racing. The 4-year-old gelding, owned by Martha L. Gerry and trained by Sherrill Ward,

When a reporter receives a subpoeha, or a judge issues a "gag" order against the press, the, chances are that the first place a journalist or his lawyer will turn to for help is a littleknown, under-financed, understaffed organization called the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press.

A new team of three lawyers yesterday took over the defense in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case and said they would file a second application for a new trial in New Jersey on the basis of newly discovered evidence.
The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld its own rules limiting the size of contingency fees lawyers may charge in negligence cases and set the stage for a test of the regulations in Federal court.

An international panel of bankers and economists has warned that both industrialized and developing countries face an "immediate danger of progressive collapse" because of the payments problem created by the sharp increase in the price of oil.

The European Economic Community took a first step toward creating a common internal energy policy today as its nine members agreed at a meeting of energy ministers on joint objectives for energy use by 1985.
Six prominent scientists deplored today the forced resignation of the director of the National Institutes of Health, the nation's foremost biomedical research organization.

Led by a Councilman who reportedly declared that he would not approve putting public funds in a "foreign bank," the five-member Town Board of Islip, L.I., yesterday struck the European-American Bank and Trust Company from the list of banks authorized to receive deposits of municipal funds.

Ted Lindsay, the former Detroit Red Wing who played 17 seasons in the National Hockey League, watched tonight's contest between the St. Louis Blues and the New York Islanders and called it "probably one of the worst games I've ever seen," The two coaches agreed their players had given terrible performances. The result was. an 8-4 victory for the Blues in St. Louis Arena before a crowd of 17,249.

Rick Barry staged a oneman show last night at Madison Square Garden. The Golden State Warrior, forward hooked the basketball with his left and. right hands, scored on jump shots off the dribble and straight up, and drove the Knicks mad at both ends of the floor.

The Assembly's Democratic leadership disclosed today that it would push still another state income tax proposal-this one a 2 per cent tax on gross income earned in New Jersey-despite the fact that it had less of a chance of being approved by the Senate than the smaller tax that the Senate Democratic caucus rejected yesterday.
The North American Soccer League announced yesterday that it would hold an indoor tournament this winter and that CBS would provide television coverage of two games.

After months of high-level study, the Defense Department has decided that it should standardize the prices and reduce the staffs but not abolish five private dining rooms for top-ranking officers and officials.

A number of the nation's major companies were reported to day to have sent letters to President Ford urging him to sign, rather than veto, a strip mine control bill that has been bitterly opposed for years by the mining industry's trade associations here.

In just an hour yesterday, Jean Vergnes whipped up breakfast (scrambled eggs), lunch (omelettes of all sorts), dinner (Supreme de Volaille Gismonda)-and the enthusiasm of a youthful audience that decided that the chef himself was the most delightful treat of the day.
The offices of the New York Passport Agency, a feature of the Rockefeller Center area for almost 40 years, will remain in its present location.

The Glen Cove school district may have to cut its teaching staff and educational programs because of a limit on its taxing power resulting from a court decision, the president of the city's Board of Education said today.
Rabbi Baruch Korff asked Americans today, in the spirit of "peace on earth, goodwill to men," to leave former President Richard M. Nixon alone, If they do not, the Rabbi said, Mr. Nixon may die.

WNBC-FM radio has changed its musical format from rock to 24-hours of low-key popular music. John Lund, program manager for WNBC-AM and FM, said the new format, called "The Love of New York," was geared' to a younger audience than those of most "easy listening" stations in New York.

The United States has decided to boycott a' special furid being set up here to pro. vide emergency relief and development aid to the countries hardest hit economically. The decision marks the first time that the United States has declined to participate in a major new United Nations undertaking.
Macmllian, Inc., has obtained exclusive rights to the publication and performance of all Soviet music in the Western Hemisphere, it was announced yesterday.
New York City's outstanding bonds, mauled by losses in recent weeks, improved in price yesterday after the city set forth a sharply curtailed schedule of public borrowing for the first half of 1975.

Alderman John J. Hoellen, describing himself as a "work horse not a race horse," announced today that he would be the regular Republican party's candidate to oppose Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago in 1975. Mayor Daley, a Democrat, is seeking a sixth term.

State Attorney Robert Eagan said today he was investigating a,$1.5-million check that bounced after it was presented to the floundering Florida, Blazers. of the' World Football League. The prosecutor said he was conducting an investigation. of possible fraud and trafficking in bad checks. The check was flashed before television cameras just before kickoff at the Nov-21 playoff game between,the Blazers and the Philadelphia Bell.

Nearly one-third of those who have joined Alcoholics Anonymous during the last three years are women, according to a survey announced today by the chairman of the board of trustees of the organization.

After being down most of the session, prices closed mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as a result of a buying spurt near the close. Prices in the over-the-counter market also were irregular as trading in both markets rose slightly.

Over the years, the British playwright Tom Stoppard has built up a reputation as the playboy of the Western word. But what was he like when he was a slip of a lad, before the metaphysical histrionics and dramatic conjuring tricks of such plays as "Jumpers" and "Travesties"?

The Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, which played to empty seats and was in financial distress four years ago during the last recession, is now performing to sell-out audiences and is in sound economic condition.
Joseph A. Livingston, a retired sportswear manufacturer, died of a kidney ailment yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 70 East 77th Street.

An ecological experiment harnessing the efforts of city agencies and community volunteers is converting piles of construction debris deposited as landfill on the shore of Jamaica Bay into a landscaped public park at the foot of Pennsylva. nia Avenue in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.
Two high schools that have been a center of racial turmoil will remain closed until Jan. 2, after the Christmas holidays, because of the threat of further trouble, school officials said today.
LEND AN EAR The New York University Choral Arts Society will give a bon voyage concert of early classics tonight at 8:30 before flying to Rome to perform at the Vatican.

Wall Street is flooded with red ink, but some of the biggest investment banking houses in the country are nevertheless paying year-end bonuses, a spot check of leading investment houses disclosed yesterday.
The British Government sought today to clear up some questions surrounding a missing member of Parliament who disappeared last month in Miami Beach.

An explosion, apparently caused by a spark that ignited flamable liquid, damaged part of a Newark-chemical plant. The blast demolished part of the Honig Chemical and Processing Corporation. No injuries were reported, although four men were working in the building at the time.

The Security Council today unanimously adopted a resolution calling on South Africa to Like the necessary steps to withdraw from South-West Africa, the former German colony that South Africa has been administering since the end of World War I.

The Conservative party has decided for the first time to hold an annual election for its leader. But the new rules have to be approved by Edward Heath, the party leader who faces possible defeat under the proposals.

Pan American World Airways agreed yesterday to give-Trans World Airlines its authority to serve Austria from this country, in a revised plan for a global route-exchange agreement between the two United States flag airlines.
Agriculture Department officials today unveiled a proposal for a new computerized system of reports designed to help strengthen Federal policing of abuses in commodity futures trading.

Governor Byrne, citing personal knowledge of "huge fees" being paid to physicians or other health-care providers, today directed the State Commission of Investigation to open an inquiry into possible fraud in New Jersey's Medicaid program.

Top-seeded John Newcombe of Australia beat Uli Pinner of West Germany, 6-4, 6-4, in a second-round match at the New South Wales open tennis championships today. Americans Mike Machette and Raz Reid won their second-round matches but John Andrews and Steve Docherty lost.

Leroy Barnes, whom law-enforcement authorities described as one of the nation's major drug traffickers, was charged yesterday with offering a $130,000 bribe to policemen after they stopped his Mercedes-Benz sedan in the South Bronx and allegedly found a gun in it.
Australian troops in World War II were used as "guinea pigs" in poison gas experiments, a federal minister confirmed today.

A National Council of Churches Conference on world hunger ended a two-day session today by adopting a broad statement that includes an appeal to its constituent denominations to double their food aid next year.
The Public Service Company of Indiana filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a public offering of 1.3 million common shares.

With time running out on the Dec. 31 deadline Congress has imposed on the Federal Communications Commission for plans to deal with sex and violence on television, Richard E, Wiley, the agency's chairman, said yesterday that "one of the commission's initiatives" could be a. public proceeding, This would mean open hearings on network practices with programs considered unsuitable for juvenile Viewinfg.

Supreme Court narrowed its definition of interstate commerce today and, in the process, denied Federl relief to laber unions forbiddent to picket by state courts and to a California manufacturer trying to invoke the antitrust laws against price-fixing.
Striking mine construction workers defied court orders today to cease their picketing, which has virtually halted all coal production and made thousands of miners idle.

New York City announced a major curtailment in public borrowing yesterday in a move intended to reduce a glut of its obligations on the market and to cut interest costs by stimulating competition for its bonds.

New York City announced a major curtailment in public borrowing yesterday in a move intended to reduce a glut of its obligations on the market and to cut interest costs by stimulating competition for its bonds.
The resignation of Roy L. Ash as director of the Office of Management and Budget was announced today by the White House, and several other Cabinet-level changes were reported imminent.

Charles O. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, plans to seek a restraining order against Jim Hunter tomorrow in Alameda County Court here, preventing the pitcher from negotiating with any other team. He will also ask the court to overturn the arbitrator's decision that made Hunter a free agent.

Just about every letter that Virgil, Lane delivers in these parts is a special delivery. It's not that they cost extra or go out at all hours of the day or night. It's just that they are so dashed hard to deliver.
A serious rift has developed between REypt and Syria over United' States proposals for a second step in the disengagement of Arab and Israeli armies.
Bombs exploded tonight outside three telephone exchanges in central London, killing a man and injuring at least five persons, including policemen.
The common, or at least "complementary," international energy policy worked out by Presidents Ford and Valery Giscard d'Estaing in Martinique marks a highly important

Gov. Ronald Reagan's inner circle of Republican financial backers in California gave a quiet luncheon in Los Angeles last Friday for Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr., the Texas Democrat who is apparently on the verge of declaring his Presidential candidacy.
Steve Grogan, Kansas State quarterback, led the North to a 29-24 seesaw victory over the South in the annual Blue-Gray college football game tonight.

Communist attacks, shifting in intensity from province to province in the last 12 days, have pushed Government troops out of two district capitals, isolated a border province capital and sharply reduced security on several important roads.

As everybody interested in music knows, Mussorgsky's masterpiece, "Boris Godunov," is seldom presented as it originally was written. Ever since 1908, the reorchestration (and, often, reharmonization) by RimskyKorsakov has been in use. Only recently has the original orchestral score been made generally available.
The 63d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $500,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $15,624.50 from 310 contributors. The over all figure now stands at $500,765.48.

Two leading black politicians said yesterday they were pressing Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey to appoint Basil A. Paterson as Secretary of State, arguing that the black community deserved a visible state post and that the frontrunner for the job, Mario M. Cuomo, was not so well qualified.

A former professor of dentistry at the University of Uruguay was found shot to death Monday evening on the sidewalk only three doors from his home in Jamaica Estates, Queens, in what the police said yesterday was an apparent robbery.
OF MICE AND MEN, John Stelnbeck's drama, directed by Edwin Sherln, starring James Earl Jones and Kevin Conway, at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 7.

An Israeli force drove five miles into southern Lebanon this morning and blew up six houses in Majdal Zun, it was officially announced here. Israeli military headquarters said the houses had been "used by terrorists."
Joe Richards, bowling columnist of The Daily News, died at his home here Sunday at the age of 81.
Robert Wayne (Bud) Moore offensive coordinator under Paul (Bear) Bryant at Ala bama, was named head foot ball coach at the University of Kansas yesterday.
Chairman Mao: Tse-tung met with President Mobutu Sese seko of Zaire in China Yesterday, according to Hsinhua, the Chinese news agency.

Three Coast Guard crewmen were rescued early yesterday from the cold, choppy waters off Rockaway, Queens, two hours after their launch had capsized, trapping two of them in a cabin inside, They survived thanks to an air pocket while the third man was able to crawl onto the upturned bottom of the vessel.

A state audit of fiscal irregularities in Community School District 9 in the Bronx, which was officially made public yesterday, criticized the city Board of Education for not having done more to prevent and correct abuses.
The Senate Judiciary committee today cleared leglislation that would permit 13 states to continue operating lotteries without fear of Federal reprisals.

Specialists in the most violent events known, such as the stellar explosions called supernovas examined today the evidence for one class of occurrence in the universe whose nature and location remain unknown.

For some years now, Milton Babbitt and Elliott Carter have served as gurus of the academic avant-garde heareabouts, and young composers have watched them closely to know which way the winds were blowing. So it made particularly good sense for the Group for Contemporary Music to present a retrospective concert of Babbitt and Carter pieces on Monday night at the Manhattan School of Music.

Billy Cunningham scored a season-high 3.3 points, 13 in the fourth quarter, to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 113-109 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight, in a National Basketball Association at the Providence Civic Center.
Bill Nelsen, quarterback coach, and Phil Bengston, director of pro scouting, have resigned from the New England Patriots, Coach Chuck Fairbanks said today.

A new team of three lawyers yesterday took over the defense in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case and said they would file a second application for a new trial in New Jersey on the basis of newly discovered evidence.

The Assembly overwhelmingly passed a bill today to make farmers responsible for the misdeeds of their, migrant worker crew leaders, then went on to pass overwhelmingly, a second bill that appeared to nullify the first.

Persistence, steady habits and a lucky barber for a talisman have paid off for Ernest M. Steele, an unemployed former children's-wear manufacturer, who has become the first $250,000 winner in the state's new 50-cent weekly lottery.

The United States dollar and tlie-British pound were dumped by money dealers today, forcing the currencies to record 'lows against European currencies, and raising the Swiss franc under heavy buying deinand. The price of gold rose with the decline of the dollar.
Edward Darling, author and editor, died last Thursday at his home at Dennis, Mass. He was 67 years old. Mr. Darling attended Dartmouth College and Harvard University.

Top-seeded Johll Newcombe of Australia beat Uli Pinner of West Germany, 6-4, 6-4, in a second-round match at the New South Wales open tennis championships today. Americans Mike Machette and Raz Reid won their second-round matches but John Andrews and Steve Docherty lost.
The official leader of Rhodesia's 5.5 million blacks said today that a constitutional conference with the Rhodesian Government could not begin until agreement was reached on majority rule.

Dan Devine promised Notre Dame's football fans the same type of game they had under Ara Paraseghian as Devine made his first appear-ance today as coach. of the Fighting Irish, 11 years after he was first considered for the job.

The Ford Administration and members of a Senate-House conference, committee have worked out a compromise foreign-aid package that would allow the United States to resume military assistance to Turkey through Feb. 5 while efforts continue for a Cyprus settlement.
About 130 customers will receive refunds totaling up to $240,000 from a gold and silver coin dealer to settle a city consurmer protection suit.
Defense Minister Shimon Peres said today that Syrian ground-to-air missile batteries near Damascus were manned by Soviet soldiers.

W. R.. Battle, the father of Tennessee's football coach, Bill Battle, died early today of a heart attack after collapsing in the stands during last night's Tennessee's Liberty Bowl victory over Maryland.

' In almost all forms of tournament play, chance plays a role away from the card table. A lucky pair can find themselves in a weak section, in spite of the efforts of organizers to seed them equally. And in most team events the luck of the draw is highly significant.

The 93d or Watergate Congress is now breaking up, and the chances are that the 94th, which convenes on Jan. 14, will be more liberal, more spendthrift, more partisan and increasingly critical of the Ford Administration.

The Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company said yesterday it had declared a partial force majeure against its December sales and commitments for returns to toll customers.
President Ford, described as "concerned and. very disappointed," demanded today that the United States Steel Corporation justify in writing the reasons for the price increases it announced yesterday.

Sales advanced 29.1 per cent to $359.3million from $278.3-million.
The Defense Department today denied reports that United States troops were being trained to take over Middle East oilfields in the event of another embargo by the Arab oil-producing countries.

Herstatt creditqrs would grant him and other leading figures in the Herstatt case immunity from possible legal claims, Judge Wilhelm Uhlenbruck said. Mr. Gerling, an insurance executive, was the insolvent bank's majority stockholder.

A man awaiting trial on indictments growing out of the 1971 Attican prison revolt has been arrested on charges of robbing a 74-year-old widow.

Richard M. Nixon, for six years the most powerful person in the most powerful nation on earth, was turned down today by the Dade County Board of Commissioners on a petition to keep tourists off the road in front of his Key Biscayne house. The vote was 5 to 3.

Congressional conferees agreed today on legislation that would provide 375,000 public service jobs next year and pay Federal cash benefits to as.many as 3 million. workers not now covered by unemployment compensation.

Europe's bullion trading centers reacted bullishly today to the FrenchAmerican decision at Martinique to permit nations to adopt current market prices as the basis of valuation for their gold holdings, instead of the official price of $42.22 an ounce.

The F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company announced yesterday that it and Piel Bros., Inc., were engaged in negotiations which would permit Schaefer to assume the total manufacturing and marketing of about 1 million barrels of the Piel's and Trommer's brands of beer.
Premier Constantine Caramanlis today proposed a leading jurist and man of letters as his Government's choice for the first president of the new Greek Republic.
Society should consider a mortorium on. use of the poor as subjects of medical experimentation, a doctor suggested today.
Turkish Cypriote refugees forced Archbishop Makarios to retreat today when he attempted to visit their camps inside this British base area.
The Federal Energy Administration has obtained price rollbacks totaling about $77-million to correct alleged overcharging on petroleum products by 15 oil companies, a spokesman said today.
Lionel A. Racine, assistant controller of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 39 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

A. King McCord, former chairman of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company, died yesterday in West Penn Hospital, Pittsburgh. He was 70 years old and lived in Fox Chapel, Pa.

The Justice Department is in vestigating the award of a Federal contract worth at least $46 million for the leasing of Government office space in a Philadelphia building developed by a close friend of Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader.

PARIS-Moscow has followed up its increasing detente with Paris by opening here a rather boring exposition called "France and the U.S.S.R.-The Great Moments of a Tradition." This displays some socialist realist paintings, some ceramics with hortatory slogans and pre-Communist mementos including French paintings from Russian museums.
President Ford said today that he and his family would fly to Colorado Sunday morning for their annual.. holiday skiing vacation in the resort town of Vail.

Senator William Proxmire said today that investigators for the Senate-House Joint Economic Committee had found identical prices on 2,969 items among 3,959 checked in Kansas City stores of the nation's two largest retail food chains.

Lou Guarini, an 18-year-old college sophomore, may be the youngest Coach of a varsity high school team in the country. And a successful one at that. In his first year as head coach of the St. Peter's Prep gymnastics team, Guarini's squad captured the county title and finished second to Henry Hudson High of Atlantic Highlands in the state championships recently.

Congressional conferees agreed today on legislation that would provide 375,000 public service jobs next year and pay Federal cash benefits to as many as 3 million workers not now covered by unemployment compensation.

Mike Dabney scored 22 points to lead Rutgers to a 73-67 victory over Princeton tonight. Rutgers took a 25-23 lead with five minutes left in the first half and was never headed on the way to its sixth victory in seven games.

There is something reassuring, at a time of cosmic international disasters, about a Belgian town voting on whether to put a Romanesque tower or a Gothic steeple on its restored medieval church. The world may be going down the drain, but in Nivelles, twenty miles south of Brussels, Romanesque versus Gothic is the hot issue.

The National Securities And Research corporaton, investment managers with about $525-million under management, reported yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of 1.5 million units of a gold trust to be sold at $20 each.

Paul Laxalt, the only Republican to capture a Democratic Senate seat in last month's election, is to be sworn in tomorrow as the new Senator from Nevada.

Rutgers University today released a volume of reports on New Jersey's population, energy, housing, transportation and environmental problems that researchers hope will be used by 'state planners and political leaders in mapping solutions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- When in the Shanghai Communique of 1972 the United States and China decided that. cultural, journalistic and academic exchanges were desirable "to broaden the understanding between the two peoples," they recognized that there are essential differences between their social systems.

Chester Rohrlich, lawyer, legal author and teacher, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 22 East 88th Street. Mr. Rohrlich, a senior partner in Lehman, Rohrlich, Solomon Hoffman, specialized in corporate law.

When Mayor Beame introduced Livia Weintraub to the 1,500 merrymakers gathered at Roseland Dance City Monday night, he said he wished the city had more women like her. "Oh, please God, no," murmured a guest. "One is enough."

A Methodist missionary expelled from South Korea last Saturday for criticizing the Government of President Park Chung Hee said yesterday that he believed three other missionaries were under immediate threat of deportation and that 15 more might also be forced to leave.

Corn led a downturn in grain prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, amid discussion of the latest export inspection figures issued late Monday. The figures indicated that exports were moving at a much slower rate than a year ago.
William C. Mayer, a lawyer here for more than half a century, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old and lived at 81 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.
The Boston Bruins capitalized on Atlanta mistakes to defeat the Flames, 5-3, tonight and move within 5 points of the Buffalo Sabres, leaders in their National Hockey League division.

Under the guise of protecting the rights of a tiny Indian tribe, a bill is on its way through Congress that would drastically reduce the acreage of public lands in the Grand Canyon and virtually declare open season on the area's Desert Bighorn sheep.

Ani Kavafian has been a fixture of New York's chambermusic activity for several years now and has been giving annual solo recitals here since 1972. This year's installment, Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum, was enormously impressive.

The apparently accidental mutilation of a sacred Japanese artwork while it was clearing Customs inspection at Kennedy International Airport has shocked its Japanese trustees and briefly jeopardized the opening of a showing of their collection of religious art here.
The resignation of Roy L. Ash as director of the Office of Managenlent and Budget was announced today by the White House, and several other Cabinet-level changes were reported imminent.
President Ford, described as "concerned and very disappointed," demanded today that the United States Steel Corporation justify in writing the reasons for the price increases it announced yesterday.

Harry J. O'Donnell; the press secretary and: adviser to Governor Wilson who worked hard and unsuccessfully 'to defeat Representative Hugh L. Carey in the last months election, has received a job offer from Mr. Carey.

State Attorney Robert Eagan said today he was investigating a $1.5-million check that bounced after it was presented to the floundering Florida Blazers of the World Football League. The prosecutor said he was conducting an investigation of possible fraud and trafficking in bad checks.

Governor Wilson assessed his own brief term in office yesterday, as a "year of progress' during which he both undertook "historic initiatives" and charted a "new course, essential to our time," for state government.

Leroy Barnes, whom law-enforcement authorities described as one of .the nation's major drug traffickers, was charged yesterday with offering a $130,. 000 bribe to policemen after they stopped his Mercedes-Benz sedan in the South Bronx and allegedly found a gun in it.

Fired by the pioneering spirit that distinguished Lewis Clark, John C. Fremont and Walter O'Malley, a little band of explorers wearing hard hats of robin's-egg blue struck off yesterday into the Bronx wasteland that was Babe Ruth's playground and may some day be Catfish Hunter's. The party included eight or 10 male members of the sporting press, about the same number of photographers, one young lady and a reformed shortstop named Phil Rizzuto.

Within limits Mayor Beame's proposal for large-scale investment of city-employe pension reserves in municipal bonds offers an easy and constructive way to steady the creaky market for New York City securities. It already has had a beneficial effect in that direction by enabling Controller Goldin to assure the banking community yesterday that the city would not have to go through with a new $500-million bond issue next month.

ALTSCHUL--Alexander, M.D. The Associated Alumni of the Mount Sinal Hospital and School of Medicine records with sorrow the death of its fellow alumnus, Dr. Alexander Altschul. The Alumni extends its deep sympathy to his beloved family.
The number of new housing units started in November dropped to the lowest level in eight years, the Government reported today.

Kenneth Wells Parkinson testified at the Watergate cover-up trial today that after he had been hired by the Nixon reelection campaign to handle the legal problems resulting from the Watergate break-in, John N. Mitchell told him that there was "no connection" between the break-in and the campaign committee.
" The Missiles of October," which usurps the entire ABC schedule this evening from 8 to 11 o'clock, could be subtitled "Advertisements 'for the Memories of the Kennedy Brothers."

The Chicago Symphony Stomping and Cheering Society, New York chapter, convened at Carnegie Hall once again last night, which is to say that Sir Georg Solti brought his remarkable orchestra to town for the first of four concerts.

The Government of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, which came to power in May, easily survived its first challenge in Parliament early today.
Mrs. Michelle Ahearn, 35 years old, and her husband, Dennis, have been awarded more than $1-million damages in a suit over birth control pills that she said made her permanently blind.

The city's Board of Higher Education has approved a plan to move Bernard M. Baruch College from Manhattan to a $73-million campus to be constructed in Brooklyn.

Katherine Lilly Conroy, widow of William H. Conroy, an insurance executive, and daughter of Evan F. Lilly, a founder of the Eli Lilly, Drug Company, died Monday at her home in Washington, Conn She was 83 years old.

An ecological experiment harnessing the efforts of city agencies and community volunteers is converting piles of construction debris deposited as landfill on the shore of Jamaica Bay into a landscaped public park at tile foot of Pennisylvania Avenue in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

Involuntary Petition Filed Against: UNITED CARPET, INC., 42 Avenue A, N.Y. Petitioners are the Kane Carpet Company; the Miami Carpet Corporation and David Chassler, Inc. On Nov. 7, 1974, United Carpet made a general assignment for the benefit of creditors to Charles S. Namser to N.Y.

The City Council adopted a strict. disclosure bill yesterday requiring elected officials and all city employes earning more than $25,000 a year to report the sources of their income. The vote was 41 to i.

The Traffic Department is rearranging alternate-sideof-the-street parking schedules in a large section of the upper West Side, bounded by 84th and 97th Streets from Riverside Drive to Central Park West. No-parking times had been changed in the area several months ago to accommodate new street-sweeping routes and schedules.

Taft School of Wallingford, Conn., showing the competitive edge gained in five previous starts this season, withstood a last-period surge and beat St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., 3-2, in hockey at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

A volunteer effort to send California Christmas trees to servicemen overseas has failed, the United States Forest Service says. The service had permitted the cutting of about 2,500 Christmas trees from Tahoe National Forest under a supervised thinning and reforestation project.

State Supreme Court Justice J. Bertram Wegman died yesterday at South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, LI. He was 71 years old and lived at 10 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

Like everyone else gathered in the Theodore E. Sorensens' 19th-floor Central Park West living room last night, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis was a little shocked the first time William Devane came on the television screen portraying her former husband,President Kennedy.
The vagaries of the National Hockey League schedule gave the New YorkRangers a pushover match last night and they made the best of it, trashing the helpless Minnesota North Stars, 7-0.

The move by financial institutions other than commercial banks to offer their customers check- like accounts has spread to some credit unions. While New York State savings banks have met an obstacle-last week they were denied the right to offer so-called negotiable orders of withdrawal by an appeals court, the effort by credit unions to get into this business is just beginning.

Interest rates declined yesterday and then moved back Up as bond dealers and traders and their customers became a little disappointed that the Federal Reserve, wasn't doing more to encourage a credit market rally.
For Several years physicists seeking to detect particle' emissions from the sun's nuclear fires have felt that there seemed to be "something wrong" with it.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had achieved new highs in operating revenues for the three and 12 months ended Nov. 30. Net income for the 12-month period was also at a new high, while net for the November quarter was a record for any fourth quarter but trailed the record high set in the three months ended May 31.

Two years ago today the United States Government began an episode that will live in infamy: the Christmas bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong. It went on for eleven days. B-52's and other planes carried out 2,000 strikes, the most intensive conventional bombing campaign in history.

New York has not heard much of Charlie Ventura since he was the tenor saxaphone star of Gene Krupa's big band 30 years ago and later led the small bop combo that started the joint careers of Jackie Cain and Rov Kral.

Prescott College suspended to day all activities, and a college official announced that bank were not honoring checks from a fo undation that announced last month its willingness to meet the college's financial def icit.

Lee Scherer, a retired Navy captain who joined the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on temporary assignment 12 years ago, will be the new director of the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

The Soviet Union denied yesterday having given any specific assurances of easier emigration in return for American trade benefits and government credits. An official Tass statement said "leading circles" rejected as unacceptable any attempts to attach conditions to United States tariff reductions or otherwise interfere in internal Soviet affairs.

A 55-year-old South American condor named Long John Silver, who has been at the Bronx Zoo for 14 months, will be returned to the Milwaukee Zoo, from which he had been brought in the hope that he would mate with a condor at the Bronx Zoo named Miss MacNasty.

A group of contractors who had been working on the Third Water Tunnel project took their dispute with the city to court yesterday as the Board of Water Supply prepared for a hearing today on whether to declare them in default of its contract to build the 13.7-mile conduit.
The Soviet Union denied today that it had given any specific assurances that the conditions for emigration of Soviet citizens would be eased in return for American trade concessions and credits.

A 36-inch water main burst on the Upper West Side eary yesterday morning and forced thousands of rush-hour riders on the Seventh Avenue IRT line to leave stalled trains and hitch-hike, walk to work, or crowd on already jammed buses.

Ten large United States corporations showed profits of about $976-million but paid no Federal income taxes in 1973, Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, said today. Mr. Vanik released a study of 143 large United States corporations for the third consecutive year showing their tax liabilities.

A 43-year-old pressmap enraged at his dismissal yesterday from a Valley Stream stationery concern, fired several shots, one of them wounding a fellow employee, and was killed by police gunfire, the Nassau police said.

Oil-rich Arab countries led by Saudi Arabia have bought more than $134-million in Japanese bonds over the last year, a Japanese financial source disclosed today. The source said more than $66-million worth of bonds had been bought by the countries in the last quarter alone.
The heads of one of the proudest and oldest wine houses. in France were found guilty today of illegally doctouring their product and falsifying the pedigrees that went with the wine.

The Yankees will play fivegames against the Mets during a 31-game 1975 spring training exhibition schedule. A two-day trip by the Yankees to Puerto Rico is included. Both of these games will be played with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Half a dozen fire engines, manned by firemen, were on hand in Times Square last night for the benefit premiere of a new motion picture, "The Towering Inferno," at the National Theater, 1500 Broadway.
It wasn't a brilliant deduction on the part of Don Luce, who had scored twice for the Buffalo Sabres in their 3-2 victory over the New York Islanders tonight.
He wore out two telephones, Jim (Catfish) Hunter said with a laugh yesterday, his first as a free agent, as 20 major league clubs called to tell him they wanted him.
Volkswagenwerk, A.G., said today group sales fell 13.5 per cent to 1,867,000 vehicles in the first 11 months of 1974 while parent company sales dropped 13.2 per cent to 1,235,000.
Raids were reported today on both sides of the Israeli-Lebanese border, and gunfire was exchanged by Israelis and Arab guerrillas late in the day.

Kuwait agreed today to sell oil to the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., during the first three months of 1975 at $10.15 a barrel-in line with 1975 prices recently set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Raymond R. Schwartz, vice president for finance and planning of CBS/Records Group, a division of CBS Inc., died Monday at his home in Upper Saddle River, N. J. He was 51 years old.

SHAMROCK SPECIAL Most of us probably will never get to savor the world-renowned flavor and impact of Dublin's Abbey Theater on home ground, which is why "Home' Is the Hero" is so welcome as a somber but bright-green holiday package.

Drawing on a growing body of medical information that describes the hazards of excessive diagnostic X-rays, Ralph Nader's Health Research Group issued today a layman's guide with practical information for consumers on how to avoid unnecessary radiation exposure.

The Arnold Constable Corporation and the Kay.Corporation yesterday announced that they had signed a letter of intent providing for a $3.3-million purchase by Constable of 75 Tweed Ladies' fashion boutiques from Kay.

Two bombs exploded within a few minutes of each other tonight on a busy shopping street in the port city of Bristol. At least 20 persons were injured, and the police said they suspected the Irish Republican Army.

Nassau County's Off-Track Betting operation, due to open Feb. 1, has run into strong community resistance that could hamper the early growth of O.T.B. For the second consecutive session, volume gained in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices also were higher. Volume was down on the over-the-counter market but prices were up.

There is a childlike innocence to the work of Leonard Melfi, even his contribution to "Oh! Calcutta!", a sketch about Jack and Jill. His new show, "Horse Opera" (now at La Mama), written in collaboration with the composer John Braden, is a happy, good-natured musical celebrating life and love.

The dollar and the pound sterling recovered today from one of their worst opening rates this year and advanced slightly on world money markets. The price of gold, opening at a near-record high of $189.75 an ounce in London and Zurich, lost ground as demand slackened.

A bill adopted today by a Senate-House conference sharply limits United States Government credit for energy development in the Soviet Union. The action apparently broke an impasse on Congressional approval of an extension to lending authority of the ExportImport Bank, which makes and guarantees loans to stimulate United States foreign trade.

The city's fiscal crisis may shelve plans to construct at least three new athletic facilities for public high schools and stunt the growth of the Public Schools Athletic League football program.

Billie Jean King, the tennis ace and pioneer in the fight for greater opportunity for women in sports, signed a contract with the American Broadcasting Company yesterday to serve as a television commentator in a wide range of programs.
The Exxon Corporation challenged yesterday reports that it had been ordered by tehe Federal Energy Administration to roll back prices, because of alleged overcharges to customers.

Billie Jean King, the tennis ace and pioneer in the fight for greater opportunity for women in sports, signed a contract with the American Broadcasting Company yesterday to serve as a television commentator in a wide range of programs.

Plans to build a new community on the rolling farmland of Coventry near here-it would have been a $250-million project accommodating 20,000 peoplewere canceled today because of the depressed state of the economy.

The slowdown in the nation's economy cut sharply into individual income in November, with industrial payrolls down 2.5 per cent--or $7-billion at an annual rate-from the October, the Commerce Department reported today.

Secretary of Transportation Claude S. Brinegar announced his resignation today, effective Feb. 1. He thus became the third Cabinet-level holdover from the Nixon Administration to resign since last Friday.

Federal Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. declined today to cite for criminal contempt the three Boston School Committee members who had defied his order by refusing to approve a citywide busing plan to achieve school desegregation for next fall.

Cairo's latest statement of terms for making peace with Israel seem on their face ill-timed in presentation and absurd in content. A sweeping official declaration came without warning last week, in the midst of a sensitive and far less ambitious mediation effort by Secretary of State Kissinger.

Executives of the United Mine Workers approved a wage-contract proposal today covering 4,500 striking mine construction workers and submitted the pact for a vote, probably by this weekend, according to a Federal mediation spokesman.
In a suprise move, the New York football Giants have made an agreement to play their 1975 home games at Shea Stadium and obtained an option to play their 1976 games at Yankee Stadium.

The General Motors Corporation, reflecting one of the severest declines in the automobile industry since World War II, announced today additional layoffs and production cutbacks for the first quarter of 1975.

Mayor Beame's decision to stop work on the Second Avenue subway in order to focus limited funds on higher transit priorities represents a realistic adjustment to hard times-hard times for the city and for its deficit-ridden and deteriorating transit system.

A State Supreme Court. justice reserved decision in Manhattan yesterday on whether a news reporter should be jersey trial involving murders ganized crime. Acting Justice George Roberts said he would make known his decision in the first week of January.

France will begin building a nuclear-powered helicopter carrier next April, French navy officials said today. The carrier, which will have a crew of 840, will carry 25 small Lynx helicopters or 10 large Super Frelon helicopters for antisubmarine duties.

Kenneth Wells Parkinson insisted today at the Watergate cover-up trial that he had not knowingly played any role in the payments of cash to the Watergate burglars, He conceded, however, that he had given inaccurate testimony before a grand jury about one aspect of the case.
President Ford found himself in the midst of a controversy today over his decision to rent a larger and more secure home for his skiing holiday in Vail, Colo.

Oil-rich Arab countries led by Saudi Arabia have bought more than $134-million in Japanese bonds over the last year, a Japanese financial source disclosed today. The source said more than $66-million worth of bonds had been bought by the countries in the last quarter alone.

The General Assembly. recessed its 29th session( tonight with its president, Foreighth Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, declaring that it had been a historic, perhaps c revolutionary, meeting.

Finley had breached the stipulation in his $100,000 contract that $50,000 be paid to an insurance firm as deferred income, the Oakland A's right-handed pitcher phoned J. Carlton Cherry, his attorney in Ahoskie, N. C. "Do you think, I'm a free agent?" Catfish asked.

The Environmental Protection Agency announced today a survey of organic chemicals in the drinking water of 80 cities beginning with Philadelphia, Seattle, Miami, Cincinnati and Ottumwa, Iowa.

A major split has reportedly developed in the Portuguese coalition Government following the jailing of 11 prominent businessmen. President Francisco da Costa-Gomes is said to be trying to prevent the Cabinet from breaking up.

Mayor Beame proposed legislation yesterday that would permit landlords of as many as 900,000 rent-controlled apartments here to get monthly rent rises of up to $3 a room next year, if they can show that this year's sharply higher fuel costs have exceeded a certain level.

The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for final debate on, and probable confirmation of, Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination as Vice President. It voted to limit floor debate tomorrow on the nomination to six hours.

Governor-elect Carey is now engaged in putting together his administration, to take office in January Of the many appointments that should be made without ulterior political consideration, one of the more significant is that of Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation.

John Havlicek scored 27 points tonight as the Boston Celtics overpowered the Philadelphia 76ers, 131-99, at the Spectrum in a National Basketball Association game. The 32-point loss was the second worse of the season for the 76ers.

Whatever shock value there may be in a Senate subcommittee's charge that nationwide maltreatment of the elderly in nursing homes reflects "the deeply negative attitude toward aging in the United States," the cure for such abuses in New York and other states lies in specific governmental action and not in societal selfflagellation.

A House-Senate conference committee agreed tonight on the final version of the trade: reform bill despite a last-minute disavowal by Moscow of any deal linking trade concessions to easier emigration from the Soviet Union.

All through this land, skiarea operators are preparing for their biggest pre-holiday invasion in, at least five years. Conditions in this southern tier region of the Green Mountain state are mostly excellent,
Montreal Stable's Startahemp overtook FrankieAdams in the stretch yesterday and then outdueled Nostrum in the final 50 yards to win the $38,250 Sport Page Handicap by a head at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON--As the world staggers from one economic disaster to another, questions arise: Whose fault is it? Are economists or politicians to blame? Naturally enough, both sides tend to blame each other.
Nearly 700,000 more Americans applied for unemployment insurance benefits during the first week of December, the Labor Department reported today.
A British doctor and two nurses will leave here next week for the Iranian-Iraqi frontier to give medical help to thousands of Kurds who have been fleeing into Iran, some pursued by Iraqi bombers.

A United States military court in Berlin sentenced a soldier from Hoboken, N. J., today to 60 days at hard labor, fined him and stripped him of his rank for disobeying an officer's order to get a haircut.

President Anwar el-Sadat is continuing to voice a sense of urgency about United States peace efforts in the Middle. East and warning that the time is running out for the American step-by-step approach.

The National Conference on Soviet Jewry, representing 38 national . organizations and more than 100 Jewish communities, expressed "shock and consternation," after learning of the statement by the Soviet press agency Tass denying an agreement with the United States on the issue of emigration.

The defending champion, Plero Gros of Italy, won his second World Cup giant slalom of the season today by a margin of seven-tenths of a second over Greg Jones of Tahoe City, Calif., who came out of the pack to ski the fastest run of the day in the two-heat event.

The team that gets no respect until it's time for the National Football League draft--the Black College allAmerica team -- was announced at the Essex House yesterday, and this year's featured attractions were Walter Payton, Jackson State running back, and Gary (Big Hands) Johnson, Grambling defensive tackle.

THE UNDERSTUDY By Elia Kazan. 347 pages. Stein Day. $8.95. I have always hated the phrase "compulsively readable" - and not just for grammatical reasons-yet this is precisely what comes to mind when I try to sum up my feelings about Elia Kazan's new novel, "The Understudy." It expresses my ambivalence about the book and also conveys the fact that I read it as if I had no choice.

Despite poor response to the program, Charles E. Goodell, chairman of the Presidential Clemency Board, held out little hope today that President Ford ford might extend next month's deadline for pardon applications by draft evaders and deserters.
William D. Lamborn, president of Lamborn Co., Inc., international sugar brokers here, died Sunday after a fall in his home in Rye, N. Y. He was 51 years old and lived at 70 Overlook Place.

A former top executive of the Dairylea milk cooperative who has been listed as fugitive from justice for the last three weeks appeared in an Albany courtroom yesterday and pleaded not guilty to a charge that he was a conspirator in the Dairylea milk-adulteration case.

A. Gerdes Kuhbach, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and $10,000a-year raise last week, increasing his salary New Jersey, was given a to $80,000 a year, a Port Authority spokesman said last night.

Several weeks ago, in apparent response to critical comment about Yonkers, Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli issued a statement to correct the "considerable misunderstanding" about his office and the city. It stated that "Mayor Matrinelli is Republican, the city's population is growing and approaching a quarter of a million, it is the fourth largest city in the state and the only major city with a Republican mayor."

CBS Inc. announced yesterday a contribution of $1-million to public television, largely to support fund-raising and efforts to increase contributions from viewers.
Attorney General Louis J Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he would seek the impaneling of a special grand jury t0 investigate alleged crimes ir the nursing-home industry.

Montreal International Airport was shut down today by striking snow-removal crews, disrupting the travel plans of tens of thousands of persons, An airport spokesman said about 275 maintenance workers had walked off the job at 12:01 A.M. for a 24-hour "study session." They want higher pay.

One hundred and twenty-six deer were killed during the sixday hunt in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge that ended yesterday at 5 P.M., according to a refuge spokesman.

A former secretary of the Brooklyn Democratic committee and a former Democratic party fund-raiser have been indicted by a special grand jury in Brooklyn on charges that they stole more than $100,000 from the party's annual dinner funds, Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, announced yesterday.

In a departure from tradition, employees of state and city courts in all boroughs of the city and in the neighboring counties will be required this year to take vacations during the quiet holiday. season and to charge that time against their vacations.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he would seek the im- part paneling of a special grand jury to investigate alleged crimes in the nursing-home industry.
Robert Mellish quit as chief whip of the Labor Government today but withdrew his resignation nine hours later after a meeting with Prime Minister Harold Wilson.

Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan today ruled illegal the city's plan to retire 860 city employes aged 63 to 65 before their mandatory retirement age of 65.The plan would have saved the jobs of 860 younger civil servants.
The Atomic Energy Commission is investigating three Incidents, involving plutonium and uranium, that occurred at an Oklahoma nuclear facility on Monday.

Harry Hooper, the oldest member of the Baseball Hall of Fame, died yesterday at the age of 87. He leaves 2 sons, Harry Jr. and John; a. daughter, Marie Strain; 12 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren.
By far the best-known English Cookbook is Hannah Glasse's modestly titled "The Art of Cookery, Made Plain and Easy: Which far exceeds any Thing of the Kind ever published."

Mayor Beame yesterday increased from 22 to 27 the membership on his task force on child abuse and neglect and directed the group to evaluate "thoroughly" child- protective and rehabilitative services offered by the city and private agencies.

Conditions for realistic negotiations aimed at producing both a humanitarian and a political remedy for the agonies of Cyprus seem better now than at any time since mid-August, just prior to Turkey's massive invasion of the island. Even the fact that Turkey has only a caretaker Government no longer appears an insurmountable obstacle to serious Cyprus talks.

Old friends of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are turning up in increasing numbers. Yesterday gifts from 215 donors totaling $11,007 were recorded. The donations, which will help the destitute, the ill and the lonely, brought the overal ltotal of the 63d annual appeal to $511,773.32.
A last-ditch legislative effort to block construction of a giant hydroelectric project on the New River on the VirginiaNorth Carolina border was defeated tonight in the House of Representatives.
Paul John Knowles charged with seven murders in three states and a possible suspect in at least seven more, was killed today as he sought to escape from officers in a police car.
Arab investors have bought a 20.7 per cent share in one of Britain's biggest construction concerns in a deal worth more than $9.2-million, it was announced today.

For more than half a century bridge teachers-have been trying in vain to eradicate the old wives' tale that calls for the opening lead of the highest card of partner's suit. As a result of this failure, players in home games continue to hurl tricks at gratified declarers by leading unsupported kings, queens and jacks from three-card or four-card holdings in their partners' suits.
On the night of Nov. 2, when President Ford was speaking in an auditorium in Wichita, Kan., a ragtag band of youths marched through the cold rain chanting: "N-I-X-O-N . . What does it spell? Ford!"

State Superior Court Judge George Y. Schoch affirmed today his earlier ruling that Gerardo Catena, a reputed Mafia leader who has been jailed for nearly five years on civil contempt charges, should be freed on the ground that further imprisonment will not make him "break his silence."

A 36-inch water main burst on the Upper West Side early yesterday morning and forced thousands of rush-hour riders on the Seventh Avenue IRT line to leave stalled trains and hitch-hike, walk to work, or crowd on already-jammed buses.
George Scott and Mike Hegan, first-basemen, are among six players who have signed contracts today with the Milwaukee Brewers of the American League.
In a surprise move, the New York football Giants have made an agreement to play their 1975 home games at Shea Stadium and obtained an option to play their 1976 games at Yankee Stadium.

The Food and Drug Administration plans/ to approve the permanent use of an artificial food coloring although some of the agency's own scientists say there are questions about whether it may cause cancer and fetal death.

The Yankees will play fivegames against the Mets during a 31-game 1975 spring training exhibition schedule. A two-day trip by the Yankees to Puerto Rico is included. Both of these games will be played with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Brenda Workman has now met 310 men as the result of an ad she placed about herself in a dating magazine called The Black Book. The last time we heard from her, the number was 300.

Darryl Brown's 28 points and 16 rebounds led Fordham to an 85-77 victory over City College last night in the. losers' gym. Kevin Brown broke his Fordham assist record, set earlier this year, with 14 in a game that was marked by good shooting on both sides.

OF MICE AND MEN, a play by John Steinbeck. Directed by Edwin Sherin; setting, costumes and lighting by Wilham and Jean Eckart; production stage manager, Harry Young. Presented by Elliott Martin, in association with Mortlmer Levitt. At the Brooks Atkinson Jheater, 256 West 47th Street.

The stock market staged a moderate advance yesterday in stepped up trading despite some negative economic developments. Brokers noted that there was little specific news to account for the upswing except recent growing indications that the Federal Reserve Board was easing its monetary retraints.

"They keep paving over everything - nobody knows nothing." That was the assessment of a Department of Water Resources engineer when his Commissioner, Charles Samowitz, wondered out loud why water was still gushing from an 8-foot-square crater on the west side of 84th Street three hours after a 32inch water main burst.

Five counselors waiting behind desks without phones in a vast, colorless room, and using. a card file of job openings at 44 organizations, constitute the city's primary help to the thousands of employes who will lose their jobs in Mayor Beame's plan to balance. the city budget.
A slowdown in world economic activity and continued conservation efforts -whether voluntary or induced by higher priced petroleum products have combined to create a worldwide oil surplus.

Some 600 custodial workers in Jersey City's school system plan to strike today to protest stalled contract negotiations, a union spokesman said. Robert Jastrebski, president of Local 2622 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal employes, said picket lines would go up this morning in front of the city's 40 elementary and high schools.

Kathleen Ann Smith was married yesterday to Donald Wayne Carson of the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine Moore. Edward Drury, president of the Temple' of. the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Kensington, Md., performed the Mormon ceremony at the temple.

Both houses of the Legislature will reconvene here tomorrow in what Democratic leaders have described as a final attempt to reach agreement on an income tax plan for a new system of financing public schools in New Jersey.

Rose Borgenicht Friedman, widow of Dr. E. David Friedman, professor of neurology at the New York University Medical School, died Tuesday at her home. She was 86 years old and lived at 40 East 89th Street.

Sehator Mark O. Hatfield, assailing what he called a lack of leadership in the Administration, called today for an effort on the scale of that led by Herbert Hoover during and after World War I to feed the hungry and starving in nations threattened by famine.

The Pacific Gas Electric Company has applied to the United States Department of the Interior for right-of-way permits to cross Federal lands with a new pipeline that would bring natural gas from the Arctic.

Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain will hold talks with President Ford here Jan. 30, the White House announced today. It said they would discuss economic and energy problems, the Atlantic Alliance, the Middle East and East-West relations.

The General Motors Corporatioin, reflecting one of the severest declines in the automobile industry since World War II, announced today additional layoffs and production cutbacks for the first quarter of 1975.

A shopper in a branch of a leading supermarket chain yesterday faced the problem of deciding among extralarge eggs at $1.05 a dozen, large at 97 cents and medium at 89 cents. All were Grade A.

The police in three towns in this Somerset County area joined today with the county Prosecutors office in trying to unravel the mystery of a 20year-old youth who stabbed his father, mother and sister Tuesday morning and later died in an automobile accident.

A New York University graduate student was stabbed repeatedly by an assailant in his university-sponsored apartment at 1 Fifth Avenue, little more than a day after a woman student was raped during a robbery by three intruders in the same building.

Eight months after the premiere of the Jerome RobbinsLeonard Bernstein dance version of S. Ansky's Hasidic play, "The Dybbuk," comes Pearl Lang's own variation on the theme, "The Possessed," subtitled "The Dybbuk," which is scheduled for its world premiere at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A.

Mrs. Lawrence A. Crail, who as Benedict Talbot had been a well-known fashion stylist here for many years, died Monday at her home at the Elms Inn in Ridgefield, Conn. She was 93 years old.

The end of the Vietnam war and the military draft has not diminished the need of the 5.5 million members of the American military community for the "home away from home" that the United Service 'Organization Provides.

The Houston International Tournament, now going on at the Seminar Center of the Continental Houston Motor Hotel, ran four rounds of its scheduled 11 before the first upset was tallied. Then Julio Kaplan, formerly of Puerto Rico and now living in Far. Rockaway, Queens, bagged the Czech grandmaster Vlastimil Jansa, one of the four foreign entrants favored to take the first prize.

The deficit in the basic United States balance of payments deepened to $3.6-billion in the third quarter from $2.5-billion in the second, the Commerce Department reported today.
A police official in Amsterdam today identified a Lebanese citizen, Aime Nassif, 62 years old, as a key figure in an attempt to defraud the City of Los Angeles of more than $800,000.

A House-Senate conference committee agreed tonight on the final version of the trade reform bill despite a last-minute disavowal by Moscow of any deal linking trade concessions to easier emigration from the Soviet Union.

When the General Assembly suspended its annual session tonight, instead of formally closing it, delegates skipped the traditional minute of "silent prayer or meditation," but. this year they end the people at home will need considerably more considerable more time for reflection on what the organization means to them, and where it is going.

Grain prices took their cue yesterday mainly from offstage--when the Dow Jones average rose, so did the grains. Soybeans also moved up, but there the influence came from a sharply higher soybean oil price bid yesterday in the Gulf port area because of export demand.

Paul Laxalt was sworn in today as Nevada's junior Senator. The 52 year-old Republican thus became the first Senator elected last month to take office He gained seniority over the other freshmen Senators, who are scheduled to assume office Jan. 3.

A. Woodson Taulbee, president of Woodson Wallpapers, Inc. died Monday at his home, 172 East 61st Street. He was 66 years old. Mr. Taulbee, who established his company in 1956, was given credit for introducing pure and vivid colors to wallpaper, which until then had been dominated by traditional pastel colors.
