France will begin building a nuclear-powered helicopter carrier next April, French navy officials said today. The carrier, which will have a crewof 840, will carry 25 small Lynx helicopters or 10 large Super Frelon helicopters for antisubmarine duties.
Portugal will grant independence to the Cape Verde Islands next July 5, Antonio de Almeida Santos, the minister in charge of African affairs, announced today.

Lanny McDonald scored a pair of goals and earned an assist on Errol Thompson's tally to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in the National Hockey League.

Following is a chronology De of developments on the questions of trade benefits to ha the Soviet Union and Soviet emigration: October, 1972-The United States and the Soviet Union sign a trade agreement in which the Russians agree to repay Lend-Lease debts and the Nixon Administration agrees to seek nondiscriminatory tariffs for Russian goods.

Three Australians, John Newcombe, Ken Rosewall and Tony Roche, led the advance today into the men's quarterfinals at the New South Wales tennis tournament. Newcombe beat a fellow Aussie, Colin Dibley, 6-4, 6-3; Rosewall outlasted Raz Reid of Greenville, S.C., 7-6, 4-6, 6-2, and Roche eliminated Ulli Martin of West Germany, 6-2, 7-5.

A three-judge Federal court ruled today that the New Hampshire Ballot Law Comnmission could continue its review of the state's disputed United States Senate contest. The Democratic candidate for the seat, John A. Durkin, who won the official state recount by 10 votes, had asked the court to rule unconstitutional the ballot commission's review of the recount.

South Africa is considering withdrawal from the United Nations as a result of the latest United Nations SecurityCouncil call that the government relinquish control of South-West Africa, or Namibia, Foreign Minister Hilgard Muller said tonight.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation in Los Angeles said yesterday that it was selling the major part of its European retail marketing assets to Elf Union, S. A., of France for about $25-million.

A second key witness for the defense in. the perjury trial of Judge Martin Ginsberg said today he had been alone with Judge Ginsberg, then an Assemblyman, at the time he allegedly received part of a bribe.
Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that President Ford was "giving serious consideration" to signing the Federal strip mine control bill instead of vetoing it as promised.

A spokesman for the nation's scheduled airlines said yesterday that his industry would press Congress next year to reduce the 8 per cent Federal excise tax on airline tickets and air cargo waybills in order to stimulate slumping air travel.

Robert S. Benjamin has been elected chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, replacing Dr. James R. Killian Jr., who announced his resignation on Monday. Dr. Killian said he would keep his seat' on the board'until his replacement was confirmed by the Senate.

The Supreme Court ruled today that a woman who was the subject of "calculated falsehoods" in a newspaper account of her home and children could collect damages for invasion of privacy despite contentions that press freedom would suffer from such a policy.
Rabbi Samuel I. Korff, prominent in: New England Jewish affairs, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 61 years old and lived in Newton. Mass.

College scouts are knocking on doors and writing persuasive literature to the many football prospects produced by the recent New Jersey campaign. Actually, as is often the case, the best are more than football prospects. Most of them are as competent in one or more other sports, an obvious bonus for the schools that ultimately get them.
President Ford found himself in the midst of a controversy today over his decision to rent a larger and more secure home for his skiing holiday in Vail, Colo.

International The Soviet Union denied yesterday having given any specific assurances of easier emigration in return for American trade benefits and government credits. An official Tass statement said "leading circles" rejected as unacceptable any attempts to attach conditions to United States tariff reductions or otherwise interfere in internal Soviet affairs.

Dr. Irving Berchuck, superintendent of Community School District 24 in Queens, will be. come top assistant to Deputy School Chancellor Bernard R. Gifford as part of a continuing effort to strengthen management of the school system and curb abuses in the districts.

To the Editor: I was very surprised to read your Dec. 5 editorial praising the U.S. Treasury's plan to sell two million ounces of gold on Jan. 6. I realize that it is to the Government's advantage to prevent a further deterioration in our balance-of-payments position;

Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz persuaded the Delaware River Port Authority today to reject Virginia:s high bid for the authority:s last ferryboat and reopen the bidding to allow Gloucester County an opportunity to buy it.
The House of Representatives today passed and sent to the White House a bill authorizing $2.69billion in foreign aid during the fiscal year ending next June 30; The vote was 209 to 189.

The House passed today a $4-billion bill to provide 111,000 public service jobs and to extend unemployment benefits to jobless workers. The appropriations bill was sent to the Senate, where passage was believed likely tomorrow.

A Justice Department official in Montgomery, Ala., has confirmed that Air Force buses are being used to transport the children of military personnel at Maxwell Air Force Base to some all-white or nominally integrated private schools in the area.

Although the Ford Administration has repeatedly emphasized its intention to reduce United States dependence on "unreliable sources" of oil, the nation imported more oil from the Arab countries from June through October than it did during the same period last year before the Arab oil embargo, according to a study by an industry - supported research group.

Wallace LaPrade, the special Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who headed the investigation of the John Calzadilla kidnapping case, was promoted to a top Washington post today as one of 10 assistant F.B.I. directors.

A. Gerdes Kuhbach, executive director of the Port Authorjty of New York and New Jersey, was given a 10,000-a-year raise last week, increasing his salary to $80,000 a year, a Port Authority spokesman said last night.
Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey announced yesterday the appointment of Deputy Mayor Judah Gribetz as counsel to the Governor.
A fight by rivals for a girl friend last evening ended with one college student critically wounded with an axe and another under arrest for attempted murder.

"Hearts and Minds," the controversial documentary study of United States involvement in Vietnam, failed to open today because the recently organized production company that acquired it could not come up with $1million to buy it from the original distributor, Columbia Pictures.

With ownership of gold becoming legal in the United States Dec. 31, the experience of Japan in taking a similar step 20 months ago might be reccalled: A gold fever developed, but it proved shortlived.

While Gabe Paul was back in New York playing Santa Claus at a Yankee Christmas party, the team's scouting director, Clyde Kluttz, was in Ahoskie, N.C., yesterday telling Jim (Catfish) Hunter how wonderful the big city was for right-handed pitchers.

The Soviet Union has followed up yesterday's disavowal of deal on emigration for trade benefits with a private denunciation of Congressional adoption of a ceiling on Export-Import Bank credits to Moscow.
Mutual fund sales outpaced redemptions in November for the seventh straight month, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

The Chrysler Corporation said today it was recalling 583 light. duty trucks because of a defect that has resulted in two reports of front wheels falling off. Chrysler said there had been no collisions or injuries as a result of the defect.

Plans for a controversial 30story office and apartment building opposite Lincoln Center were approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday by a 16-to-6 vote with the majority expressing misgivings and the minority charging that the board was taking part in a charade.

Bessie Frenkel Klenosky, for more than 35 years a fundraiser and production chief for the American Red Cross, died Wednesday at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. She was 75 years old and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.

The city and a group of leaders representing the municipal unions agreed yesterday to seek voluntary retirements of city employes aged 63 to 70 to save the jobs of 860 younger employes. The latter are scheduled to be dismissed in the budgetcutting layoffs recently announced by Mayor Beame.

The Capitol Building smells of fresh paint. With a certain aimlessness, the outgoing Republicans chat in the marble corridors. They clean out desks. With a certain polite diffidence, the incoming Democrats arrange to move in.
Moon Se Kwang was hanged today in a Seoul prison for killing the wife of President Park Chung Hee during an attempt to assassinate her husband.

Nelson Rockefeller has become the second man confirmed as Vice President of the United States under the terms of the 25th Amendment, and some of his opponents are inclined to blame the amendment itself for having made his nomination possible.
STOCKHOLM - Sometime soon, unless he changes his mind, a cheerful, cultivated man who wears pastel-colored jackets and pale-green shirts will retire as head of the Swedish Communist party.
Pope Paul VI said in a special message today that progress had been made toward unity and peace in the world. Nevertheless, "many, very many problems still remain potentially open," he warned.
The Legislature adjourned for the year this evening without approving a new system of financing public schools in Pew Jersey, thus defying a State Supreme Court order to do so by Dec. 31.

Bill Barber notched his 14th and 15th goals and Ross Lonsberry scored twice within 'two minutes as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-1, for their ninth straight triumph tonight at the Spectrum.

The State Commuter Operating Agency today announced plans for public hearings on 25 per cent fare increases being sought by four debt-ridden railroads serving New Jersey commuters. An armed holdup at a suburban supermarket that led to the taking of about 40 hostages ended early today when the gunmen freed their prisoners and surrendered, the police said.
The state Board of Law Examiners announced today that 2,616 applicants-a record numberhad passed the written examination for admission to the bar at the examinations held last July 23 and 24.

Pierre Boulez put his fluoroscopic method on four scores last night in Fisher Hall. He led the New York Philharmonic in Handel's "Water Music," Schumann's First Symphony, the Violin Concerto No. 2 by Szymanowski and Ravel's "Bolero."
On July 31, 1971, George Harrison presented two charity shows to help Bangladesh refugees. Other players included Ravi Shanker, Bob Dylan, Ringo Starr, Leon Russell, Billy Preston and Eric Clapton.
An Army private was sentenced to five months' confinement at hard labor today and was reduced to the lowest rank by a military court for failing to have his hair cut.

It might seem that all department store Santa Clauses are created equal, but visits to a number of major department stores in the city dispelled that notion. Some of the places try hard, others try hardly at all.
Eighteen - year- old Michael Walsh, convicted of manslaughter in the stabbing death of an acquaintance he believed had given drugs to his girlfriend, has been placed on probation.
The dollar rallied slightly today from the all-time lows in European markets earlier in the week. Dealers said the recovery was due largely to several central banks supporting the currency.

Teddy Topper, a salesman from Kew Gardens, Queens, bought a Chevy Nova last September for his daughter, Mrs. Jane Wolin. Mrs. Wolin was driving it along the Belt Parkway the other day when it sputtered, died, and refused. to move.

A private attorney who worked for the nation's largest dairy cooperative was indicted today in connection with helping funnel $13,400 in illegal contributions to the 1970 reelection campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.
Annamarie Proell, the World Cup leader from Austria, won the first women's parallel ski race in Europe today. She defeated Christa Zechmeister of West Germany in the final.

EIIis Rainsberger, the offensive coordinator at Wisconsin and the last of nine coaches interviewed, has accepted the head football coaching job at Kansas State, replacing Vince Gibson, who resigned after eight years.

Though Samuel C. Dunton has been a professional photographer for 40 years, he has never asked a subject to "Smile, please." And with good reason.

Congress moved toward possible final passage tonight of the sweeping trade reform bill, hammered into final shape by, Senate and House conferees. Good majorities for passage appear assured in both houses.

Senate passage of a bill that would extend United States fisheries jurisdiction from 12 to 200 miles off shore is an understandable but ill-advised reflection of the legitimate concern of American fishermen over the depletion of coastal stocks. Consumer prices rose strongly again in November, the Labor Department reported today. Paper recycling has become a victim of the recession. A number of dealers who used to buy those newspapers you stacked in the cellar don't want them any more. Dr. Ellen Deborah Ellis, founder and first chairman of the political science department at Mount Holyoke College, died Friday in Wallingford, Pa., where she lived. Her age was 96.

The Supreme Court's validation of the Northeast rail reorganization law removes the last legal roadblock to creation of a viable transportation network out of the Penn Central and other bankrupt roads. Rick Forzano, who took over the Detroit Lions head coaching job; when Don McCafferty died last July and directed the team to a 7-7 season signed a three-year contract today.
Four men were held on homicide, kidnapping and conspiracy charges today in connection with a holdup in Camden that was followed by a murder here.

An investigator hired by the oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union has disputed the theory of the Oklahoma Highway Patrol about the death of Karen Silkwood, 28 years old, who had raised safety questions about a plutonium processing plant.
The lack of a way to get to work is a greater cause of unemployment in a poor rural community than the so-called "culture of poverty," a government-sponsored study has concluded.

Extra trains will operate on both Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve to handle the expected early departure from Pennsylvania Station of regular commuters, the Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday.

Dr. Kate Barber Winton, who with her late husband, Dr. Andrew L. Winton, published several books analyzing the structure and composition of foods, died Saturday in the Hewitt Memorial Hospital in Shelton, Conn.

Yankee Coaching Staff Retained The New York Yankees announced yesterday that all four coaches who served under Manager Bill Virdon last season will return in 1975. They are Elston Howard, first base coach; Dick Howser, third base; Whitey Ford, pitching coach, and Mel Wright, bullpen coach. Howard and Howser have been coaches since 1969. Virdon personally asked all of them to return.

John W. Ryan Jr., who was Chief Judge of the Buffalo City Court from 1950 to 1958, and then until his retirement in 1972 a member of the State Investigation Commission, died Friday at his home in suburban Orchard Park. He was 69 years old.

(1970), both by the young American director Brian De Palma, to be followed by works from Italy, France, Germany, Czechoslovakia, Japan and by other American entries.

To the Editor: There is clear evidence that, as chief U.S. delegate John A. Scali warned the U.N. General Assembly on Dec. 6, support for the U.N. among the American people is eroding. One reason for this is the fact that in the past year the U.N. General Assembly has practiced selective outrage at violations of human rights.

Three major steel companies say they will fight proposed Government regulations that would force them to stop dumping more than a ton of cyanide a day into the Monotigahela River.
The survivors of a Beaumont man who was sucked out the broken window of an airplane flying over New Mexico have filed a $3.7-million suit against National Airlines, Inc.

Over the last decade there have been many attempts to start what might be termed "instantn" big jazz bands. The technique is to begin as a rehearsal band meeting once a week, stock it from the pool of skilled studio musicians available in New York and play charts by arrangers who have made some reputation writing for other big bands.

NEWARK-With the blessing of Secretary of State Kissinger and the State Department, the Newark Museum bas quietly returned an important art work that had been stolen in Syria and then smuggled out of that country. The mosaic returned to Syria by the Newark Museum. It was found to have been stolen from an ancient palace, after the museum had bought it from a dealer here.
One of the smallest crowds in the Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl 16-year history and a national television audience saw two games for the price of one at the Astrodome last night.

Slumping automobile sales have. forced C. H. Masland Sons, one of the nation's largest carpet manufacturers, to shut down its Carlisle, Pa., plant for two weeks.

Two armed men and their accomplices shot to death one of three men taking more than $10,000 in cash from a bank to a Brooklyn army and navy store yesterday, seized the money and escaped in two automobiles, one of which they seized on the spot after removing its two occupants.

Sales of the nation's leading chain stores in November gained 5.5 per cent from November, 1973, the smallest increase since April, 1972, when the gain was 5.1 per cent.

The New York Board of Rab bis said yesterday that Rabbi David Haymovitz, who resigned a $32,000-a-year position with the Human Resources Administration, had been "literally hounded" out of office, and suggested that the "attack" upon him "was an attack on the Jewish community."

Ellsworth Van Graafeiland, a former president of the New York State Bar Association, and Henry Bramwell, a Brooklyn Civil Court Judge, were both confirmed as Federal judges by the United States Senate last Friday.

Maurice Fischer, former city editor and assistant to the editor of The Chicago Daily News, died yesterday. He was 71 years old. Mr. Fischer, who was known as "Ritz," had suffered a heart attack some weeks ago.

A former Federal housing official, William Pelski, a key witness in the bribery case against former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, has been released from jail.

Carl F. Stover has been appointed Director of Bicentennial Resources Development for the National Endowment for the Arts. He will be responsible for guiding the Endowment's involvements in the observance of the bicentennial of the American Revolution.

Just three months ago, Harry J. O'Donnell, speaking on behalf of Governor Wilson, publicly described a speech my Hugh L. Carey as "a perfect example of political pollution." After Jan. 1, if anyone should discern a pollutant in one of Governor Carey's speeches, Mr. O'Donnell will have only himself to blame.

The Christmas shopping season wound up yesterday after three strong days, fulfilling many retailers' hopes that the brisk finish of the 22-day season would offset a persistent earlier lag. The New York Times Shoppers at the Sears department store at the Paramus Park Mall in New Jersey. Lastminute shopping picked up sales for the nation's retailers at the end of a slow season.

Investigations of recent plane crashes suggest that there has been an unacceptable relaxation of precautions at the controls. The airlines' superb safety record of recent years may itself have contributed to a more cavalier attitude toward the safety manual. This year's record of 461 fatalities-the worst since 1960-underscores the need for instant tightening of procedures.

Churchgoing in the United States in 1974 remained at the same level as in the three previous years, with 40 per cent of adults of all faiths attending a place of worship in a typical week, the Gallup Poll reports.

Julius Rykovich, a former Chicago Bears football player, died yesterday of cancer. He was 51 years old. Mr. Rykovich was a halfback on the 1943 University of Notre Dame football team.

Two patrolmen found two 10-year-old boys sneaking from a city park with a freshly cut evergreen tree in tow, local policemen said today. The officers suspected the tree had been cut illegally in the park and stopped the youths for questioning.

The Soviet grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi publicly apologized today for his disparaging remarks last month about his victorious rival, Anatoly Karpov, following their match, which left Karpov as the challenger for the world chess title.

When Harry Ryttenberg spotted Jay Robbins running out of his Bronx real-estate office at 200 East 170th Street in his underwear yesterday, "it immediately aroused my suspicions-even though it was Christmas Eve."

Early last September, the twostory house at 440 Stoneford Street in East Oakland was put up for sale by the Department of Housing and Urban Development here. The price of the house was only $11,500 because it had been vacant for more than a year and needed repair work.

The council of nine chiefs of the Mohawk nation will hold an inquiry today into shootings that have taken place on a 612acre Adirondack site that the Indians claim as their sovereign soil and thus beyond the juris. diction of United States and New York Law.

The F.B.I. said yesterday that it had arrested a 23-year-old man who lived in the Santa Cruz Mountains near San Jose, Calif., and whom it described as the "commuter bandit" who flew from California to New York to rob banks.

Owners of World Team Tennis will be searching for new money under their Christmas trees tomorrow to avoid folding before the league's second season, which begins in May.

It will be cloudy and seasonable in the Northeast today; light snow or flurries may develop over New England. Except for Florida where skies will be clear, rain will occur from the Middle and South Atlantic States to Ohio, the Gulf Coast and eastern Texas; clouds will continue westward to Illinois and Minnesota.
Investigators rummaged through Christmas presents and wreckage today in an effort to determine the cause of a plane crash yesterday that killed three North Carolina men on ,their way to Houston.
Toyota, the auto manufacturer, will cut its planed 'capital expenditures in half in the. next fiscal year because of a slump in domestic sales, the company said yesterday.

United States companies have signed 12 oil exploration agreements with Egypt in recent days, a Treasury official reported today. Assistant Secretary Gerald L. Parsky said the agreements contemplated outlays of $300million over 8 to 12 years.
Nicholas B. Sharry, New England's No. I ranked doubles tennis player for more than 20 years, died today when the car he was driving left the highway and struck a tree. He was 58 years old.

Enacting a ceremony introduced by Pope Paul II in 1475, Pope Paul VI opened the Holy Year yesterday in Rome by tapping the huge marble door of St. Peter's Basilica.

The prospect of trading in gold, whether directly through the purchase of bullion or indirectly through the various commodities exchanges, is perhaps the most exciting new investment game to come alone since silver was freed for trading on June 12, 1963.

A convicted stock manipulator who turned Government informer and imputed wrongdoing to judges in New York and Boston has been revealed as the informant who exposed a scheme to defraud the City of Los Angeles of millions of dollars.

Representatives of United Air Lines pilots have rejected a proposed contract that would have increased pay for senior pilots by $14,000 to $80,616, over the next 31 months. The reason for the rejection was not immediately revealed.

United States Steel has a Christmas present of sorts for the nation. It is not going to raise prices on its major products quite as much as it originally intended. Since steel is so basic to the cost of thousands of other products, the trimming of the projected increase represents a moderate victory for the moderate approach to an incomes policy on which President Ford relies to curb inflation.

Hoyt Brawner, athletic director at the University of Denver since 1962, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.
The 91-foot American aluminum-hulled ketch Ondine III is favored for both line honors and the race record in the Sydney-Hobart sailing race, which starts Thursday.

The package of concessions on Berlin offered by East Germany in exchange for a five-year extension of traditional trade credits from West Germany represents a breakthrough of major importance. It is further evidence, already reflected in Bonn's negotiations with the Soviet Union, that Chancellor Schmidt's insistence on linking the problems of Berlin to negotiations on trade and tech. nologv with Communist countries is paying off.

Atistair W. Gillespie, Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce, accused the United States today of "intolerable interference" in Canada's business affairs after a United States company had ordered its Canadian subsidiary to halt a sale of $500,000 worth of office furniture to Cuba.

Under rigorous security precautions, thousands of Christian pilgrims celebrated today the birth of Jesus. A state appeals court reduced the sentence of Louis Hodges for armed robbery but upheld his conviction. He had been convicted of the armed robbery of a Mercer County supermarket in 1971 and been sentenced to a total of 32 years in state prison on charges of robbery, armed robbery and illegal possession of a gun. The appeals court reduced the term to a maximum of 15 years.

After earlier warnings concerning the depressed state of its assets, the Ford Foundation dropped the other shoe with its announcement of sharply reduced grant schedules. The international oil shortage may mean that the Texas longhorn will once again play an important role in supplying beef for the dinner tables of America.

A Melbourne magistrate ruled today that John Stonehouse, the British former Minister who vanished from Miami Beach five weeks ago, would be held until Australian immigration officials decided whether to deport him.

The trappings of New York State power remain in the old gingerbread Capitol in Albany, but the real power is shifting day by day to a warren of offices at 270 Broadway where the desks have the word "surplus" taped to them, the paint is smudgy green and the dusty overhead nines are exposed.

If New York can be a cruel, cold, hard, destructive, demanding and merciless city, at this time of year it is seductively beautiful. An affluent fairyland, it gives the lie to poverty and need and defeat; a thousand towers shower diamonds in the sky. The trees so carefully planted by city planners are like multi-colored sparklers tossed along Sixth Avenue. Wreaths and bells sway across streets in older neighborhoods, as in small towns.

A 25-year-old woman, nude except for a pair of boots, was found dead yesterday in the bathtub of an apartment at the Gorham Hotel, at 136 West 55h street. The death will be ruled "suspicious" pending an autopsy, according to a police spokesman.
Two cruise ships with about 1,000 Christmas pilgrims abroad have cut short their visits to Israel, sailing this morning instead of tomorrow without a planned visit by passengers to Jerusalem.

Christmas was observed yesterday with religious fervor, the exchange of gifts and gatherings of families and friends. Here in New York, where rain fell through much of the day, streets were for the most part all but empty of people and traffic.
The women in congress are talking about establishing their own caucus to increase their influence and unify their strategy.
The city's Health Department yesterday released the names of 17 more food establishments that failed to correct first-inspection Health Code violations by the time a second inspection was made.
An accountant linked by Congressional ivestigators with the Mafia has confessed to helping a plot to loot the city treasury of millions of dollars, a court hearing was told yesterday.

Two off-duty policemen working as bank tellers today chased three men who robbed a Bank of America branch of more than $10,000. One suspect was killed and another was captured.

Crude oil leaking from an industrial refinery tank continued to spread over a wide area of Japan's scenic Inland Sea today, causing damage to fisheries estimated by various officials at more than $20.6-million.

, who recently was traded from the Chicago White Sox of the American League to the National League's Atlanta Braves, has become a licensed thoroughbred trainer. The Oregon State Bar, after suffering a setback in a Government antitrust suit against it, has abandoned its fee schedule for simple legal work. Despite little favorable economic news, the stock market posted its second consecutive moderate advance yesterday in slow trading.

West Germany's jobless rate averaged 2.6 per cent for the entire year, the highest proportion of unemployed in 15 years, the Federal employment office said today, The present number of 600,000 unemployed can be expected to rise to one million, or 4 per cent, this winter, Josef Stingl, employment director, said.

The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would not require registration of gold investment programs by three New York concerns proposing to offer to sell gold to the public after Dec. 31.
The Saigon command said this morning that a besieged district capital, 50 miles north of here, fell to the Communists yesterday in a heavy shelling and infantry attack.

Native New Yorkers who have moved away and recent arrivals who have adopted the city as their new home were among 280 donors yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in its 63d annual appeal.

Israeli troops shelled a number of southern Lebanese villages today, causing property damage but no casualties, residents of the area said. The residents said that the Shelling began at 2 P.M. and went on intermittently for 20 minutes.
The New York Nets won by the largest margin in their history tonight as they trounced the Virginia Squires 130-85 in an American Basketball Association ation game.
Ken McFeeley, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, directed 27,000 police officers yesterday to defy a departmental order to begin wearing name tags on their uniforms next Thursday.
The day after Christmas was like the day before Christmas in many of the city's big stores-jammed with customers in a buying mood. There were some differences, of course.
An antitrust suit brought by California's Attorney General, Evelle Younger, was filed in Contra Costa County Superior Court today against the Union Oil Company.
Israel and Egypt were reported today to be very far apart in their initial positions for the next round of negotiations over Sinai.

International New and conspicuous diplomatic tension, reflected in the public and private remarks of officials in their respective capitals, seems to be building up between the United States and Israel in advance of the next round of negotiations with Egypt over the Sinai peninsula.

The essential thesis of French policy on the problem of oil prices is to seek the solution through massive, long-term industrial export programs, it has now emerged. This has become clear from the concluding reports on four recent French missions to oil-producing countries.
About 100 army veterans early this morning stormed a provincial hotel 140 miles south of here and detained a group of opposition legislators, including the Opposition party leader, Kim Young Sam.
The United States Army Silver Eagles claim to have one of the largest yo-yos around. The precision flying helicopter team uses its 58-pound, 4-foot-in-diameter vo-yo as a recruiting device.

CHINA PERCEIVED: Images and Policies in Chinese-American Relations. By John K. Fairbank. 245 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $7.95.

The Continental Can Company said yesterday that 1974 earnings will be in the range of $4 to $4.25 a share, up from $3.25 in 1973, despite all of its Inventories being converted to last-in, first-out (LIFO) valuation.

The Cairo Police Rowing Club did what few crews have been able to achieve. They defeated Harvard University's eight-oared shell in the second and final race of the International Rowing Regatta on the Nile.

The Federal Trade Commission moved today to eliminate what it called unfair and deceptive warranty practices in the mobile-home industry by reaching agreements with large manufacturers and by proposing a new rule on all future mobile. home warranties.

While at least one neighbor heard her dying screams and did nothing, a 25-year-old model was beaten to death early Christmas morning in her Kew Gardens, Queens, apartment, which virtually overlooks the scene of the murder of Catherine Genovese 10 years ago.

Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt will make an unexpected trip to Moscow on Saturday accompanied by Gen. Mohammed Abdel Gharry el-Gamasy, who was named Egypt's Commander in Chief and Defense Minister tonight, informed political sources said.
President Ford has sighed legislation that officially opens the Little League baseball program to participation by girls.

Allen Murphy scored 24 points to lead Louisville past Western Kentucky, 10781 in the opening round of the Holiday Classic Tournament tonight. The victory puts Louisville in the final against Florida State tomorrow night.

In a hitherto secret report on the DC-10 crash near Paris last March, the Federal Aviation Administration has been charged by its own inquiry board with "questionable" actions in certifying the plane and with being "ineffective" in enforcing corrective steps after a neardisaster in 1972.

The Civil Aeronautics Board's enforcement staff said today that 20 airlines, including virtually all of the nation's largest, illegally gave preferential treatment to Government officials and others whose influence could affect the airlines' future.

A Federal judge told the United States Steel Corporation today it must either shut down its No, 4 open hearth Dec. 31 as an air-pollution source or pay a $2,300 daily fine to keep it open up to 90 days.
Israel and Egypt were reported today to be very far apart in their initial positions for the next round of negotiations over Sinai.

Venezuela will take 99 per cent of the profits of the Creole Petroleum Corporation in 1974, Robert N. Dolph, president of the company, Venezuela's largest oil producer, told employes in a Christmas message released yesterday.

There are times when being a parent Isn't all it's cracked up to be, and you might find yourself looking around for a fresh point of view, a revitalizing notion. Lloyd deMause's notion could serve, or else it could scare you to death. Mr. deMause, who describes himself as a psychohistorian, sees the parent and child relationship as nothing less than the "main dynamic of history."

United States manufacturing, mining and utility companies operated at 77 per cent of rapacity in November, against october's revised 80 per cent level and last November's 87 per cent in November, 1973, a preliminary report by McGraw-Hill, Inc.'s economics departnent reported yesterday.

The Control Networks Corporation, a manufacturer of telephone switchboards, filed suit yesterday against the Continental Telephone Corporation to Compel Continental to complete its acquisition of Control Networks.

Miss Dejean Repologle, 16 years old, of Jacksonville, Fla., lost a leg today as a result of a terrorist grenade attack Sunday on a busload of Americans on a Christmas pilgrimage to the Holy Land.
An imprisoned Filipino priest went on a hunger strike yesterday to protest the alleged torture, and indefinite detention of political prisoners by the martial-law Government.
M. G. (Dan) Beard, who contributed to the development of transport aircraft, died Wednesday in the Veterans Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

New York banks are shouldering more of the nation's business loans than they have in three years as cash-squeezed corporations borrow here instead of from regional banks, which are themselves pinched for funds.

" That'll Be the Day" and "Stardust" are two British films that between them tell the story of a rock star's rise from provincial adolescence to lonely splendor at the top. Whatever their appeal for general moviegoers, the films should be of great interest to rock fans.
Gail Goodrich and Lucius Allen scored 28 points each, leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 99-89 National Basketball Association vic tory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

The immigration police today expelled from ?? Vietnam and American writer and former Foreign Service officer, John D. Marks, who was co-author of the controversial book "The C.I.A. and the Cult of Intelligence."

The Council on Foreign Relations has announced that applications for the Edward R. Murrow Fellowship for 1975-76 are now available to men and women from American print and electronic media who are interested in working in international affairs.
Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight for a vacation and said that he plans two visits to Latin America during the early months of 1975.

A global survey of political and civil liberty indicates that personal freedom diminished this year for 85 million people in seven countries. This assessment was made by Freedom House, a New York-based non profit organization that describes itself as dedicated to the strengthening Of free societies, in its 23d annual report on world freedom.

Well, it still would be a secret from anyone else, because neither Dryer nor Tarkenton will say what it is, even though Dryer might know that Tarkenton knows what Dryer knows about him.

William S. Dunn, a former State Assemblyman, died yesterday at Cobleskill Community Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived here. Mr. Dunn served in the Assembly from 1933 to 1936 and, while he was a Democrat, was one of the first to turn from the New Deal that came in with the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt as President in 1932.

John Stonehouse, the missing British Member of Parliament who turned up in Australia this week, was quoted today by a London newspaper as saying that he faked his death last month because "I was being blackmailed by men who threatened to use my political career to squeeze me dry."

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind. -The Indiana State Police recaptured an escaped state prison convict tonight, but two hostages, a woman and a teen. aged girl, were killed before the inmate surrendered at a farm house west of the prison.

The First Women's Bank of New York, unable to raise the full $4-million in capital that it expected, will soon ask the Government to authorize it to begin operations with somewhat less than that amount, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation disclosed yesterday.
A 34-year-old woman and her four children, aged 2 to 10, were found slain today in the hamlet of Preston in Henry County, a county sheriff's office spokesman said.

Jack Benny, the master commedian who won America's laughter for 50 years by portraying himself as a violinplaying miser, died today of cancer. He was 80 years old.
President Ford has signed legislation that officially opens the Little League baseball program to participation by girls.

Thanom Kittikachom, the deposed military dictator who was overthrown in a student uprising 14 months ago, returned to Thailand early today, reliable sources reported. The sources said that Marshal Thanom, who has been living in exile in Boston, had arrived at Bangkok alone aboard a Lufthansa plane.

International The Commerce Department reported that the United States balance of export and import trade slipped back into a modest deficit in November after a small surplus in October. The deficit was more than accounted for by one product, oil. [31:3.]

ROME, Dec. 30-A high court ruled today that investigations into alleged right-wing plots must be conducted from Rome. LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31-- The new year's first aeronautical adventure will seek to fulfill a century-old dream of a manned-balloon flight across the Atlantic Ocean.
Mayor Beame signed a bill into law yesterday exempting elderly persons on fixed incomes from rent increases in rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)--Rusty Tillman, a Washington Redskin linebacker, underwent surgery today to repair torn knee ligaments prior to an operation for a shoulder separation next week. Dr. James Palumbo, the team physician, performed the 90-minute operation at suburban Arlington Hospital.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 31 (UPI)--Presentation of evidence in a Federal District Court hearing on the validity of an 1868 treaty between the Sioux nation and the United States ended today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--The jury at the Watergate cover-up trial deliberated for a second day today without reaching a verdict.

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 1-- France's centralized broadcasting system went out of existence last night, to be replaced with seven state-owned television and radio companies designed to improve programming through competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) --Middle and upper-income workers face 5.85 per cent cuts in take-home pay beginning tomorrow, when withholding for Social Security taxes resumes. For a worker earning $15,000 a year, that means there will be about $17 less in this week's pay envelope.

A 40-year-old fire lieutenant dragged a seemingly dead Brooklyn woman from her burning apartment yesterday and, with other firemen, worked for 20 minutes before getting a response from the victim to heart massage and mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.

Born nine years ago with fanfare and "pizazz," the city's Night Mayor program officially and quietly slipped into limbo last Friday, without announcement.
Trading was light in fixed-income markets yesterday, with short-term attention fixed upon New Year's Eve and long-term thoughts dwelling more soberly on the huge financing calendar ahead for 1975.
HADDON HEIGHTS, Dec. 31 (UPI)--A podiatrist who was shot five times during a holdup at his home here today shot and killed one masked man and may have wounded another, the police reported.

TRENTON, Dec. 31--The plaintiffs in the successful legal attack on New Jersey's system of financing public schools said today that they would ask the State Supreme Court tomorrow to order the State Legislature to approve a state income tax, despite the fact that few legislators believe the court has that power.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (AP)--John Newcombe will get his longawaited chance tomorrow at Jimmy Connors when the two world class players meet for the title of the Australian tennis championship.

There are New Yorkers in pain today, suffering from hangovers. It is too late to prevent the hangovers, and other than making resolutions they will not keep about never getting hangovers again, there is not much the New Yorkers will do with their hangovers except to suffer them. Still, hope springs, and there are supposed to be better ways.

Jim (Catfish) Hunter signed a five-year contract estimated at $3.75-million with the New York Yankees last night, ending the most celebrated bidding war in American sports history. The total value of the pact sets a record for baseball.

The suit, filed Monday by William Knott of Fenton, accused the railroad of sex discrimination because similar hair standards were not applied to women employes.

Mrs. Walden, co-publisher of The Stewart Citizen and Citizen-Herald of Walden, succeeds Michael Milmoe, publisher of The Canastota (N.Y.) Bee Journal.

Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court suffered a stroke in the Bahamas and was taken to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where he was reported in serious condition. Page 31.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 1--A spokesman said today that former President Richard M. Nixon was preparing a statement, to be released tomorrow, about the verdicts in the Watergate cover-up trial.
New Year's Eve at the Metropolitan Opera has traditionally been filled with the gaiety of a Johann Strauss operetta or a fluffy Donizetti comedy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--The multibillion-dollar American arms sales to Iran are beginning to impose a drain on critical military skills needed by the United States armed forces, the General Accounting Office has found.

The alcoholic now can buy loss-of-income insurance to protect him when his weakness keeps him from working, the Health Insurance Institute told United Press International. The Institute says at least 17 major companies are writing such insurance. But to get it, the alcoholic must acknowledge his illness, register and place himself under medical care.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP)--John Newcombe, saying the had been "well psyched up," defeated Jimmy Connors, 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6, in the final of the Australian open tennis championships today.

The Zenith Radio Corporation has agreed to discontinue the use of the challenged TV advertising claim that "Every color TV Zenith makes is built right here in the United States by Americans like these." Which is nice, since it wasn't true in the first place.
By the time 1975 ends, 1974 might look like a great year in adland. But right now, standing this close to it, it doesn't look all that hot.

In the waiting room of the Dane County Social Services building on the outskirts of Madison, Wis., three bearded young men, dressed in ski jackets and blue jeans, sat reading magazines one day recently while a young woman sitting nearby was studying a college textbook.
BLUDENZ, Austria, Jan. 1 (Reuters)--Three West Germans were cleared tonight of starting an avalanche that killed 12 skiers at an Alpine resort near here.
Western civilization, says John Murray Cuddihy, rests on secularized Christianity, and in order to be fully accepted in it, the classical Jew was obliged to euphemize himself.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 1--Foreign Minister Yigal Allon, in the first related official Israeli comment since the postponement of the Cairo visit of the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, said today that there would be no need to coax Israel to negotiate if Egypt was really ready for significant talks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1--Four men who under President Nixon were among the most powerful officials in the nation--John N. Mitchell, H.R. Haldeman, John D. Ehrlichman and Robert C. Mardian--were convicted today on all counts in the Watergate cover-up trial.
BATON ROUGE, Jan. 1 (UPI) --Louisiana's new state Constitution, which sets forth a basic set of laws for the state's 3.5 million residents, took effect today at one minute past midnight.
Good acting, not just good dancing, highlighted the first performance this season of American Ballet Theater's production of "La Sylphide" at the City Center yesterday.

K.S. (Bud) Adams, the Houston Oilers' owner, who had a verbal battle recently with Sid Gillman, his head coach and general manager, over "lavish" spending, yesterday criticized the coach. He chided Gilman for forcing the departure of Dan Downs, the Oilers' assistant general manager.

"Single Frame Dance," the collective title for this week's Film Forum show, is a program of eight shorts, 73 seconds to 28 minutes long, each an exploration of singleframe editing. This is the process by which time can be brought to a stop or so speeded up that three months can he refined into 10 minutes of screen life, as David Rimmer does in his lovely time-lapse landscape movie, "Canadian Pacific."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 An advisory council of prominent private citizens looking into the financial problems of the Social Security System has tentatively decided to recommend a big increase in the Social Security wage base the amount subject to Social Security tax probably to $24,000 in 1976.
Ken Loeffler, a member of the basketball Hall of Fame who coached championship teams at LaSalle College, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Rumson, N.J., where he lived. His age was 72.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, who has been under some political pressure because of his business interests, promised today to devote his "full time and attention" to the job he said he expected to win next week Assembly speaker.

THERE are certain diseases, called iatrogenic, in which the treatment by a specialist creates its own new and often more serious ailment, because the system is not treated in a fundamental or balanced way.

Pupils in the fifth-grade social-studies class at Salome H. Long Memorial School in Saddle Brook, N.J., are busily preparing for a second annual bazaar later this month to raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Mayor Beame called on Governor Carey yesterday to name a special prosecutor to investigate the nursing-home industry in order to "allay any possible questions in the minds of the public." However, he emphasized that he had "full faith and confidence in the integrity" of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 2 (Reuters) The Reynolds Metals Company said today it would withdraw its legal challenge to Guyana's 1974 $6.9-million levy on metallurgical bauxite.

The stock market began the new year in an ebullier manner yesterday as bargain-hunting, especially in the depressed glamour and blue-chip issues, enabled stocks to pose a broad advance in moderate trading. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened higher, continuing a rally begun Tuesday and gradually increased their gains throughout most of the session.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 2 (AP)?James B. Longley, insurance man was sworn in tonight as Maine's 67th governor and the nation's only independent to hold such an office.

In the thirty months since the breakin at the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee in the Watergate building, nine associates or subordinates of former President Richard M. Nixon have been convicted of various felonies committed in Mr. Nixon's service. Fifteen others have pleaded guilty to felonies or misdemeanors in the Watergate matter, or in other cases "related" to Mr. Nixon.

Within three days of the play's silver anniversary on Broadway the New Phoenix Repertory Company last night presented its new production of Carson McCullers's "The Member of the Wedding." Twenty-five years can be a difficult period in the life of a play.

At 11 o'clock yesterday morning, several dozen bandaged victims of the Penn Central train crash in the Bronx sat in Fordham Hospital's cafeteria, drinking coffee, joking about their bruises and abrasions and lavishly praising the hospital staff for its efficiency and their fellow passengers for their calm and stoicism.

Casting the eye about for a place to pick up a bit of lunch after a recent visit to the Morgan Library, I thought the entrance to Giambelli, 238 Madison Avenue between 37th and 38th, looked promising, and went in.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 3 Communist forces appeared on the verge today of overrunning the first province capital in South Vietnam since they took Quang Tri on May 1, 1972, nine months before the signing of the Paris peace agreement.

Franklin Gledhill, who retired in 1965 as a vice president and director of Pan American World Airways, died yesterday in Torrington (Conn.) General Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in New Hartford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) President Ford, limping slightly from his strenuous Colorado skiing holiday, returned to Washington today and began preparing for a round of consultations on allegations that the Central Intelligence Agency illegally spied on thousands of American citizens.
DETROIT, Jan. 2 The Chrysler Corporation announced today a series of plant reopenings and closings that indicate the company has reduced some of its backlog of cars.

"Master of steam and motor vessels of any gross tons, oceans," the Coast Guard license said, and it meant that Capt. Robert Lathrop could take a ship any place in the world. Captain Lathrop, however, was in the wheelhouse of a ferry. It was the Pvt. Joseph F. Merrell, and Captain Lathrop was taking it to Staten Island.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 Governor Byrne asked the State Supreme Court today to order a wholesale redistribution of $640-million in state school aid, withdrawing all of it from wealthy and middle-income communities and diverting it to poorer districts in New Jersey.

With the City Council chamber jammed with family members, friends and politicians, Mayor Beame swore in Stanley M. Friedman as Deputy Mayor for intergovernmental affairs, and Leonard E. Yoswein as his legislative representative in Albany.
Ogilvy Mather, the country's 10th largest advertising agency, has just added its fourth executive vice president: William H. Weed.
In sharply reduced trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market rose markedly yesterday.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan 2 The Washington Capitals achieved a minor victory tonight in their 5-2 loss to the New York Islanders. They weren't shut out. The scores had read 5-0 and 7-0 at the end of two previous contests with the Islanders this season. The telling statistic at Nassau Coliseum tonight was the shots on goal; New York 46, Washington 15.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 State Controller Arthur Levitt indicated today that, contrary to Governor Carey's expressed concern, he did not expect the current state budget to slip into deficit.
ROME, Jan. 2 Pope Paul VI has denounced the Mafia in a New Year's remark for the second time in two years.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 2 (UPI) A $13-billion suit against the Mobil Oil Company was dismissed but will be refiled against several oil companies charging them with antitrust conspiracy, an attorney for Nelson Bunker Hunt said today. Mr. Hunt is a Texas oil millionaire.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 2 Nicaragua's usual political tranquillity has been abruptly shattered by the leftist guerrilla action last weekend in which a group of prominent politicians and businesssmen were kidnapped and exchanged for 14 political prisoners.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 A $225-million antitrust suit was filed in Federal District Court here today against the E. Gallo Winery, by far the nation's largest vintner.

Two hundred thirty-two persons were injured and more than 20,000 rush-hour commuters were stranded or delayed yesterday morning when a Penn Central commuter train bound for Grand Central Terminal apparently ignored a warning signal and plowed into the rear of another train just outside the Bronx Botanical Garden station.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 The stroke that Justice William O. Douglas suffered on New Year's Eve has partially paralyzed his left arm but left the rest of his body functioning and his brain undamaged.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered yesterday a rollback of freight rate increases of up to 132 per cent that went into effect on Tuesday on fresh fruits and vegetables moving from the West to the East and South.

Rosalind Reed Landes, an associate with Eastdil Realty, real estate and investment banking affiliate of Blyth Eastman Dillion, was married here last evening to William Ronald Dietz, chairman of Citicorp Business Credit, Inc., factoring and commercial finance subsidiary of Citicorp.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 Reports from Cairo that the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, postponed his trip to the Middle East for reasons of ill health have met with widespread skep- ticism in foreign diplomatic circles here.
PARIS, Jan. 2 European consumers may get some price relief from another stage of tariff cuts that became effective yesterday.

Adolescents, some of them with criminal records, many of them with severe behavioral problems, and educationally handicapped, are "wandering the streets" because, over the years, little or no notice was taken of the changing youth population pattern, and its concomitant needs, in the foster care program.
For the second consecutive month, gasoline prices dropped in the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan area, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Presdent Ford is expected to announce soon the nomination of Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan to be Ambassador to Ireland, Administration sources disclosed tonight.

SYRACUSE Not many professors are carried into the classroom on a surfboard, But Dr. Sarah Short, associate professor of nutrition at Syracuse University did make that kind of entrance recently. The reason for her outlandishness was that she wanted students to be excited about nutrition. If popping out of a cake or riding on a motorcycle will rivet her students to their seats, Dr. Short does it.

College hockey returns to New York tonight with the opening games of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Hockey Festival at Madison Square Garden. At 6:30 Cornell (with a 5-2-1 won-lost-tied record) faces off against Boston College (5-4-1), and the 9 o'clock contest pits Brown (5-2-1) against St. Lawrence (2-6). The winners will meet at 3:30 P.M. Sunday, after the 1:30 consolation game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, accused the the Mobil Oil Corporation and a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation today of blackmailing the Defense Department by threatening to cut off certain fuel supplies unless they were exempted from some legal requirements.

The nation's largest chain store organizations reported yesterday record dollar figures for their December sales and substantial gains over the level of sales in the corresponding month of 1973. In some instances, however, the higher sales did not compensate for the rise in prices, indicating that unit volume was below the year-earlier level.

"Comedians" (Komodianten), made by the late G.W. Pabst in Nazi Germany in 1941, is of primary interest to students of Pabst and German war films in general. It's not great Pabst and it's not even of much political and social importance, being overshadowed by Pabst's less innocent "Paracelsus," made two years later.

A long-awaited Vatican statement on ways to improve Roman Catholic-Jewish relations is being made available today.

A 16-year-old youth was fatally stabbed late last night in a Brooklyn housing project. The police said that his assailant, a 55-year-old man, who, like his victim, was a resident of the project, had told them the youth was one of three teen-agers who were trying to mug him.
Manila has posted the highest bid in chess history, a $5-million purse, for the 1975 world championship match between Bobby Fischer and his Russian challenger, Anatoly Karpov.

Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb, director of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and head of Psychiatry Service at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, has been asked by Governor Carey to become the State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, and has accepted, according to mental health leaders close to both men.
The coal miners' strike and the sharp decline in steel and automotive shipments took a heavy toll of the earnings of the nation's railroads in the fourth quarter of 1974.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 Israeli troops staged several raids into southern Lebanon last night in a continuing drive to keep the border area clear of Palestinian guerrillas, and the Lebanese Defense Ministry said today that the attacks left five Lebanese dead.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 2 Richard M. Nixon was decribed by an associate today as "deeply anguished" by the plight of four of his former White House and political aides who were convicted yesterday in the Watergate cover-up case.
The city recovered $510,000 from nursing homes last year following a spot check by Department of Social Services auditors of 13 of the city's 111 privately owned nursing homes.

Governor Carey has set exacting goals for his four years in Albany. His inaugural address promised a revival of social concern for the needy and afflicted in the spirit of his estimable Democratic predecessors Alfred E. Smith, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Herbert H. Lehman and Averell Harriman. But with that pledge went a stress on cutting government costs that sounded like a paraphrase of all the Republican budget-balancers from Calvin Coolidge to Gerald Ford.

In addition, most interest rates rose in the week ended Wednesday, raising the possibility that the First National City Bank might increase its prime rate today. The money supply showed its slowest growth rate in at least a year and a half.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 (UPI) Thousands of Cairo University students demonstrated on campus today in support of workers who clashed with the police yesterday in a rock-throwing melee over demands for higher pay.

A singer, who is accused along with two men of murdering her husband, a rock-music arranger, in their Lincoln Towers apartment in October, 1973, won permission in Surrogate's Court yesterday to try to collect $80,000 insurance on his life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 President Ford's economic advisers have reached virtual unanimity on the need for a tax cut to fight the recession, and the President appears to be moving toward such a decision, Administration officials reported today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 2 (AP) The first thoroughbred foal sired by Secretariat, the 1973 Triple Crown winner, has arrived just a few furlongs from the spot where the famed stallion, Man O' War, once held court.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 1 Ireland's energetic foreign minister, Garret FitzGerald, took over the presidency of the Common Market Council with the new year, and European officials here are watching to see how the highly respected but at times unorthodox official handles the community in this crisis-ridden period.

It is perhaps surprising that in half a century of contract-bridge history, nobody has written a comprehensive and practical book on defensive play. WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 The rapid growth of manufacturers' inventories slowed somewhat in November, the Commerce Department reported today.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 2 (UPI) A Superior Court judge has suspended temporarily a new state law controlling electric shock treatments for mental patients, pending a hearing on its constitutionality.
An ad that ran recently in Women's Wear Daily announced that this spring Fleet Street, a manufacturer of women's rainwear, will be "launching the most aggressive advertising campaign" in its history.

A well-dressed young man walked into Nathan's Famous Restaurant in Times Square early this morning, drew a gun and shot a patron and three security guards two of the four fatally. The board of trustees of Presbyterian Hospital announced yesterday the election of Dr. Felix E. Demartini as vice chairman of the board. He will be responsible for all scientific and health programs and professional staffing at the hospital.
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Communistled rebels pressed nearer to Phnom Penh's defense perimeter today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 2 (UPI) Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard said today that he hoped to have his second double-heart patient out of bed within 48 hours, three or four days after the New Year's Eve operation.

Gold futures dropped sharply yesterday in what one analyst called "almost panic liquidation" by European and LatinAmerican institutions. They had bought gold recently at quite high prices hoping to sell it at still higher prices to eager Americans after the legalization Tuesday of gold ownership in the United States.

BANGUI, Central African Republic, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Elizabeth Domitien of the Central African Republic became Africa's first woman premier today.

The Knicks defeated the Phoenix Suns, 117-113, inovertime last night at Madison Square Garden, and the victory did wonders for Walt Frazier's morale. The Knick's captain scored 32 points, in cluding 8 of New York's 12 points in the five-minute extra session.

Ever since it became legal for Americans to buy gold bullion at the start of this new year, the gold price has been falling like a stone. On Monday, gold hit a peak in London of $197.50 an ounce. It dropped on Tuesday and Wednesday, and yesterday fell $11.50 to close at $174.50.

Those who prefer more fleshly steeds strutting their stuff without the symbolism and psychiatry will have an opportunity to savor simpler entertainment this weekend and next at the Felt Forum of the Madison Square Garden Center.

Hoffman.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 Less than an hour after a terrorist's bomb exploded last month in Ben Yehuda Street, Jerusalem's busiest thoroughfare, the shops were open again and the sidewalks crowded. LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2--Walt W. Rostow, National Security Adviser to former President Lyndon B. Johnson, has won a temporary court order barring use of an interview with him in "Hearts and Minds," a movie about the United States involvement in Vietnam.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UPI)-- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced Friday that it had started construction of the largest blast furnace in the Western hemisphere at its Sparrows Point plant near this Maryland city.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 3-- About 25 municipal employes worked their last day for Long Beach today as the result of a layoff announced late last year by this financially pressed city.

DETROIT, Jan. 3--The American Motors Corporation in an effort to cut costs has notified its 7,500 salaried employes that it will defer putting into effect a dental plan, stop merit raises and freeze the cost of living increases at the level paid in the last quarter.

The deputy director for clinical services at the Willowbrook Development Center testified yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that conditions at the Staten Island institution had improved and in some cases were "excellent."

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia-- Arab officials say their new oil wealth will create a framework for stability in the Middle East, but their vast income is now being used to put international pressure on Israel.
WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Jan. 3 (AP)--Peter Dodge of St. Johnsbury, Vt., won the men's giant slalom competition today in the first Canadian-American amateur ski races of 1975.
Gold prices continued to drift lower yesterday as investors and speculators waited for the sale of 2 million ounces of gold by the United States Government on Monday.

PARIS, Jan. 3--Iran is to lend the French Atomic Energy Authority $1-billion for 15 years for a 10 per cent stake in a giant uranium enrichment plant being built in the Rhone Valley, French officials said today.

It is a waspwaisted city of a half-million people squeezed in on the west by Puget Sound, with the Olympic Mountains etching a snowy backdrop, and on the east by Lake Washington with the even higher backdrop of the Cascade Mountains. Seattleites can fish, hike, climb, camp and ski practically right in their own backyard.

"The Ascent of Man," a 13-part series beginning on public television tonight at 8:30 o'clock, is quite simply a milestone in television programing. The scope is immense, almost arrogant. Offering an intensely "personal view," Jacob Bronowski attempts a massive survey of science, from flint tools to the theory of relativity. Using history and philosophy, he makes plausible connections, takes gigantic leaps of imagination, transforms abstractions into the concrete. The extent of his success is remarkable.

The restaurant business, by its very nature, is transient. And the landmarks business, by its nature, is intended to be rather permanent. (The first was Fraunces Tavern, which is actually newer it is a 1907 reconstruction of a Georgian building.)

Charles E. Means, national director of manpower for the Boy Scouts of America, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 2400 Johnson Avenue, the Bronx. He was 62 years old.
The stock market advanced broadly yesterday in accelerated trading sparked by the Federal Reserve Board's reduction of its discount rate late Friday.

Mayor Beame yesterday rebutted Federal assertions that the city had been delinquent in administering an emergency jobs program and implied that if the program had been delayed, the blame might rest with the regional office of the United States Department of Labor.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (Reuters) The troubled British car industry was plunged into further gloom today as Chrysler (U.K.), Ltd., Co. announced that it was putting thousands of workers on a three-day week.
Steel production got off to a slow start this year, with output last week dropping 12 per cent from the year-ago level to 2,483,000 tons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President Ford has signed bills honoring former Presidents Harry S. Truman and Herbert Hoover.

The nursing home scandal poses two stern tests for Governor Carey. The first is whether he can set in motion an effective, credible and thorough investigation of the problem and the second is whether he can turn this wretched system around so that it serves the citizens of the State of New York rather than a tight circle of selfish, callous traders in human misery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 An extensive investigation by the Atomic Energy Commission has been unable to determine how a woman technician who had worked in a nuclear fuel processing plant in Oklahoma came to swallow microscopic amounts of plutonium.

TRENTON, Jan. 6 Angered by what was described as continuing "poor and inadequate coverage of New Jersey news and events," the State Senate today set up a commission to investigate television news coverage by stations in New York and Philadelphia.

Dr. Nelson W. Cornell, prominent orthopedic surgeon and former chief of orthopedics at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died last Tuesday at the Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 78 years old and had returned to live in Chenung, N.Y., his birthplace.

Richard A. Corroon Jr., board chairman of the Corroon Black Corporation,international insurance brokers, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 68 years old and had homes here and in Amagansett, L.I.

Helen Green Daniels, civic worker and historian, died Sunday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. She was 76 years old and lived at 5 Coulter Avenue, Pawling, N.Y.
Ray Morgan; a television and radio announcer, narrator and actor, died Sunday of cancer in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He lived at 92 Howard Park Drive, Tenafly, N.J.

Relations have reached a low point between the 19 municipal hospitals and the voluntary, or nonprofit, hospitals, which for the last 10 years have supplied, under contract, most of the professional services in the city facilities.
The manager and two young clerks of an upper West Side grocery store were gravely wounded last night by a gunman who had apparently argued with his victims earlier in the day, the police said.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (AP) The Soviet press reported today that Secretary of State Kissinger's refusal to rule out force in dealing with Middle East oil problems had "caused a stormy reaction in the world."

On rare occasions, truth bridge-table truth that is can be stranger than fiction. Plays can arise that are so unusual that it would be hard to construct such a situation.

The State Department of Mental Hygiene underspent its state appropriation by several hundred milliom dollars a year for the last four years, using the money it "saved" to reduce the need for new state funds rather than for expansion, a state budget official testified yesterday.

A bill to establish a state Office of Cultural Resources, which would incorporate the present New York State Council on the Arts and consolidate cultural policy-making for some 40 other state agencies, will be introduced in the Legislature this month by State Senator William T. Conklin, Republican of Brooklyn.

TUCUMAN, Argentina, Jan. 6 (AP) Two Argentine army generals and 11 other military officers died when their twinengine plane crashed and burst into flames about 35 miles from Tucuman in northwest Argentina during a heavy rainstorm, the authorities said today.
CONCORD, N.H., Jan 6 (AP) New Hampshire's role in deciding the disputed WymanDurkin race for the United States Senate is over and must now be left to the Senate, the State Supreme Court said today.
Walter Lippmann, the political columnist, has left the bulk of his more than $500,000 estate to Harvard College, his alma mater, while giving his papers to Yale University.

The Board of Education, which was ordered by Mayor Beame to lay off 995 teachers and other employes as part of an effort to reduce the city's budget deficit, will dismiss no employes, it was disclosed yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (UPI) John D. Ehrlichman, a con victed Watergate conspirator, won a postponement today of his perjury trial in connection with the break-in at the office of the former psychiatrist of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.
In November, 1972, Joe Linko was making one of his periodic unofficial inspection tours of the highways in New York City. Mr. Linko makes his living repairing TV sets in the Bronx.

A lawsuit was filed yesterday by the American Film Theater, Inc., charging that major motion-picture companies had conspired to violate antitrust laws by threatening by boycott or blacklist exhibitors who presented the plaintiff's Theateron-Film series.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 6 (AP) Defense Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon had been reinforced by Palestinian troops frm Syria armed with missiles.

PARIS, Jan. 6 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia arrived on an official visit today, marking the end of strained relations between his country and France over French nuclear tests in the South Pacific.
More than 300 people attended a brief funeral service yesterday morning for Milton Cross at All Angels Episcopal Church, 81st Street and West End Avenue.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 6 The Du Pont Company denied today that it "has intervened or wishes to intervene in the editorial processes of the Wilmington newspapers" both of which are controlled by the company.

LONDON, Jan. 6 Priceless treasures from a collection of ancient marble vases and sculpture of an 18th-century archeologist and diplomat may come to light as a result of the discovery of remains of a wrecked warship in which they sank nearly 180 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Alan Greenspan, chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the nation's economic slump could last longer and be deeper than anticipated and predicted that unemployment would approach 8 per cent of the workforce this year.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 Governor Carey, in his first message to the Legislature on Wednesday, will propose an income-tax credit of up to $10 a year for political contributions as a way of stimulating public support for political campaigns.

These days, perhaps only Boris Spassky shares Bisguier's love of the formal pawn center and the wideopen attacking play to which it can give rise.

When "The Ascent of Man" has its United States premiere at 8:30 tonight on the Public Broadcasting Service, it will be required viewing for about 25,000 people in all parts of the country. That is the estimated number of students enrolled at more than 200 colleges and junior colleges in credit courses based on the television series created by the late Dr. Jacob Bronowski. The series traces the history of Western culture through science.
Anyone who chooses to give a tuba concert is a dedicated soul indeed; a man who, like Harvey Phillips, plans a series of five in one month has to be obsessed with doing things in depth.

Coleman B. McGovern, a member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1916 to 1971, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while vacationing in Bermuda. He remained a limited partner in the brokerage firm of Prescott, Ball Turben. He was 83 years old and lived at 1160 Park Avenue.

Aroused by a recent House committee report assailing the Federal Aviation Administration's record on air safety, the Transportation Department announced yesterday that it had called an F.A.A. management meeting for Jan. 15 to take an "in-depth" look at the agency's operations.

The Board of Education, which was ordered by Mayor Beame to lay off 995 teachers and other employes as part of an effort to reduce the city's budget deficit, will dismiss no employes, it was disclosed yesterday.

For the last two years, Paula Goldstein has been working with the multihandicapped children of Intermediate School 237 in Queens, cheerfully prodding them through laborious exercises, devising equipment to enable them to get maximum use unresponsive limbs and gently encouraging them to talk from their unresponsive limbs and gently encouraging them to talk about their agonizing problems of social adjustment.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 6 Harry H. Wellington, a professor of law at Yale specializing in labor and Constitutional issues, was named today as dean of the Yale Law School.

A.G. Becker Co., Inc., following an investment of nearly $25-million in European capital, has changed its name to the Becker Warburg-Paribas Group, Inc., Paul R. Judy, president and chief executive of the new holding company, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The bill allowing heavier trucks on the interstate highway system, signed by President Ford Saturday, passed Congress after a lobbying drive that included last-minute campaign contributions to 117 members of the House.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 6 All was in order at the Bowie race track today as its meeting got off to a belated start. Originally listed to begin last Thursday, the opening of the 60-day session was delayed because of a strike by the Independent Association of Race Track Employes, a strike that also closed down the final program of the Laurel race track card on New Year's Day.

Two young armed men were killed and a shotgun-carrying member of a Bronx youth gang was seriously wounded last night by police gunfire touched off when the victims attempted to flee during a routine traffic check near the Bronx Zoo.

Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb, in his first official remarks after being sworn in yesterday as the State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, strongly supported the release of mental patients for rehabilitation in community facilities, but stressed the need for aftercare for such patients.

The commission named by President Ford to investigate charges of domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency would inspire greater confidence if so many of its members did not have close ties to the national security establishment.

Dr. Edward J. McCormick of Toledo, Ohio, who was president of the American Medical Association in 1953-54, died there yesterday in St. Vincent Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Toledo.

Paul H. Sampliner, a founder and former president of the Independent News Company, Inc., a distribution organization, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 150 Central Park South.
