CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. Steven Bock's parents have long forgotten the name of the doctor who first diagnosed his deafness. They call him "Dr. Clicker" because of the sound made by the instrument he held the baby's ears.

HOUSTON, Jan. 7 (AP) The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women accused the National Collegiate Athletic Association of athletic piracy today because of the N.C.A.A. plan to establish a national championships program for women.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (AP) Julie Heldman, after a morning at a local playground conducting a clinic, defeated Pam Teeguarden, 6-3, 6-4, and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $75,000 opening tournament of the Virginia Slims women's tennis tour today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) The Justice Department has submitted two nominations to the judge who will choose a trustee to oversee the divestiture of ITT Levitt and Sons, Inc., from the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

At 8 o'clock there is "Antonio and the Mayor," at 9:30 o'clock, "Miles to Go Before I Sleep:" Both are well produced, competently acted, superior to most commercialTV fare and, ultimately, soothing.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Jan. 7 In a carnival atmosphere, Virgin Islanders danced in the streets in homemade costumes, heard speeches, watched parades and danced in ballrooms through the night after witnessing the swearing-in yesterday of the islands' second elected Governor, Cyril E. King.
BOSTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) An objection that women had not been equally considered for the rand jury that indicted a doctor for manslaughter in the death of an aborted fetus was overruled today.
Amanda Blake, the "Miss Kitty" of "Gunsmoke" fame on television, is having some real-life problems these days as a protector of wildlife.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) A campaign to end the difference in the income-tax rate of the single and the married will be renewed when Congress returns next week.

Several more companies announced yesterday changes to last-in, first-out (LIFO) inventory accounting, a method that reduces earnings, at least in the short term,. but also cuts the concern's income tax liability.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 The State Department said today that the United States and India had resolved "in principle" problems that had arisen over the terms of American food shipments to India.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 Governor Carey will propose in his State of the State message tomorrow that added funds be devoted to the court system. STAR BOUND Tonight begins a new film-lecture series, "Beyond Science Fiction," at the American museum-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West at 81st Street. Here, sci-movie fans can watch appropriate movies in the tingling, skylike darkness of the dome and hear authoritative spokesmen on the world of fantasy founded on fact. The program there are four successive Wednesday features at 7, with short subjects is a result of last summer's popular science-fiction movie festival at the planetarium.

As a drawback there were problems of pitch in the young cellist's technique. In his recital Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the plus factor remained and the minus factor was considerably diminished. In fact, except where he occasionally slid a tone, the cellist's pitch was seldom flawed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 Some Administration energy planners say that they fear President Ford's emerging enlergy policy calling for a $3a-barrel tax on crude oil will send inflationary shocks through the depressed economy, aggravate the recession and possibly provoke new increases in the price of foreign crude oil.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 7 The Bollingen Prize in Poetry of the Yale University Library has been awarded to A.R. Ammons, a 48-year-old professor of English at Cornell University.

NICE, France One little-noticed revolution in American bureaucratic life has been the swift emergence of the United States female diplomat. Within the brief period 1971-1974 the number of women Foreign Service officers enrolled in the State Department and the U.S. Information Agency has tripled, rising from 4.9 per cent to 15 per cent.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation announced in Pittsburgh yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its Thomas Strip division in Warren, Ohio, to Hille Muller of Dusseldorf, West Germany. Terms of the transaction, which is expected to be closed next June, were not disclosed.

PARIS Jan. 7 Despite a renewed decline in gold prices brought on by the evident reluctance of Americans to snap up the metal as was expected of them by European speculators, the dollar continued dropping toward new lows today in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 Without an emergency increase in military aid by Congress, the Defense Department probably will run out of funds to buy ammunition for Cambodia this April, Pentagon officials said today.
BATON ROUGE, Jan. 7 (AP) Henson Moore, a Republican, defeated Jeff LaCaze, a Democrat, tonight in their re-run of Louisiana's 6th Congressional District election.

BUFFALO, Jan. 7 (AP) The Buffalo Braves blew a 17point lead in the first quarter, then came back to defeat the Los Angeles Lakers, 115-107, behind Bob McAdoo's 44 points and 18 rebounds in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

Expected weakness developed in gold futures prices yesterday, reflecting traders' disappointment at the low level of many bids at the Government's. gold auction Monday. After a recovery late in the day, closing prices on the Commodity Exchange for the spot January delivery were $172 4/10 an ounce, down $1.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 On the night of last Nov. 5, as Gov. Malcolm Wilson went down to defeat and the Democrats won control of the State Assembly, a trim, gray-haired man whose name few people outside the world of politics would recognize suddenly became the most powerful Republican in the State of New York.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 In the first significant attempt to reduce prices to stimulate car sales since the automobile industry went into its deep decline, the Chrysler Corporation plans to announce a system of rebates next Sunday that will save buyers of certain new Chrsyler cars from $200 to $400.

The special state prosecutor's office charged yesterday that Irving Goldman, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, lied when he denied being the president of a dummy candy company that was set up to funnel thousands of dollars in payoffs to Transit Authority policemen and officials.

TRENTON, Jan. 7 John P. Tully, accused of being a gangland killer and drug smuggler, pleaded guilty in state and Federal courts today to all charges against him and agreed to turn state's evidence in the trial of members and associates of the Campisi family.

SHAWANO, Wis., Jan. 7 About 250 Wisconsin National Guardsmen arrived in this farming and dairy region today and positioned themselves on the wooded periphery of an abandoned Roman Catholic novitiate that was seized on New Year's Day by a group of armed Menominee Indians demanding that the facility be deeded to them.
Burton K. Wheeler, a powerful voice in the Senate against intervention in World War II, died late Monday night, apparently of a stroke, in his home in Washington. He was 92 years old.

Warren H. Phillips, president of Dow Jones Co., Inc., which publishes The Wall Street Journal, will be elected chief executive of the company in March, succeeding William F. Kerby, Dow Jones announced yesterday.

Texasgulf, Inc., announced yesterday reduced prices for copper products sold here and in Canada. Now the issue is: Should the tiebreaker take the form of sudden death or lingering death?

PATERSON, Jan. 9--Rose Costanza, the widow of a wealthy Clifton pavin contractor who was shot to death three years ago, was accused at a civil trial today of slaying him because "he could not satisfy her exorbitant demands in money and sex."

AMERE 18 miles off the east coast of Puerto Rico lies the tiny island of Vieques. It has lonely beaches, clear waters, a modicum of historic and natural sites even a weeklong summer festival. Yet Vieques has escaped the tourist incursions of other Caribbean islands.

Four West European countries that are in the market for new jet fighter planes are reportedly shying from purchases in the United States be- cause of fears over the political repercussions of the cost.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The 94th Congress, dominated by Democrats and spurred by aggressive freshmen, will convene Tuesday to search for quick remedies to a deepening national recession.

The Internal Revenue Service estimates that taxpayers in the New York area have several billion dollars worth of Federal refunds due on their 1974 incomes. The agency's Manhattan and Brooklyn districts are designing campaigns intended to bring about early delivery of the refunds.

Karl Pretshold, a former public relations counselor to the city's Health Department, died Saturday in Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 455 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 The Assembly formally adopted the Democratic majority's sweeping changes in rules and procedures today, with the Republicans, in their new role as the minority, calling the proposals "routine housekeeping changes" and offering their own amendments.
KUWAIT "In Saudi Arabia we are accused of being loose women," Princess Hussa alSabah sail with a smile, as she drove her Cadillac past the fashionable French boutiques in downtown Kuwait City.
Marvin M. Karpatkin, a prominent civil rights advocate, died here yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 48. He was stricken while jogging outside his home, 280 Riverside Drive.
Alexander A. Falk, a former State Senator and president of the State Civil Service Commission, died yesterday at his home in Margaretville, N.Y. He was 74 years old.
Can a pair of trousers stand in the way of art research? Yes, if a woman is wearing them, says the Frick Art Reference Library, a private research facility for art scholars.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 Secretary General Waldheim said today that there was "plenty of room for improvement" in the competence of the United Nations staff and in the procedures for hiring them.

The Soviet national boxing team, undefeated in international competition but still feeling the effects of jet lag, worked out yesterday at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum in preparation for a four-match tour of the United States.
Jane L. Alpert received a 27month prison sentence yester day for conspiracy to bomb buildings and for bail-jumping five years ago when she was a militant radical opposed to the war in Vietnam.

Ernest M. Whitcomb, retired president of the First National Bank of Amherst, Mass., and former chairman of the United States Envelope Company, died yesterday in Northampton, Mass. He was 92 years old and lived in Amherst.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 13 The 24th annual East-West All-Star Game of the National Basketball Association, in streamlined format, will take place tomorrow night in Phoenix for the first time, as the climax of what has become this league's only true annual convention.

Trading in all securities of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., which had been scheduled for resumption on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, has been suspended through Jan. 22 by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 12 A Federal jury here has awarded a $500,000 judgment to a worker who was disabled in a 1973 apartment building collapse in which 14 workers were killed and 34 were injured.

Four women filed a class-action suit against Newsday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, charging that the Long Island newspaper had violated the civil rights of its women employes and of job applicants.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 13 Ragged refugees from the besieged town of Neak Luong, which commands Cambodia's crucial Mekong River supply line, arrived in Phnom Penh by boat today and described the town as under steady enemy shellfire and very short of food, with thousands going hungry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The United States charged North Vietnam today with "flagrant violation" of the Vietnam cease-fire agreements and urged the Soviet Union, China and others to persuade Hanoi to resume the political talks with the Saigon Government that were broken off last year.

A record total of $1.56-billion of Series E and H Savings Bonds were sold in the fourth quarter, up from $1.31-billion in the 1973 final quarter, but down from $1.62-billion in last year's third quarter, the Treasury reported yesterday.

The Bank of New York Company, Inc., parent of the Bank of New York, yesterday reported fourth-quarter operating earnings of $10.4-million, or $1.73 per share, up 10.3 per cent from year-earlier levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Presidential commission investigating alleged domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency held its first meeting today and was told by Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, a former C.I.A. director, that the number of "misdemeanors" by the agency was "quite small."

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 13 (AP) Angus S. Alston, who rose from a telephone coin box collector to head the giant Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, died here yesterday at the age of 60. A company spokesman said he had been suffering from cancer.

LONDON, Jan. 13 Hopes for forceful Government action to deal with Britain's economic crisis sparked a big rally in the stock market here, with prices scoring their best gains since October in the last two trading sessions.

For her first "post-operative evaluation" since her surgery Sept. 28 for breast cancer, Betty Ford went to Bethesda Naval Hospita] yesterday for a four-hour session that included laboratory tests and an examination by her surgeon, Dr. William Fouty. They produced "no evidence of a recurrence" of malignancy.
HUMACAO, Puerto Rico, Jan. 13 (AP) Arthur Ashe overcame a leg injury to beat Marty Riessen, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, in the $60,000 CBS classic tennis tournament today.
UNION, Jan. 13 (UPI) A Federal official pledged today to keep the identities of bookies confidential if they cooperated with a new law requiring them to pay a 2 per cent Federal excise tax.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) Former Senator Eugene McCarthy, seeking the Presidency for the third time, proposed several measures today to help solve the nation's economic problems.

The La Salle String Quartet, which has been concentrating on contemporary music ever since its four members came together in 1954, started a four-concert series last night in Tully Hall. In these concerts the entire oeuvre of Schoenberg, Berg and Webern for string quartet will be played (the remaining concerts will be given on Jan. 27, April 28 and May 1).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) An unidentified group of American Indians will buy the Willard Hotel two blocks from the White House for $7-million, the National American Indian Council said today.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 13 (AP) Top-ranked Indiana, led by Scott May's 19 points, solved Minnesota's zone defense in the second half tonight and rolled to its 18th consecutive victory a 79-59 decision over the 16th-ranked Gophers in a Big Ten Conference basketball game.

PARIS, Jan. 13 The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that Western industrial nations may be producing almost as much energy as they consume by 1985 if they take advantage of potentials for conservation of expanded output and if world prices remain about unchanged.

In his seventies and eighties, Dr. Albert Schweitzer had the kind of fame that at the time seemed irreversible. More than any other living man, he was accepted as the conscience of the civilized world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Congressional Democratic leaders pledged today to take decisive action to revive the nation's slumping economy, and later gave a mixed review to President Ford's new economic proposals.

Fire Department officials disclosed yesterday that an untended fireplace in which wood continued to burn after the family went to bed, was the cause of the fire that killed a 31-year old mother and two of her three children as it swept through their duplex apartment at 133 East 80th Street early yesterday morning.

A recent memorandum from the Office of Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare declared that the Federal Government's "affirmative action" requirements for college faculty hiring "must not operate to restrict consideration to minorities and women only." Rather, the memo continued, the affirmative action program was intended to forbid "differential standards based on race, color, sex, religion or national origin."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Democratic Representatives voted today to abolish the House Internal Security Committee, which for 45 years, under various names, has been the spearhead of anti-Communist investigations on Capitol Hill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) An unarmed man waving a brown bag tried to force an Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 to take him to Puerto Rico today, but was thwarted by another passenger and a crewman who forced him into a lavatory.

HARTFORD, Jan. 13 Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut said today that she was as outraged as any citizen would be that her home in Windsor Locks had been broken into, but that she would not order the state police to post a regular watch on the place.

A heavy-snow warning for the metropolitan area was put into effect by the National Weather Service yesterday afternoon but was called off early in the evening when the storm moving up the coast veered out to sea.

PARIS, Jan. 13 Two men armed with bazookas fired rockets today as an Israeli airliner with 136 passengers was about to take off for New York from Orly airport. The rockets missed that plane but hit a parked Yugoslav aircraft and a storage building.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 The Carey administration wants to cut 8,000 to 9,000 employes from the state payroll by attrition in the next fiscal year, the Acting State Budget Director said today.

A 19-year-old student pilot with only eight hours of flying lessons skillfully landed a four-passenger, single-engine plane at the Westchester County Airport after the pilot lost consciousness and his foot jammed the controls.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 13 The Texas Legislature that convenes here tomorrow for its 20week biennial session will have $1.4-billion more to spend than it had two years ago. As could be expected, there are all kinds of ideas on how to get rid of the surplus.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 A former South Korean chief of naval operations urged the Korean military services today to overthrow President Park Chung Hee.
MIAMI, Jan. 13 (AP) Fran Tarkenton, Minnesota Viking quarterback, citing a sore arm, was excused today from playing in the Pro Bowl game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Presidential commission investigating alleged domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency held its first meeting today and was told by Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, a former C.I.A. director, that the number of "misdemeanors" by the agency was "quite small."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 President Ford, under enormous political pressure to act decisively to restore the nation's nose-diving economy, has now turned sharply away from the policies he embraced after taking the oath of office just five months ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 13 (Reuters) Indonesia will withdraw her troops from the International Commission for Control and Supervision in South Vietnam if the situation there puts them in danger, according to Foreign Minister Adam Malik.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Richard M. Nixon, reported earlier as having spent a quiet 62d birthday last Thursday, actually was feted at a surprise party at his San Clemente, Calif., estate, one of the participants said tonight.
It is amazing that Jerome Robbins's "Goldberg Variations" is now nearly four years old. In a sense, it still seems a new work. The reason for this is probably its aural and visual complexities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Senate Rules Committee was unable to agree today on what the full Senate should do about the contested New Hampshire Senate seat when the 94th Congress convenes tomorrow.

PHOENIX,, Ariz., Jan. 12 Navajo officials havve angrily rejected a charge by Senator Barry Goldwater that labor union funds were responsible for the extra-ordinarily high turnout of Navajo voters in the November general election.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Jan. 13 (UPI) The Dennison Manufacturing Company joined today the companies protesting the Federal Trade Commissioner's proposed settlement of an antitrust complaint against the Xerox Corporation.
Organized baseball is safe from destruction for at least another season.

MADRID, Jan. 13 (Reuters) Village priests are calling on their congregations to pray for rain as weather experts predict that the drought that has stricken a vast area of central and southern Spain will continue.

Tim St. Lawrence of the New York Athletic Club won his ninth straight Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior pole-vault championship last night in the airdome at Columbia's Baker Field.

Immigration officials estimate that there are six to seven million aliens in this country who entered unlawfully, including 1.3 million in the metropolitan area. WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) President Ford will nominate William T. Coleman Jr., a Philadelphia lawyer, as Transportation Secretary in his first appointment of a black Cabinet member, the White House announced today.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 Governor Carey said today that he was asking the Governors of the Northeastern states to present a unified response to President Ford's tax and economic proposals to prevent undue hardship to the region.

The Diamond Shamrock Corporation reported yesterday increases of 105 per cent in earnings for the fourth quarter and 87 per cent for last year on sales gains of 49 and 48 per cent, respectively. All 1974 results set records for the chemicals, oil and natural gas producer based in Cleveland.
